  <div class="section" id="oracle-cloud-infrastructure-cli-command-reference">
<h1>Oracle Cloud Infrastructure CLI Command Reference<a class="headerlink" href="#oracle-cloud-infrastructure-cli-command-reference" title="Permalink to this headline">¶</a></h1>
<p><a class="reference internal" href="oci.html"><span class="doc">Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (oci)</span></a></p>
</div>
<div class="section" id="announcements">
<h1>Announcements<a class="headerlink" href="#announcements" title="Permalink to this headline">¶</a></h1>
<div class="section" id="interactive-features">
<h2>Interactive Features<a class="headerlink" href="#interactive-features" title="Permalink to this headline">¶</a></h2>
<p>OCI CLI offers interactive features to guide you through command usage.</p>
<dl class="simple">
<dt>Enabling them allows:</dt><dd><ul class="simple">
<li><p>Suggestions and autocompletion to help compose commands;</p></li>
<li><p>Color-coded suggestions to distinguish required parameters from optional parameters where required parameters are also highlighted with (*) for accessibility support; and</p></li>
<li><p>Quick references display alongside suggestions to recognize command and parameter purposes.</p></li>
</ul>
</dd>
</dl>
<p>Try the interactive features anytime with the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">-i</span></code> option:</p>
<div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="n">oci</span> <span class="o">-</span><span class="n">i</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
<p>Read more on <a class="reference external" href="https://docs.oracle.com/iaas/Content/API/SDKDocs/cliusing_topic-Using_Interactive_Mode.htm">OCI Documentation</a>.</p>
</div>

<div class="section" id="oracle-cloud-infrastructure-python-sdk-ocisdkversion">
<h1>Oracle Cloud Infrastructure Python SDK - 2.78.0<a class="headerlink" href="#oracle-cloud-infrastructure-python-sdk-ocisdkversion" title="Permalink to this headline">¶</a></h1>
<p>This is the public Python SDK for Oracle Cloud Infrastructure. Python 3.6, 3.7, 3.8 and 3.9 are supported.</p>
<div class="highlight-pycon notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="gp">&gt;&gt;&gt; </span><span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">oci</span>
<span class="gp">&gt;&gt;&gt; </span><span class="n">config</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">oci</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">config</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">from_file</span><span class="p">(</span>
<span class="gp">... </span>    <span class="s2">&quot;~/.oci/config&quot;</span><span class="p">,</span>
<span class="gp">... </span>    <span class="s2">&quot;integ-beta-profile&quot;</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="gp">&gt;&gt;&gt; </span><span class="n">identity</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">oci</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">identity</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">IdentityClient</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">config</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="gp">&gt;&gt;&gt; </span><span class="n">user</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">identity</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">get_user</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">config</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">&quot;user&quot;</span><span class="p">])</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">data</span>
<span class="gp">&gt;&gt;&gt; </span><span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">user</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="go">{</span>
<span class="go">  &quot;compartment_id&quot;: &quot;ocid1.tenancy.oc1...&quot;,</span>
<span class="go">  &quot;description&quot;: &quot;Integration testing user [BETA]&quot;,</span>
<span class="go">  &quot;id&quot;: &quot;ocid1.user.oc1...&quot;,</span>
<span class="go">  &quot;inactive_status&quot;: null,</span>
<span class="go">  &quot;lifecycle_state&quot;: &quot;ACTIVE&quot;,</span>
<span class="go">  &quot;name&quot;: &quot;testing+integ-beta@corp.com&quot;,</span>
<span class="go">  &quot;time_created&quot;: &quot;2016-08-30T23:46:44.680000+00:00&quot;</span>
<span class="go">}</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
<p>To get started, head over to the <a class="reference internal" href="installation.html#install"><span class="std std-ref">installation instructions</span></a> or see more examples in the
<a class="reference internal" href="quickstart.html#id1"><span class="std std-ref">quickstart</span></a> section.</p>
<p>The most recent list of supported services is located on the <a class="reference external" href="https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/iaas/Content/API/SDKDocs/pythonsdk.htm#ServicesSupported">Python SDK</a> page on the Oracle Cloud Infrastructure Documentation site.</p>

Please check the <a class="reference internal" href="backward-compatibility.html#backward-compatibility"><span class="std std-ref">Backward Compatibility</span></a> section if you are using <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">oraclebmc</span></code>.</p>

<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title1" class="topic nested0" id="Overview_of_the_Compute_Service">
<h1 class="title topictitle1" id="ariaid-title1">Overview of the Compute Service</h1>
<div class="body">
<p>Oracle Cloud Infrastructure
<a class="xref" href="https://www.oracle.com/cloud/compute/">Compute</a> lets you provision and manage compute hosts, known as instances. You can create instances as needed to meet your compute and application requirements. After you create an instance, you can access it securely from your computer, restart it, attach and detach volumes, and terminate it when you're done with it. Any changes made to the instance's local drives are lost when you terminate it. Any saved changes to volumes attached to the instance are retained.</p>
<p>Oracle Cloud Infrastructure offers both bare metal and virtual machine instances:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<strong>Bare metal:</strong> A bare metal compute instance gives you dedicated physical server access for highest performance and strong isolation. </li>
<li>
<p><strong>Virtual machine:</strong> A virtual machine (VM) is an independent computing environment that runs on top of physical bare metal hardware. The virtualization makes it possible to run multiple VMs that are isolated from each other. VMs are ideal for running applications that do not require the performance and resources (CPU, memory, network bandwidth, storage) of an entire physical machine.</p>
<p>An Oracle Cloud Infrastructure VM compute instance runs on the same hardware as a bare metal instance, leveraging the same cloud-optimized hardware, firmware, software stack, and networking infrastructure.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Learn more about the <a class="xref" href="https://www.oracle.com/cloud/compute/">Compute service and related services</a>.</p>
<p>Be sure to review <a class="xref" href="../References/bestpracticescompute.htm">Best Practices for Your Compute Instances</a> for important information about working with your Compute instances.</p>
<p>Linux instances on Oracle Cloud Infrastructure can use Oracle Ksplice to apply critical kernel patches without rebooting. Ksplice can maintain specific kernel versions for Oracle Linux, CentOS, and Ubuntu. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/oracle-linux/ksplice/index.htm">Oracle Ksplice</a>.</p>
<p>Compute is Always Free eligible. For more information about Always Free resources, including capabilities and limitations, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/FreeTier/freetier.htm">Oracle Cloud Infrastructure Free Tier</a>.</p>
</div>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title2" class="topic nested1" id="instance-types">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title2">Instance Types</h2>
<div class="body">
<p> When you create a compute instance, you can select the most appropriate type of instance for your applications based on characteristics such as the number of CPUs, amount of memory, and network resources.</p>
<section class="section" id="instance-types__instance-features"><h3 class="title sectiontitle vl-include-in-page-toc">Instance Features</h3>
<p>Oracle Cloud Infrastructure offers features that let you customize your instances for specialized workloads and security requirements.</p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Burstable instances</strong> are virtual machine (VM) instances that provide a baseline level of CPU performance with the ability to burst to a higher level to support occasional spikes in usage. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="../References/burstable-instances.htm">Burstable Instances</a>.</li>
<li><strong>Shielded instances</strong> harden the firmware security on bare metal hosts and virtual machines (VMs) to defend against malicious boot level software. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="../References/shielded-instances.htm" title="Shielded instances harden the firmware security on bare metal hosts and virtual machines (VMs) to defend against malicious boot level software." uk-tooltip="">Shielded Instances</a>.</li>
<li><strong>Extended memory VMs</strong> are VM instances that provide more memory and cores than available with standard shapes. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="../References/extended-memory-vm-instances.htm" title="Extended memory virtual machine (VM) instances are VM instances that provide more memory and cores than available with standard shapes." uk-tooltip="">Extended Memory VM Instances</a>.</li>
</ul>
</section>
<section class="section" id="instance-types__shapes"><h3 class="title sectiontitle vl-include-in-page-toc">Shape Types</h3>
<p>Oracle Cloud Infrastructure offers a variety of shapes that are designed to meet a range of compute and application requirements:</p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Standard shapes:</strong> Designed for general purpose workloads and suitable for a wide range of applications and use cases. Standard shapes provide a balance of cores, memory, and network resources. Standard shapes are available with Intel, AMD, and Arm-based processors.</li>
<li><strong>DenseIO shapes:</strong>Designed for large databases, big data workloads, and applications that require high-performance local storage. DenseIO shapes include locally-attached NVMe-based SSDs.
</li>
<li><strong>GPU shapes:</strong>
Designed for hardware-accelerated workloads. GPU shapes include Intel, AMD, or Arm CPUs with NVIDIA or AMD graphics processors.
 Some bare metal GPU shapes support cluster networking.</li>
<li><strong>High performance computing (HPC) and optimized shapes:</strong>
Designed for high-performance computing workloads that require high frequency processor cores. Bare metal HPC and optimized shapes support cluster networking.
</li>
</ul>
<p>For more information about the available bare metal and VM shapes, see <a class="xref" href="../References/computeshapes.htm">Compute Shapes</a>, <a class="xref" href="https://www.oracle.com/cloud/compute/bare-metal.html">Bare Metal Instances</a>, <a class="xref" href="https://www.oracle.com/cloud/compute/virtual-machines.html">Virtual Machines</a>, and <a class="xref" href="https://www.oracle.com/cloud/compute/gpu.html">Virtual Machines and Bare Metal (GPU)</a>.</p>
</section>
</div>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title3" class="topic nested2" id="flexible_shapes">
<h3 class="title topictitle3 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title3">Flexible Shapes</h3>
<div class="body">
<p><a class="xref" href="../References/computeshapes.htm#flexible">Flexible shapes</a> let you customize the number of OCPUs and the amount of memory allocated to an instance. When you <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/launchinginstance.htm" title="Create a bare metal or virtual machine (VM) compute instance." uk-tooltip="">create a VM instance</a> using a flexible shape, you select the number of OCPUs and the amount of memory that you need for the workloads that run on the instance. The network bandwidth and number of VNICs scale proportionately with the number of OCPUs. This flexibility lets you build VMs that match your workload, enabling you to optimize performance and minimize cost.</p>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title4" class="topic nested2" id="capacity_types">
<h3 class="title topictitle3 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title4">Capacity Types</h3>
<div class="body">
<div>
<p>You can choose the type of host capacity to use when launching compute instances. On-demand capacity is the default, but you can use preemptible capacity, capacity reservations, or dedicated capacity instead.</p>
<ul>
<li><strong>On-demand capacity:</strong> Pay for only the compute capacity that you use. With on-demand capacity, you pay for compute capacity by the second, and <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/resource-billing-stopped-instances.htm" title="When you stop an Oracle Cloud Infrastructure Compute instance, billing for the stopped instance depends on the shape that you used to create the instance." uk-tooltip="">depending on the shape</a>, you pay only for the seconds that your instances are running. Capacity availability is not guaranteed when launching large workloads.</li>
<li><strong>Preemptible capacity:</strong> Preemptible capacity allows you to save money by using preemptible instances to run workloads that only need to run for brief periods or that can be interrupted when the capacity is reclaimed. Preemptible instances behave the same as regular compute instances, but the capacity is reclaimed when it's needed elsewhere, and the instances are terminated. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="../Concepts/preemptible.htm">Preemptible Instances</a>.</li>
<li><strong>Reserved capacity:</strong>
Reserve capacity for future usage, and ensure that capacity is available to create Compute instances whenever you need them. The reserved capacity is used when you launch instances against the reservation. When these instances are terminated, the capacity is returned to the reservation, and the unused capacity in the reservation increases. Unused reserved capacity is metered differently than used reserved capacity. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/reserve-capacity.htm" title="Capacity reservations allow you to reserve instances in advance so that the capacity is available for your workloads when you need it." uk-tooltip="">Capacity Reservations</a>.</li>
<li><strong>Dedicated capacity:</strong> Run VM instances on dedicated servers that are a single tenant and not shared with other customers. This feature lets you meet compliance and regulatory requirements for isolation that prevent you from using shared infrastructure. You can also use this feature to meet node-based or host-based licensing requirements that require you to license an entire server. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="../Concepts/dedicatedvmhosts.htm">Dedicated Virtual Machine Hosts</a>.</li>
</ul>
<p>Service limits and compartment quotas apply to all types of host capacity. For reserved capacity, if your request for reserved capacity will exceed your service limits, request a service limit increase before you reserve the capacity. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/General/Concepts/servicelimits.htm">Service Limits</a>.</p>
</div>
</div>
</article>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title5" class="topic nested1" id="components-for-launching-instances">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title5">Components for Launching Instances</h2>
<div class="body">
<p class="keepWithNext">The components required to launch an instance are:</p>
<dl>
<dt class="dt dlterm">availability domain
</dt>
<dd class="dd">The Oracle Cloud Infrastructure data center within your geographical region that hosts cloud resources, including your instances. You can place instances in the same or different availability domains, depending on your performance and redundancy requirements. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/General/Concepts/regions.htm">Regions and Availability Domains</a>.</dd>
<dt class="dt dlterm">virtual cloud network</dt>
<dd class="dd">A virtual version of a traditional network—including subnets, route tables, and gateways—on which your instance runs. At least one cloud network has to be set up before you launch instances. For information about setting up cloud networks, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Network/Concepts/overview.htm">Networking Overview</a>.</dd>
<dt class="dt dlterm">key pair (for Linux instances)</dt>
<dd class="dd">A security mechanism required for Secure Shell (SSH) access to an instance. Before you launch an instance, you'll need at least one key pair. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/managingkeypairs.htm">Managing Key Pairs on Linux Instances</a>.</dd>
<dt class="dt dlterm">password (for Windows instances)</dt>
<dd class="dd">A security mechanism required to access an instance that uses a Windows platform image. The first time you launch an instance using a Windows image, Oracle Cloud Infrastructure will generate an initial, one-time password that you can retrieve using the console or API. This password must be changed after you initially log on.</dd>
<dt class="dt dlterm">image</dt>
<dd class="dd">
<p>A template of a virtual hard drive that determines the operating system and other software for an instance. You can launch instances from these sources:</p>
<ul>
<li>Oracle Cloud Infrastructure
<a class="xref" href="../References/images.htm">platform images</a>.</li>
<li>Trusted third-party images published by Oracle partners from the Partner Image catalog. For more information about partner images, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Marketplace/overview-marketplace.htm">Overview of Marketplace</a> and <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Marketplace/Tasks/workingwithlistings.htm">Working with Listings</a>.</li>
<li>Pre-built Oracle enterprise images and solutions enabled for Oracle Cloud Infrastructure.</li>
<li><a class="xref" href="../Tasks/managingcustomimages.htm" title="You can create a custom image of an instance's boot disk and use it to launch other instances. Instances you launch from your image include the customizations, configuration, and software installed when you created the image." uk-tooltip="">Custom images</a>, including <a class="xref" href="../References/bringyourownimage.htm">bring your own image scenarios</a>.</li>
<li><a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Marketplace/Tasks/publishingcommunityapplications.htm">Community images</a>, created and published by community members for use by other community members.</li>
<li><a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Block/Concepts/bootvolumes.htm">Boot volumes</a>.</li>
</ul>
</dd>
<dt class="dt dlterm" id="components-for-launching-instances__Shape">shape</dt>
<dd class="dd">A template that determines the number of CPUs, amount of memory, and other resources allocated to a newly created instance. You choose the most appropriate shape when you launch an instance. See <a class="xref" href="../References/computeshapes.htm">Compute Shapes</a> for a list of available bare metal and VM shapes.</dd>
<dt class="dt dlterm">tags</dt>
<dd class="dd">
<p>Apply tags to resources to help organize them according to your business needs. You can apply tags when you create a resource, and you can update a resource later to add, revise, or remove tags. For general information about applying tags, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/General/Concepts/resourcetags.htm">Resource Tags</a>.</p>
</dd>
</dl>
<div class="p">You can optionally attach volumes to an instance. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Block/Concepts/overview.htm">Overview of Block Volume</a>.<div class="uk-alert uk-alert-primary"><span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="file-edit"></span><strong> Note</strong><br/><br/> Resources that are created and used by compute instances, such as boot volumes and network traffic, are billed separately from the compute instance.</div></div>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title6" class="topic nested1" id="events">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title6">Creating Automation with Events</h2>
<div class="body">
<p>You can create automation based on state changes for Oracle Cloud Infrastructure resources by using event types, rules, and actions. <span id="events__ph_pointertoevents">For more information, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Events/Concepts/eventsoverview.htm">Overview of Events</a>.</span></p>
<p class="keepWithNext">The following Compute resources emit events:</p>
<ul>
<li>Autoscaling configurations and autoscaling policies</li>
<li>Cluster networks</li>
<li>Console histories</li>
<li>Images</li>
<li>Instances and instance attachments</li>
<li>Instance configurations</li>
<li>Instance console connections</li>
<li>Instance pools</li>
</ul>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title7" class="topic nested1" id="resource-identifiers">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title7">Resource Identifiers</h2>
<div class="body">
<p>Most types of Oracle Cloud Infrastructure resources have a unique, Oracle-assigned identifier called an Oracle Cloud ID (OCID). For information about the OCID format and other ways to identify your resources, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/General/Concepts/identifiers.htm">Resource Identifiers</a>.</p>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title8" class="topic nested1" id="workrequests">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title8">Work Requests</h2>
<div class="body">
<p>Compute is one of the Oracle Cloud Infrastructure services that is integrated with the Work Requests API. For general information on using work requests in Oracle Cloud Infrastructure, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/General/Concepts/workrequestoverview.htm">Work Requests</a> in the user guide, and the <a class="xref" href="/iaas/api/#/en/workrequests/latest/">Work Requests API</a>.</p>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title9" class="topic nested1" id="ways-to-access-oci">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title9">Ways to Access Oracle Cloud Infrastructure</h2>
<div class="body">
<div>
<p id="ways-to-access-oci__p_waystoaccess">You can access Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI) by using the <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/GSG/Tasks/signingin_topic-Signing_In_for_the_First_Time.htm">Console</a> (a browser-based interface), <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/API/Concepts/usingapi.htm">REST API</a>, or <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/API/Concepts/cliconcepts.htm">OCI CLI</a>.<span id="ways-to-access-oci__ph_instructions"> Instructions for using the Console, API, and CLI are included in topics throughout this documentation.</span>
<span id="ways-to-access-oci__ph_sdks">For a list of available SDKs, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/API/Concepts/sdks.htm">Software Development Kits and Command Line Interface</a>.</span></p>
<p id="ways-to-access-oci__p_console-access"><span id="ways-to-access-oci__ph_console-access">To access <span id="ways-to-access-oci__ph_console-access-for-service">the <a class="xref" href="https://cloud.oracle.com/">Console</a>, you must use a <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/GSG/Tasks/signinginIdentityDomain.htm#supported-browsers">supported browser</a>. To go to the Console sign-in page, open the navigation menu at the top of this page and select <strong class="ph uicontrol">Infrastructure Console</strong>. You are prompted to enter your cloud tenant, your user name, and your password.</span></span></p>
</div>
<p>For general information about using the API, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/API/Concepts/usingapi.htm">REST API documentation</a>.</p>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title10" class="topic nested1" id="compute-over-auth">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title10">Authentication and Authorization</h2>
<div class="body">
<div>
<p>Each service in Oracle Cloud Infrastructure integrates with IAM for authentication and authorization, for all interfaces (the Console, SDK or CLI, and REST API).</p>
<p>An administrator in an organization needs to set up <strong title="A collection of users who all need a particular type of access to a set of resources or compartment." uk-tooltip="">groups <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong>, <strong title="A collection of related resources that can be accessed only by groups that have been given permission by an administrator in your organization. Compartments can have a hierarchical structure, allowing for the creation of parent compartments and child compartments (also referred to as subcompartments)." uk-tooltip="">compartments <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong>, and <strong title='An Identity and Access Management (IAM) document that specifies who has what type of access to your resources. Policy can refer to several types of documents: an individual statement written in the policy language, a collection of statements in a single named "policy" document, and the overall body of policies that your organization uses to control access to resources.' uk-tooltip="">policies <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong> that control which users can access which services, which resources, and the type of access. For example, the policies control who can create new users, create and manage the cloud network, create instances, create buckets, download objects, and so on. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Identity/domains/overview.htm">Managing Identity Domains</a>. For specific details about writing policies for each of the different services, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Identity/Reference/policyreference.htm">Policy Reference</a>. </p>
<p>If you're a regular user (not an administrator) who needs to use the Oracle Cloud Infrastructure resources that the company owns, contact an administrator to set up a user ID for you. The administrator can confirm which compartment or compartments you can use.</p>
</div>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title11" class="topic nested1" id="security">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title11">Security</h2>
<div class="body"><p class="shortdesc">In addition to creating IAM policies, follow these security best practices for Compute.</p>
<ul>
<li>Encrypt boot volumes with a custom key, and rotate keys</li>
<li>Apply the latest security patches to instances</li>
<li>Use Oracle Cloud Guard to detect and respond to security problems</li>
<li>Perform a security audit</li>
</ul>
<p>See <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Security/Reference/compute_security.htm">Securing Compute</a>.</p>
<div class="uk-alert uk-alert-warning"><span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="lifesaver"></span><strong> Tip</strong><br/><br/> You can manage network access to OCI
<strong title="The cloud objects that you create and use when interacting with Oracle Cloud Infrastructure." uk-tooltip="">resources <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong> by creating policies that control communication between them, using security attributes that you add to the resources. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/zero-trust-packet-routing/home.htm">Zero Trust Packet Routing</a>.</div>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title12" class="topic nested1" id="storage">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title12">Storage for Compute Instances</h2>
<div class="body">
<p>You can expand the storage that's available for your compute instances with the following services:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<strong>
Block Volume:</strong> Lets you dynamically provision and manage block volumes that you can attach to one or more compute instances. See <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Block/Concepts/overview.htm">Overview of Block Volume</a> for more information. For steps to attach block volumes to compute instances, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Block/Tasks/attachingavolume.htm">Attaching a Block Volume to an Instance</a> and <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Block/Tasks/attach-to-multiple-instances-compute-volume-attachment.htm">Attaching a Volume to Multiple Instances</a>. </li>
<li>
<strong>File Storage:</strong> A durable, scalable, secure, enterprise-grade network file system that you can connect to from any compute instance in your virtual cloud network (VCN). See <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/File/Concepts/filestorageoverview.htm">Overview of File Storage</a> for more information. </li>
<li>
<strong>
Object Storage:</strong> An internet-scale, high-performance storage platform that lets you store an unlimited amount of unstructured data of any content type. This storage is regional and not tied to any specific compute instance. See <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Object/Concepts/objectstorageoverview.htm">Overview of Object Storage</a> for more information. </li>
<li>
<strong>
Archive Storage:</strong> A storage platform that lets you store an unlimited amount of unstructured data of any content type that doesn't require instantaneous data retrieval. This storage is regional and not tied to any specific compute instance. See <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Archive/Concepts/archivestorageoverview.htm">Overview of Archive Storage</a> for more information. </li>
</ul>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title13" class="topic nested1" id="Limits">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title13">Limits on Compute Resources</h2>
<div class="body">
<p>For a list of applicable limits and <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/General/Concepts/servicelimits-request-increase.htm">instructions for requesting a limit increase</a>, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/General/Concepts/servicelimits.htm">Limits by Service</a>. To set compartment-specific limits on a resource or resource family, administrators can use <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Quotas/Concepts/resourcequotas.htm">compartment quotas</a>.</p>
<p class="keepWithNext">Additional limits include:</p>
<ul>
<li>To attach a volume to an instance, both the instance and volume must be within the same availability domain.</li>
<li>Many Compute operations are subject to <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/API/Concepts/usingapi.htm#throttle">throttling</a>.</li>
</ul>
<p>A service limit is different from host capacity. A service limit is the quota or allowance set on a resource. Host capacity is the physical infrastructure that resources such as compute instances run on. If you get an "Out of host capacity" error when you try to create an instance or change the shape of an instance, <a class="xref" href="../known-issues.htm#out-of-host-capacity-error-when-creating-compute-instances">try the suggested workarounds</a>.</p>
</div>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title14" class="topic nested2" id="metadata-key-limits">
<h3 class="title topictitle3 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title14">Metadata Key Limits</h3>
<div class="body">
<p>Custom metadata keys (any key you define that is not <code class="ph codeph">ssh_authorized_keys</code> or <code class="ph codeph">user_data</code>) have the following limits:</p>
<ul>
<li>Max number of metadata keys: 128</li>
<li>Max size of key name: 255 characters</li>
<li>Max size of key value: 255 characters</li>
</ul>
<p><code class="ph codeph">ssh_authorized_keys</code> is a special key that does not have these limits, but its value is validated to conform to a public key in the OpenSSH format.</p>
<p><code class="ph codeph">user_data</code> has a maximum size of 16KB. For Linux instances with cloud-init configured, you can populate the <code class="ph codeph">user_data</code> field with a Base64-encoded string of cloud-init user data. For more information on formats that cloud-init accepts, see <a aria-label="cloud-init formats. Opens in a new window" class="xref" href="http://cloudinit.readthedocs.io/en/latest/topics/format.html" rel="noopener" target="_blank">cloud-init formats</a>. </p>
</div>
</article>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title15" class="topic nested1" id="disaster-recovery">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title15">Disaster Recovery</h2>
<div class="body">
<p>Disaster recovery for OCI
Compute instances is accomplished using OCI Full Stack Disaster Recovery service. Full Stack Disaster Recovery is a robust OCI cloud native service that is tightly integrated with many OCI services including OCI
Compute. Full Stack DR can orchestrate recovery for virtual machines alone but is intended to handle recovery for entire application stacks that include much more than OCI
Compute. </p>
</div>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title16" class="topic nested2" id="disaster-recovery-overview">
<h3 class="title topictitle3" id="ariaid-title16">Overview</h3>
<div class="body">
<div>
<p>OCI Full Stack Disaster Recovery service provides a simple, low code means of creating and maintaining robust disaster recovery plans (DR Plans) that orchestrate recovery for entire application stacks. DR plans can be customized to include user-defined steps to stop and restart other OCI platform services and applications as part of a fully automated recovery plan. The disaster recovery service includes OCI native support for the following OCI resource types and assumes the supported resources are already provisioned for disaster recovery across OCI regions or availability domains.</p>
<ul>
<li>OCI
Compute virtual machines</li>
<li>Load balancers and network load balancers</li>
<li>Oracle databases <ul>
<li>Autonomous AI Database</li>
<li>Base Database</li>
<li>Exadata Database</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>Oracle Kubernetes Engine</li>
<li>Storage <ul>
<li>Block volume groups</li>
<li>File systems</li>
<li>Object storage buckets</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title17" class="topic nested2" id="disaster-recovery-configure">
<h3 class="title topictitle3" id="ariaid-title17">How to configure DR for OCI Compute instances</h3>
<div class="body">
<div>
<p>There are two approaches for adding one or more virtual machines to disaster recovery using Full Stack DR.</p>
<p><strong class="ph uicontrol">QuickDR</strong></p>
<p>Configure disaster recovery for individual OCI
Compute virtual machines from the instance details page of any Compute instance. QuickDR provides a fast and efficient method for provisioning DR for your virtual machines. QuickDR is can either create a new, dedicated, Full Stack DR configuration for your Compute instance, or you can add your Compute instance to an existing configuration. Use this approach if you have a basic knowledge of disaster recovery but little, to no experience with OCI networking, OCI storage or the full featured Full Stack Disaster Recovery service. <a class="xref" href="/iaas/disaster-recovery/doc/quickdr.html">Learn more about QuickDR</a>.</p>
<p><strong class="ph uicontrol">Full Service</strong></p>
<p>Configure disaster recovery for individual OCI
Compute virtual machines plus many other OCI resources using the Full Stack DR full featured service. Use this approach if you are experienced with disaster recovery, have a fundamental understanding of OCI Full Stack DR and need to create fully automated recovery for an entire application stack including virtual machines, storage, databases, load balancers, Oracle, or nonOracle applications and other OCI services. <a class="xref" href="/iaas/disaster-recovery/doc/overview-disaster-recovery.html">Learn more about Full Stack Disaster Recovery</a>.</p>
</div>
</div>
</article>
</article>
</article>
</article>

<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title1" class="topic nested0" id="Compute_Shapes">
<h1 class="title topictitle1" id="ariaid-title1">Compute Shapes</h1>
<div class="body">
<p>A shape is a template that determines the number of <strong title="An OCPU represents physical CPU cores. For Intel and AMD processors, the CPU capacity equivalent of one physical core with simultaneous multithreading (hyper-threading) enabled, where each OCPU corresponds to two hardware execution threads (also known as virtual CPUs or vCPUs). For Arm A1 (Compute), one OCPU corresponds to a single physical core. For Arm A2 (Compute), one OCPU corresponds to two physical cores." uk-tooltip="">OCPUs <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong>, amount of memory, and other resources that are allocated to an instance. Compute shapes are available with AMD processors, Intel processors, and Arm-based processors.</p>
<p>This topic provides basic information about the shapes that are available for bare metal instances, virtual machines (VMs), and dedicated virtual machine hosts. For information about service limits, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/General/Concepts/servicelimits.htm#computelimits">Compute Limits</a>. For information about protecting data on NVMe devices, see <a class="xref" href="nvmedeviceinformation.htm">Protecting Data on NVMe Devices</a>.</p>
<div class="uk-alert uk-alert-primary"><span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="file-edit"></span><strong> Note</strong><br/><br/>
<ul>
<li>
<p>When a new region becomes available, it might take a few weeks before host capacity also becomes available.</p>
<p>To obtain a list of shapes available to you, run the <a class="xref" href="/iaas/api/#/en/iaas/latest/Shape/ListShapes">ListShapes</a> operation.</p>
</li>
<li>If your instance uses <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Network/Concepts/securityrules.htm#stateful">stateful security rules</a>, each instance has a <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/General/Concepts/servicelimits.htm#connection-tracking">maximum number of concurrent connections</a> that can be tracked, based on the instance's shape.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<section class="section" id="Compute_Shapes__pricing"><h2 class="title sectiontitle vl-include-in-page-toc">Compute Shape Pricing</h2>
<p>You can use the <a class="xref" href="https://www.oracle.com/cloud/cost-estimator.html">Cost Estimator</a> to estimate your expected monthly project costs with Oracle Cloud Infrastructure. For detailed information about billing, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Billing/home.htm">Billing and Cost Management</a> and the Oracle Compute Cloud Services section of <a class="xref" href="https://www.oracle.com/assets/paas-iaas-universal-credits-3940775.pdf">Oracle PaaS and IaaS Universal Credits Service Descriptions</a>.</p>
<dl>
<dt class="dt dlterm">OCPUs and vCPUs</dt>
<dd class="dd">
<p>Oracle measures compute resource pricing differently. The Oracle CPU (OCPU) represents physical CPU cores and is the unit of measurement for CPUs on x86 CPUs (AMD and Intel) and Arm CPUs (OCI Ampere Compute). A virtual CPU (vCPU), the industry-standard for measuring compute resources, represents one execution thread of a physical CPU core.</p>
<p>Most CPU architectures, including x86, runs two threads per physical core, so one OCPU is the equal of two vCPUs for x86-based compute. For OCI
Compute, the minimum unit of provisioning starts from one OCPU on both X86 (Intel and AMD) and OCI Ampere Compute processors. </p>
<div class="p">The following are the provisioning units for compute instances:<ul>
<li>1 OCPU on Arm A1 (Compute) = 1 core on Arm A1 (Compute) or 1 vCPU</li>
<li>1 OCPU on Arm A2 (Compute) and A4 (Compute) = 2 cores on Arm A2 (Compute) and A4 (Compute) or 2 vCPUs</li>
<li>1 OCPU on x86 (AMD and Intel) = 2 vCPUs</li>
</ul>
</div>
<p>For more information, see <a href="https://www.oracle.com/cloud/price-list.html#compute-vm">Cloud Price List</a>. In addition, you can  read this blog post on <a class="xref" href="https://blogs.oracle.com/cloud-infrastructure/post/vcpu-and-ocpu-pricing-information">vCPU and OCPU pricing information</a>.</p>
</dd>
</dl>
</section>
</div>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title2" class="topic nested1" id="flexible">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title2">Flexible Shapes</h2>
<div class="body">
<p>A flexible shape is a shape that lets you customize the number of OCPUs and the amount of memory when launching or resizing your VM. When you <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/launchinginstance.htm" title="Create a bare metal or virtual machine (VM) compute instance." uk-tooltip="">create a VM instance</a> using a flexible shape, you select the number of OCPUs and the amount of memory that you need for the workloads that run on the instance. The network bandwidth and number of VNICs scale proportionately with the number of OCPUs. This flexibility lets you build VMs that match your workload, enabling you to optimize performance and minimize cost.
</p>
<p>The flexible shapes are:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<span translate="no">VM.Standard3.Flex (Intel)</span>
</li>
<li>
<span translate="no">VM.Standard.E4.Flex (AMD)</span>
</li>
<li>
<span translate="no">VM.Standard.E5.Flex (AMD)</span>
</li>
<li>
<span translate="no">VM.Standard.E6.Flex (AMD)</span>
</li>
<li>
<span translate="no">VM.Standard.A1.Flex (Altra processor from Ampere)</span>
</li>
<li>
<span translate="no">VM.Standard.A2.Flex (AmpereOne processor from Ampere)</span>
</li>
<li>
<span translate="no">VM.Standard.A4.Flex (AmpereOne-M processor from Ampere)</span>
</li>
<li>
<span translate="no">VM.DenseIO.E4.Flex (AMD)</span>
</li>
<li>
<span translate="no">VM.Optimized3.Flex (Intel)</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Flexible memory is also available on flexible shapes. The amount of memory allowed is based on the number of OCPUs selected.</p>
<p>For <a class="xref" href="computeshapes.htm#vm-standard">standard</a> and <a class="xref" href="computeshapes.htm#vm-hpc-optimized">optimized</a> flexible shapes, the ratio of memory to OCPUs depends on the shape.</p>
<div class="uk-overflow-auto"><table class="table vl-table-bordered" summary="Table showing the OCPU-to-memory ratios for the flexible shapes."><caption></caption><colgroup><col/><col/><col/><col/></colgroup><thead class="thead">

<p>See <a class="xref" href="extended-memory-vm-instances.htm" title="Extended memory virtual machine (VM) instances are VM instances that provide more memory and cores than available with standard shapes." uk-tooltip="">Extended Memory VM Instances</a>.</p>
</td>
<td class="entry" headers="flexible__entry__3">
<span class="notranslate">1 GB</span> or a value matching the number of OCPUs, whichever is greater</td>
<td class="entry" headers="flexible__entry__4">64 GB per OCPU, up to <span class="notranslate">512 GB</span> total<p>See <a class="xref" href="extended-memory-vm-instances.htm" title="Extended memory virtual machine (VM) instances are VM instances that provide more memory and cores than available with standard shapes." uk-tooltip="">Extended Memory VM Instances</a>.</p>
</td>
</tr>

<td class="entry" headers="flexible__entry__2">
<span translate="no">64</span>
<p>See <a class="xref" href="extended-memory-vm-instances.htm" title="Extended memory virtual machine (VM) instances are VM instances that provide more memory and cores than available with standard shapes." uk-tooltip="">Extended Memory VM Instances</a>.</p>
</td>
<td class="entry" headers="flexible__entry__3">
<span translate="no">1 GB</span> or a value matching the number of OCPUs, whichever is greater</td>
<td class="entry" headers="flexible__entry__4">64 GB per OCPU, up to <span translate="no">1024 GB</span> total<p>See <a class="xref" href="extended-memory-vm-instances.htm" title="Extended memory virtual machine (VM) instances are VM instances that provide more memory and cores than available with standard shapes." uk-tooltip="">Extended Memory VM Instances</a>.</p>
</td>
</tr>

</td>

<span translate="no">1 GB</span> or a value matching the number of OCPUs, whichever is greater</td>

</tr>
<tr class="row">

<td class="entry" headers="flexible__entry__2">
<p>126</p>
</td>
<td class="entry" headers="flexible__entry__3">
<span translate="no">1 GB</span> or a value matching the number of OCPUs, whichever is greater</td>
<td class="entry" headers="flexible__entry__4">64 GB per OCPU, up to 1454 GB total</td>
</tr>
<tr class="row">

<span translate="no">76</span>
<p>(OCPU is 1 core of an Altra processor)</p>
</td>
<td class="entry" headers="flexible__entry__3">
<span translate="no">1 GB</span> or a value matching the number of OCPUs, whichever is greater</td>
<td class="entry" headers="flexible__entry__4">64 GB per OCPU, up to <span translate="no">472 GB</span> total</td>
</tr>
<tr class="row">

<p>(OCPU is 2 cores of an AmpereOne processor)</p>
</td>
<td class="entry" headers="flexible__entry__3"><span translate="no">1 GB</span> or a value matching the number of OCPUs, whichever is greater</td>
<td class="entry" headers="flexible__entry__4"><span translate="no">64 GB per OCPU</span>, up to <span translate="no">946 GB</span> total</td>
</tr>

45
<p>(OCPU is 2 cores of an AmpereOne-M processor)</p>
</td>

</tr>

<span translate="no">18</span>
</td>

<span translate="no">1 GB</span> or a value matching the number of OCPUs, whichever is greater</td>

</tbody></table></div>
<p>For <a class="xref" href="computeshapes.htm#vm-dense">dense I/O</a> flexible shapes, the following configurations are available:</p>
<ul>
<li>
8 OCPUs, <span translate="no">128</span> GB memory</li>
<li>
<span translate="no">16</span> OCPUs, <span translate="no">256</span> GB memory</li>
<li>
<span translate="no">32</span> OCPUs, <span translate="no">512</span> GB memory</li>
</ul>
<p>These resources are billed at a per-second granularity with a one-minute minimum.
            Optimize your costs by choosing the shape that matches your workload and by changing the
            shape when your workload changes. For example, you can configure the VM to maximize
            compute processing power by choosing a low core-to-memory ratio. Or, for applications
            like in-memory databases or big data processing engines, configure an instance with a
            high core-to-memory ratio. Modify the OCPUs and memory as your workload changes, scaling
            up to increase performance or scaling down to reduce costs.</p>
</div>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title3" class="topic nested2" id="images">
<h3 class="title topictitle3 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title3">Supported Images</h3>
<div class="body">
<p>Most <a class="xref" href="images.htm">platform images</a> are compatible with flexible shapes. Use a platform image that was published after the flexible shape was released (for release dates, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/releasenotes/services/compute/">the Compute release notes</a>).</p>
<p>Custom images are also supported, depending on the image. You must <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/managingcustomimages.htm#Managing_Custom_Images__console-custom-image-tasks">add flexible shape compatibility to the custom image</a>, and then test the image on the flexible shape to ensure that it actually works on the shape.</p>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title4" class="topic nested2" id="regions">
<h3 class="title topictitle3 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title4">Supported Regions</h3>
<div class="body">
<p>For a list of supported regions, see the <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/General/Concepts/servicelimits.htm#Compute_Instances">compute instance service limits</a>. As host capacity becomes available in additional regions, the list is updated.</p>
<div class="uk-alert uk-alert-primary"><span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="file-edit"></span><strong> Note</strong><br/><br/> Capacity might be limited for A1 shapes.</div>
</div>
</article>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title5" class="topic nested1" id="computeshapes_topic-extended-memory">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title5">Extended Memory VM Instances</h2>
<div class="body">
<p>
<a class="xref" href="extended-memory-vm-instances.htm" title="Extended memory virtual machine (VM) instances are VM instances that provide more memory and cores than available with standard shapes." uk-tooltip="">Extended memory virtual machine (VM) instances</a> are VM instances that provide more memory and cores than available with standard shapes.</p>
<div class="p">The following shapes are available for extended memory VM instances:<ul>
<li>
<p>
<span translate="no">VM.Standard3.Flex</span>
</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>
<span translate="no">VM.Standard.E3.Flex</span>
</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>
<span translate="no">VM.Standard.E4.Flex</span>
</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>
<span translate="no">VM.Standard.E5.Flex</span>
</p>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title6" class="topic nested1" id="baremetalshapes">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title6">Bare Metal Shapes</h2>
<div class="body">
<p class="keepWithNext">The following shapes are available for bare metal instances:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a class="xref" href="computeshapes.htm#bm-standard">Standard Shapes</a>
</li>
<li>
<a class="xref" href="computeshapes.htm#bm-dense">Dense I/O Shapes</a>
</li>
<li>
<a class="xref" href="computeshapes.htm#bm-gpu">GPU Shapes</a>
</li>
<li>
<a class="xref" href="computeshapes.htm#bm-hpc-optimized">HPC and Optimized Shapes</a>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Network bandwidth is based on expected bandwidth for traffic within a VCN. To determine which <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Network/Tasks/managingVNICs.htm#overview__How">physical NICs are active for a shape</a>, refer to the network bandwidth specifications in the following tables. If the network bandwidth is listed as "2 x <var class="keyword varname">&lt;bandwidth&gt;</var> Gbps," it means that both NIC 0 and NIC 1 are active.</p>
<p>
For bare metal instances, optionally <a class="xref" href="../References/bios-settings.htm" title="When you create a bare metal compute instance, you can optionally configure advanced BIOS settings that let you optimize performance. For example, you can disable simultaneous multithreading to optimize the NUMA settings." uk-tooltip="">configure advanced BIOS settings</a>, such as disabling simultaneous multithreading, disabling cores, or optimizing the NUMA settings.
</p>
</div>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title7" class="topic nested2" id="bm-standard">
<h3 class="title topictitle3 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title7">Standard Shapes</h3>
<div class="body">
<p>
Designed for general purpose workloads and suitable for a wide range of applications and use cases. Standard shapes provide a balance of cores, memory, and network resources. Standard shapes are available with Intel, AMD, and Arm-based processors.
</p>
<p class="keepWithNext">These are the bare metal standard series:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<strong>BM.Standard3:</strong> X9-based standard compute. Processor: Intel Xeon Platinum 8358. Base frequency 2.6 GHz, max turbo frequency 3.4 GHz.</li>
<li>
<strong>BM.Standard.E4:</strong> E4-based standard compute. Processor: AMD EPYC 7J13. Base frequency 2.55 GHz, max boost frequency 3.5 GHz.</li>
<li>
<strong>BM.Standard.E5:</strong> E5-based standard compute. Processor: AMD EPYC 9J14. Base frequency 2.4 GHz, max boost frequency 3.7 GHz.</li>
<li>
<strong>BM.Standard.E6:</strong> E6-based standard compute. Processor: AMD EPYC 9J45. Base frequency 2.7 GHz, max boost frequency 4.1 GHz.</li>
<li>
<strong>BM.Standard.A1:</strong>
OCI Ampere A1 Compute Arm-based standard compute. Each OCPU corresponds to a single hardware execution thread. Processor: Ampere Altra Q80-30. Max frequency 3.0 GHz.</li>
<li>
<strong>BM.Standard.A4:</strong> OCI Ampere A4 Compute Arm-based standard compute. Each OCPU corresponds to two hardware execution threads (2 cores). Processor: Ampere AmpereOne-M A06-36M. Frequency 3.6 GHz.</li>
</ul>

<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title8" class="topic nested3" id="c-states-frequency-scaling">
<h4 class="title topictitle4" id="ariaid-title8">
<strong>C-States and Frequency Scaling</strong>
</h4>
<div class="body">
<p>Modern CPUs transition to a power-saving state (called c-states) when the CPU is idle or underutilized. These c-states start at C0, which is the normal CPU operating mode (the CPU is 100% activated). The higher the c-state, the deeper the sleep mode into which the CPU transitions. The sleep modes work by cutting the clock signal and power from idle units inside the CPU, thereby reducing the energy use. As the CPU transitions to higher c-states (deeper sleep states), the longer it takes to wake up the units that are shut down. This is an undesirable side effect of c-states transitions, because it can slow down a demanding application.</p>
<p>Fortunately, the hypervisor on standard VM shapes manages this complexity for the end user by preventing transitions to deeper sleep states even when the CPU is underutilized. In addition, it disables c-states when it sees sustained high utilization. When c-states are disabled, the CPU operates in C0 state, where all cores are active at base frequency. Each processor manufacturer names the maximum frequency per core differently; for Intel the maximum frequency is named max turbo frequency, and for AMD it is called max boost frequency. This maximum frequency is realized by the respective CPU's built-in algorithms when the processor is running in C0 state under normal but sustained load.</p>
<p>Currently, the hypervisor does not allow the client operating system running in the instance to manage the c-states using kernel command line options. The client always shows the base frequency, even when the hypervisor is running the processor at the maximum frequency advertised by the processor.</p>
</div>
</article>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title9" class="topic nested2" id="bm-dense">
<h3 class="title topictitle3 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title9">Dense I/O Shapes</h3>
<div class="body">
<p class="keepWithNext">
Designed for large databases, big data workloads, and applications that require high-performance local storage. DenseIO shapes include locally-attached NVMe-based SSDs.
</p>
<p class="keepWithNext">This is the bare metal dense I/O series:</p>

<li>
<strong>BM.DenseIO.E4:</strong> E4-based dense I/O compute. Processor: AMD EPYC 7J13. Base frequency 2.55 GHz, max boost frequency 3.5 GHz.</li>
<li>
<strong>BM.DenseIO.E5:</strong> E5-based dense I/O compute. Processor: AMD EPYC 9J14. Base frequency 2.6 GHz, max boost frequency 3.7 GHz.</li>
</ul>

<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title11" class="topic nested2" id="bm-hpc-optimized">
<h3 class="title topictitle3 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title11">HPC and Optimized Shapes</h3>
<div class="body">
<p>
Designed for high-performance computing workloads that require high frequency processor cores. Bare metal HPC and optimized shapes support cluster networking.
</p>
<p class="keepWithNext">This is the bare metal optimized series:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<strong>BM.Optimized3:</strong> Processor: Intel Xeon 6354. Base frequency 3.0 GHz, max turbo frequency 3.6 GHz.</li>
<li>
<strong>BM.HPC.E5:</strong> Processor: AMD EPYC 9J14. Base frequency 2.4 GHz, max boost frequency 3.7 GHz.</li>
</ul>

<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title12" class="topic nested1" id="vmshapes">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title12">Virtual Machine (VM) Shapes</h2>
<div class="body">
<p class="keepWithNext">The following shapes are available for VMs:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a class="xref" href="computeshapes.htm#vm-standard">Standard Shapes</a>
</li>
<li>
<a class="xref" href="computeshapes.htm#vm-dense">Dense I/O Shapes</a>
</li>
<li>
<a class="xref" href="computeshapes.htm#vm-gpu">GPU Shapes</a>
</li>
<li>
<a class="xref" href="computeshapes.htm#vm-hpc-optimized">HPC and Optimized Shapes</a>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Network bandwidth is based on expected bandwidth for traffic within a VCN.</p>
</div>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title13" class="topic nested2" id="vm-standard">
<h3 class="title topictitle3 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title13">Standard Shapes</h3>
<div class="body">
<p>
Designed for general purpose workloads and suitable for a wide range of applications and use cases. Standard shapes provide a balance of cores, memory, and network resources. Standard shapes are available with Intel, AMD, and Arm-based processors.
</p>
<p class="keepWithNext">These are the VM standard series:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<strong>VM.Standard3:</strong> X9-based standard compute. Processor: Intel Xeon Platinum 8358. Base frequency 2.6 GHz, max turbo frequency 3.4 GHz.</li>
<li>
<p>
<strong>VM.Standard.E2.1.Micro:</strong> E2-based, E3-based, or E4-based standard compute. Oracle Cloud Infrastructure assigns one of the following processors:</p>
<ul>
<li>AMD EPYC 7551. Base frequency 2.0 GHz, max boost frequency 3.0 GHz.</li>
<li>AMD EPYC 7742. Base frequency 2.25 GHz, max boost frequency 3.4 GHz.</li>
<li>AMD EPYC 7J13. Base frequency 2.55 GHz, max boost frequency 3.5 GHz.</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>
<strong>VM.Standard.E4:</strong> E4-based standard compute. Processor: AMD EPYC 7J13. Base frequency 2.55 GHz, max boost frequency 3.5 GHz.</li>
<li>
<strong>VM.Standard.E5:</strong> E5-based standard compute. Processor: AMD EPYC 9J14. Base frequency 2.4 GHz, max boost frequency 3.7 GHz.</li>
<li>
<strong>VM.Standard.E6:</strong> E6-based standard compute. Processor: AMD EPYC 9J45. Base frequency 2.7 GHz, max boost frequency 4.1 GHz.</li>
<li>
<strong>VM.Standard.A1:</strong>
OCI Ampere A1 Compute Arm-based standard compute. Each OCPU corresponds to a single hardware execution thread. Processor: Ampere Altra Q80-30. Max frequency 3.0 GHz.</li>
<li>
<strong>VM.Standard.A2:</strong>
OCI Ampere A2 Compute Arm-based standard compute. Each OCPU corresponds to two hardware execution threads (2 cores). Processor: Ampere AmpereOne A160-30. Max frequency 3.0 GHz.</li>
<li><strong>VM.Standard.A4:</strong> OCI Ampere A4 Compute Arm-based standard compute. Each OCPU corresponds to two hardware execution threads (2 cores). Processor: Ampere AmpereOne-M A06-36M. Frequency 3.6 GHz.</li>
</ul>

<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title14" class="topic nested2" id="vm-dense">
<h3 class="title topictitle3 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title14">Dense I/O Shapes</h3>
<div class="body">
<p class="keepWithNext">
Designed for large databases, big data workloads, and applications that require high-performance local storage. DenseIO shapes include locally-attached NVMe-based SSDs.
</p>
<p class="keepWithNext">This is the VM dense I/O series:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<strong>VM.DenseIO.E4:</strong> E4-based dense I/O compute. Processor: AMD EPYC 7J13. Base frequency 2.55 GHz, max boost frequency 3.5 GHz.</li>
<li>
<strong>VM.DenseIO.E5:</strong> E5-based dense I/O compute. Processor: AMD EPYC 9J14. Base frequency 2.6 GHz, max boost frequency 3.7 GHz.</li>
</ul>

<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title15" class="topic nested2" id="vm-gpu">
<h3 class="title topictitle3 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title15">GPU Shapes</h3>
<div class="body">
<p>
Designed for hardware-accelerated workloads. GPU shapes include Intel, AMD, or Arm CPUs with NVIDIA or AMD graphics processors.
</p>
<p class="keepWithNext">These are the VM GPU series:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>
<strong>VM.GPU2:</strong> X7-based GPU compute.</p>
<ul>
<li>GPU: NVIDIA Tesla P100 16 GB</li>
<li>CPU: Intel Xeon Platinum 8167M. Base frequency 2.0 GHz, max turbo frequency 2.4 GHz.</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>
<p>
<strong>VM.GPU3:</strong> X7-based GPU compute.</p>
<ul>
<li>GPU: NVIDIA Tesla V100 16 GB</li>
<li>CPU: Intel Xeon Platinum 8167M. Base frequency 2.0 GHz, max turbo frequency 2.4 GHz.</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>
<p>
<strong>VM.GPU.A10:</strong> X9-based GPU compute.</p>
<ul>
<li>GPU: NVIDIA A10 24 GB</li>
<li>CPU: Intel Xeon Platinum 8358. Base frequency 2.6 GHz, max turbo frequency 3.4 GHz.</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>

<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title18" class="topic nested1" id="previous-generation-shapes">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title18">Previous Generation Shapes</h2>
<div class="body">
<div class="uk-alert uk-alert-warning"><span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="lifesaver"></span><strong> Tip</strong><br/><br/> Previous generation shapes are still fully supported. However, because the underlying hardware has reached the sustaining phase of its lifecycle, capacity in certain high-demand regions might be limited.</div>
<p>
Oracle Cloud Infrastructure periodically releases new generations of Compute shapes. The latest shapes let you take advantage of newer hardware and a better price-performance ratio. When a shape is several years old, and newer generation shapes that are suited for the same purposes are available, the old shape transitions to become a previous generation shape.</p>
<p>Your current utilization is fully supported on the previous generation shape. In certain high demand regions, you may need to plan your utilization growth on a newer generation shape.</p>
<section class="section" id="previous-generation-shapes__upgrading-from-previous-generation"><h3 class="title sectiontitle vl-include-in-page-toc">Upgrading from a Previous Generation Shape</h3>
</section>
<p>To upgrade from a previous generation shape to a current generation shape, you can do the following things:</p>
<ul>
<li>For supported VM instances, <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/resizinginstances.htm">change the shape of the instance</a>.</li>
<li>For bare metal instances and VM instances that don't support changing the shape, <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/terminatinginstance.htm" title="You can permanently delete (terminate) instances that you no longer need. Any attached VNICs and volumes are automatically detached when the instance terminates. Eventually, the instance's public and private IP addresses are released and become available for other instances." uk-tooltip="">terminate the instance but DO NOT delete the boot volume</a>. Then, <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/launchinginstance.htm" title="Create a bare metal or virtual machine (VM) compute instance." uk-tooltip="">use the boot volume to create a new instance</a>.</li>
</ul>
<section class="section" id="previous-generation-shapes__previous-generation-bm"><h3 class="title sectiontitle vl-include-in-page-toc">Previous Generation Bare Metal Shapes</h3>
<p class="keepWithNext">These are the previous generation bare metal shape series.</p>

<h1 class="title topictitle1" id="ariaid-title1">Working with Boot Volumes</h1>
<div class="body"><p class="shortdesc">A boot volume is created when you create an instance.</p></div>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title2" class="topic nested1" id="tasks">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title2">Tasks</h2>
<div class="body">
<ul>
<li>
<a class="xref" href="../Tasks/list-bv-boot-volume.htm" title="Learn how list all boot volumes in a specific compartment, or detailed information for a single boot volume." uk-tooltip="">Listing Boot Volumes</a>

</li>

</li>

</li>

<ul>

</li>
<li>

</li>

</li>

</li>

<a class="xref" href="../Tasks/boot-volume-policy-assignments.htm" title="Work with backup policies assigned to boot volumes in Block Volume." uk-tooltip="">Managing Backup Policy Assignments for Boot Volumes</a>
</li>
</ul>
</li>

</li>

<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title3" class="topic nested1" id="about">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title3">About Boot Volumes</h2>
<div class="body">
<p>When you launch a virtual machine (VM) or bare metal instance based on a <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Compute/References/images.htm">platform image</a> or <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Compute/Tasks/managingcustomimages.htm">custom image</a>, a new boot volume for the instance is created in the same compartment. That boot volume is associated with that instance until you terminate the instance. When you <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Compute/Tasks/terminatinginstance.htm">terminate the instance</a>, you can preserve the boot volume and its data. This feature gives you more control and management options for your compute instance boot volumes, and enables:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<strong>Instance scaling:</strong> When you terminate your instance, you can keep the associated boot volume and use it to launch a new instance using a different instance type or shape. See <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Compute/Tasks/launchinginstance.htm">Creating an Instance</a> for steps to launch an instance based on a boot volume. This allows you to switch easily from a bare metal instance to a VM instance and vice versa, or scale up or down the number of cores for an instance. </li>
<li>
<strong>Troubleshooting and repair:</strong> If you think a boot volume issue is causing a compute instance problem, you can stop the instance and detach the boot volume. Then you can attach it to another instance as a data volume to troubleshoot it. After resolving the issue, you can then reattach it to the original instance or use it to launch a new instance.</li>
</ul>
<p>Boot volumes are encrypted by default, the same as other block storage volumes. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="overview.htm#BlockVolumeEncryption">Encryption</a>.</p>
<div class="uk-alert uk-alert-success"><span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="check"></span><strong> Important</strong><br/><br/>
In-transit encryption for boot and block volumes is only available for virtual machine (VM) instances launched from platform images, along with bare metal instances that use the following shapes: BM.Standard.E3.128, BM.Standard.E4.128, BM.DenseIO.E4.128. It is not supported on other bare metal instances. To confirm support for certain Linux-based custom images and for more information, <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/GSG/Tasks/contactingsupport.htm">contact Oracle support</a>.
</div>
<p>You can group boot volumes with block volumes into the same volume group, making it easy to create a group volume backup or a clone of your entire instance, including both the system disk and storage disks at the same time. See <a class="xref" href="volumegroups.htm" title="The Oracle Cloud Infrastructure Block Volume service provides you with the capability to group together many volumes in a volume group. A volume group can include both types of volumes, boot volumes, which are the system disks for your compute instances, and block volumes for your data storage. You can use volume groups to create volume group backups and clones that are point-in-time and crash-consistent." uk-tooltip="">Working with Volume Groups</a> for more information.</p>
<p id="about__move">You can move Block Volume resources such as boot volumes and boot volume backups between compartments. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/moveblockresourcecompartments.htm" title="Move resources to different compartments." uk-tooltip="">Moving Block Volume Resources Between Compartments</a>.</p>
<p>For more information about the Block Volume service and boot volumes, see the<a class="xref" href="https://www.oracle.com/cloud/storage/block-volumes/faq/"> Block Volume FAQ</a>.</p>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title4" class="topic nested1" id="Custom">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title4">Custom Boot Volume Sizes</h2>
<div class="body">
<p>When you launch an instance, you can use the selected image's default boot volume size or specify a custom size up to 32 TB. This capability is available for the following image source options:</p>
<ul>
<li>Platform image</li>
<li>Custom image</li>
<li>Image OCID</li>
</ul>
<p>See <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Compute/Tasks/launchinginstance.htm">Creating an Instance</a> for more information.</p>
<p>For Linux and Windows images, the custom boot volume size must be larger than the image's default boot volume size or 50 GB, whichever is higher.</p>
<div class="uk-alert uk-alert-primary"><span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="file-edit"></span><strong> Note</strong><br/><br/> For Windows Server 2012 R2 Datacenter images and Windows platform images published before October 2021, the custom boot volume size must be larger than the image's default boot volume size or 256 GB, whichever is higher.</div>
<p>If you specify a custom boot volume size, you need to extend the volume to take advantage of the larger size. For steps, see <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/extendingbootpartition.htm" title="When you create a new virtual machine (VM) instance or bare metal instance based on a platform image or custom image, you have the option of specifying a custom boot volume size." uk-tooltip="">Extending the Partition for a Boot Volume</a>.</p>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title5" class="topic nested1" id="perf">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title5">Boot Volume Performance</h2>
<div class="body">
<p>Boot volume performance varies with volume size, see <a class="xref" href="blockvolumeperformance.htm">Block Volume Performance</a> for more information. </p>
<p>The Block Volume service's elastic performance enables you to dynamically change the volume performance for boot volumes. Once an instance has been created, you can change the volume performance of the boot volume to one of the following performance levels:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Balanced </p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Higher Performance</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Ultra High Performance (See <a class="xref" href="blockvolumeultrahighperformance.htm#Higher_Performance__uhpboot">Boot Volumes and Ultra High Performance</a>.)</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>For how to change the performance for a boot volume, see <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/changingvolumeperformance.htm" title="The Block Volume service enables you to dynamically configure the performance level for block volumes and boot volumes." uk-tooltip="">Changing the Performance of a Volume</a>
</p>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title6" class="topic nested1" id="bootreplication">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title6">Cross-Region Boot Volume Replication</h2>
<div class="body">
<p>The Block Volume service provides you with the capability to perform ongoing automatic asynchronous replication of boot volumes to other regions. This feature supports disaster recovery, migration, and business expansion scenarios, without requiring boot volume backups. See <a class="xref" href="volumereplication.htm" title="The Block Volume service provides you with the capability to perform ongoing automatic asynchronous replication of block volumes, boot volumes, and volume groups to other regions and availability domains." uk-tooltip="">Block Volume Replication</a> for more information.</p>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title7" class="topic nested1" id="policy">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title7">Required IAM Service Policy</h2>
<div class="body">
<div>
<p>To use Oracle Cloud Infrastructure, an administrator must be a member of a group granted security access in a <strong title='An Identity and Access Management (IAM) document that specifies who has what type of access to your resources. Policy can refer to several types of documents: an individual statement written in the policy language, a collection of statements in a single named "policy" document, and the overall body of policies that your organization uses to control access to resources.' uk-tooltip="">policy <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong> by a tenancy administrator. This access is required whether you're using the Console or the REST API with an SDK, CLI, or other tool. If you get a message that you don't have permission or are unauthorized, verify with the tenancy administrator what type of access you have and which <strong title="A collection of related resources that can be accessed only by groups that have been given permission by an administrator in your organization. Compartments can have a hierarchical structure, allowing for the creation of parent compartments and child compartments (also referred to as subcompartments)." uk-tooltip="">compartment <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong> your access works in.</p>
</div>
<p>For administrators: The policy in <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Identity/Concepts/commonpolicies.htm#launch-instances">Let users launch compute instances</a> includes the ability to list boot volumes. The policy in <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Identity/Concepts/commonpolicies.htm#volume-admins-manage-volumes-and-backups">Let volume admins manage block volumes, backups, and volume groups</a> lets the specified group do everything with block volumes, boot volumes, and backups, but not launch instances. </p>
<div><span id="policy__ph_computepermissionsxrefs">If you're new to policies, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Identity/domains/overview.htm">Managing Identity Domains</a> and <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Identity/Concepts/commonpolicies.htm">Common Policies</a>. For reference material about writing policies for instances, cloud networks, or other Core Services API resources, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Identity/policyreference/corepolicyreference.htm">Details for the Core Services</a>.</span></div>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title8" class="topic nested1" id="applying-tags">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title8">Applying Tags</h2>
<div class="body">
<p>Apply tags to resources to help organize them according to your business needs. You can apply tags when you create a resource, and you can update a resource later to add, revise, or remove tags. For general information about applying tags, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/General/Concepts/resourcetags.htm">Resource Tags</a>.</p>
</div>
</article>
</article>
