<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title1" role="article">
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title1" class="topic nested0" id="network_landing">
<h1 class="title topictitle1" id="ariaid-title1">
Networking Overview</h1>
<div class="body">
<p>When you work with Oracle Cloud Infrastructure, one of the first steps is to set up a Virtual Cloud Network (VCN) for cloud resources. This topic gives you an overview of Oracle Cloud Infrastructure Networking components and typical scenarios for using a VCN.</p>
<div class="uk-alert uk-alert-warning"><span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="lifesaver"></span><strong> Tip</strong><br/><br/> Watch a <a class="xref" href="https://apexapps.oracle.com/pls/apex/f?p=44785:265:0:::265:P265_CONTENT_ID:32072">video introduction</a> to the service.</div>
</div>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title2" class="topic nested1" id="Componen">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title2">Networking Components</h2>
<div class="body">
<p>The Networking service uses virtual versions of traditional
            network components you might already be familiar with:</p>
<dl>
<dt class="dt dlterm">
Virtual Cloud Network (VCN)</dt>
<dd class="dd">
A virtual, private network that you set up in Oracle data centers. It closely resembles a traditional network, with firewall rules and specific types of communication gateways that you can decide to use. A VCN resides in a single Oracle Cloud Infrastructure region and covers one or more CIDR blocks (IPv4 and IPv6, if enabled). See <a class="xref" href="overview.htm#Allowed">Allowed VCN Size and Address Ranges</a>. The terms <em>virtual cloud network</em>, <em>VCN, and cloud network </em>are used interchangeably in this documentation. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/VCNs.htm" title="A Virtual Cloud Network (VCN) is a customizable and private network set up in Oracle Cloud Infrastructure." uk-tooltip="">VCNs and Subnets</a>.</dd>
<dt class="dt dlterm">SUBNETS</dt>
<dd class="dd">
<div>
<p> Subdivisions you define in a VCN (for example, 10.0.0.0/24, 10.0.1.0/24, or 2001:DB8::/64). <span id="Componen__ph_subnet-vnics">Subnets contain virtual network interface cards (VNICs), which attach to Compute instances.</span> Each subnet consists of a contiguous range of IP addresses (for IPv4 and IPv6, if enabled) that don't overlap with other subnets in the VCN. You can set a subnet to exist either in a single <strong title="One or more isolated, fault-tolerant Oracle data centers that host cloud resources such as instances, volumes, and subnets. A region contains one or more availability domains." uk-tooltip="">availability domain <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong> or across an entire region (regional subnets are recommended). Subnets act as a unit of configuration within the VCN: All VNICs in a particular subnet use the same route table, security lists, and DHCP options (see the definitions that follow). You can define a subnet as either public or private when you create it. Private means VNICs in the subnet can't have public IPv4 addresses and internet communication with IPv6 endpoints is prohibited. Public means VNICs in the subnet can have public IPv4 addresses and internet communication is allowed with IPv6 endpoints. See <a class="xref" href="overview.htm#Private">Access to the Internet</a>.</p>
</div>
</dd>
<dt class="dt dlterm">VNIC</dt>
<dd class="dd">
<div> A virtual network interface card (VNIC), which attaches to a Compute instance and resides in a subnet to enable a connection to the subnet's VCN. A VNIC is the component the Compute instance uses to connect with endpoints inside and outside the VCN. Each Compute instance has a primary VNIC that's created during Compute instance creation and can't be removed. You can add secondary VNICs to an existing Compute instance (in the same availability domain as the primary VNIC), and remove them as needed. Each secondary VNIC can be in a subnet in the same VCN as the primary VNIC, or in a different subnet either in the same VCN or a different one. However, all the VNICs must be in the same availability domain as the Compute instance. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/managingVNICs.htm">Virtual Network Interface Cards (VNICs)</a>. A VNIC attached to a Compute instance and residing in an IPv6-enbled subnet can optionally be assigned an IPv6 address.</div>
</dd>
<dt class="dt dlterm">PRIVATE IP</dt>
<dd class="dd">
A private IPv4 address and related information for addressing a Compute instance (for example, a hostname for DNS). Each VNIC has a primary private IP, and you can add and remove secondary private IPs. The primary private IP address on a Compute instance doesn't change during the Compute instance's lifetime and can't be removed from the Compute instance. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/managingIPaddresses.htm">Private IP Addresses</a>.
</dd>
<dt class="dt dlterm">PUBLIC IP</dt>
<dd class="dd">A public IPv4 address and related information. You can optionally assign a public IP to Compute instances or other resources that have a private IP. Public IPs can be either <em>ephemeral</em> or <em>reserved</em>. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/managingpublicIPs.htm">Public IP Addresses</a>.</dd>
<dt class="dt dlterm"> IPV6</dt>
<dd class="dd">An IPv6 address and related information. IPv6 addressing is supported for
                        all commercial and government regions. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="ipv6.htm">IPv6 Addresses</a>. </dd>
<dt class="dt dlterm">
Dynamic Routing Gateway (DRG)</dt>
<dd class="dd">
 An optional virtual router that you can attach to one or many VCNs. It provides a path for <em>private</em> network traffic between a VCN and an on-premises network. You can use it with other Networking components and a router in an on-premises network to establish a connection by way of Site-to-Site VPN or Oracle Cloud Infrastructure
FastConnect. It can also provide a path for private network traffic between a VCN and another VCN in the same region or in a different region. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="overview.htm#on_prem_access">Access to Your On-Premises Network</a>, <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/managingDRGs.htm">Dynamic Routing Gateways</a>, <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/scenario_d.htm" title="This scenario describes using a mutual connection to an upgraded DRG to enable traffic between two or more VCNs." uk-tooltip="">Local VCN Peering Through an Upgraded DRG</a> and <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/scenario_e.htm" title="This topic is about remote VCN peering." uk-tooltip="">Remote VCN Peering through an Upgraded DRG</a>.
</dd>
<dt class="dt dlterm">INTERNET GATEWAY</dt>
<dd class="dd">An optional virtual router that you can add to a VCN for direct internet access. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/managingIGs.htm">Internet Gateway</a> and also <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/scenarioa.htm">Scenario A: Public Subnet</a>.</dd>
<dt class="dt dlterm">NETWORK ADDRESS TRANSLATION (NAT) GATEWAY</dt>
<dd class="dd">
 Another optional virtual router that you can add to a VCN. It gives cloud resources without public IP addresses access to the internet without exposing those resources to incoming internet connections. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="overview.htm#Public">Public vs. Private Subnets</a> and also <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/NATgateway.htm">NAT Gateway</a>.
</dd>
<dt class="dt dlterm">SERVICE GATEWAY</dt>
<dd class="dd">
 Another optional virtual router that you can add to a VCN. It provides a path for <em>private</em> network traffic between a VCN and <a class="xref" href="https://www.oracle.com/cloud/networking/service-gateway/service-gateway-supported-services/">supported services in the Oracle Services Network</a> (examples: Oracle Cloud Infrastructure
Object Storage and Autonomous AI Database). For example, DB Systems in a private subnet in a VCN can back up data to Object Storage without needing public IP addresses or access to the internet. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/servicegateway.htm#Access_to_Oracle_Services_Service_Gateway">Access to Oracle Services: Service Gateway</a>.
</dd>
<dt class="dt dlterm">LOCAL PEERING GATEWAY (LPG)</dt>
<dd class="dd">
 Another optional virtual router that you can add to a VCN. It lets you peer one VCN with another VCN in the same region. <em>Peering</em> means the VCNs communicate using private IP addresses, without the traffic traversing the internet or routing through an on-premises network. A VCN must have a separate LPG for each peering it establishes. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/localVCNpeering.htm">Local VCN Peering using Local Peering Gateways</a>.
</dd>
<dt class="dt dlterm">REMOTE PEERING CONNECTION (RPC)
            </dt>
<dd class="dd">A component that you can add to a DRG. It lets you peer one VCN with another VCN in a <em>different</em> region. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/scenario_e.htm" title="This topic is about remote VCN peering." uk-tooltip="">Remote VCN Peering through an Upgraded DRG</a>. </dd>
<dt class="dt dlterm">ROUTE TABLES</dt>
<dd class="dd">
 Virtual route tables for a VCN. They have rules to route traffic from subnets to destinations outside the VCN by way of gateways or specially configured Compute instances. A VCN comes with an empty default route table, and you can add custom route tables. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/managingroutetables.htm">VCN Route Tables</a>.
</dd>
<dt class="dt dlterm">SECURITY RULES</dt>
<dd class="dd">
 Virtual firewall rules for a VCN. Ingress and egress rules specify the types of traffic (protocol and port) allowed in and out of the Compute instances. You can decide whether a particular rule is stateful or stateless. For example, you can allow incoming SSH traffic from anywhere to a set of Compute instances by setting up a stateful ingress rule with source CIDR 0.0.0.0/0, and destination TCP port 22. To implement security rules, you can use <em>network security groups</em> or <em>security lists</em>. A network security group consists of a set of security rules that apply only to the resources in that group. Contrast this with a security list, where the rules apply to all the resources in any subnet that uses the list. A VCN comes with a default security list with default security rules. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="securityrules.htm">Security Rules</a>.
</dd>
<dt class="dt dlterm">DHCP OPTIONS</dt>
<dd class="dd">Configuration information automatically provided to the Compute instances when they boot up. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/managingDHCP.htm">DHCP Options</a>.</dd>
<dt class="dt dlterm">CIDR NOTATION</dt>
<dd class="dd">A compact method for specifying IP addresses or address ranges and network masks. For example, using IPv4 a private IP address range of 10.0.0.0/24 represents all addresses between 10.0.0.0 and 10.0.0.255. The /24 represents a subnet mask of 255.255.255.0 because the first 24 bits are masked. IPv6 uses similar notation to for address blocks. For more information,  see  <a aria-label="RFC1817. Opens in a new window" class="xref" href="https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc1817" rel="noopener" target="_blank">RFC1817</a> and <a aria-label="RFC1519. Opens in a new window" class="xref" href="https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc1519" rel="noopener" target="_blank">RFC1519</a>.</dd>
</dl>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title3" class="topic nested1" id="Allowed">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title3">Allowed VCN Size and Address Ranges</h2>
<div class="body">
<p>A VCN covers one or more IPv4 CIDR blocks or IPv6 prefixes. The allowable VCN size range is
                    /16
                    to /30. Example: 10.0.0.0/16. The Networking service reserves the first two IP
                    addresses and the last one in each subnet's CIDR.
                     You can enable IPv6 for VCNs when you create them, or you can enable IPv6 on existing IPv4-only VCNs. If you decide to use an Oracle-allocated IPv6 prefix, you always receive a /56. Alternately, you can <a class="xref" href="BYOIP.htm" title="Oracle Cloud Infrastructure allows you to Bring Your Own IP (BYOIP) address space to use with resources in Oracle Cloud Infrastructure, in addition to using Oracle owned addresses." uk-tooltip="">import your own BYOIP IPv6 prefix</a> from which you can assign any prefix of /64 or larger to a VCN, or you can assign a ULA prefix of /64 or larger. GUA ranges can be up to 2000::/3 and ULA ranges can be up to fc00::/7. IPv6 subnets are always /64 in size.</p>
<p>
For a VCN, we recommend using the private IP address ranges specified in <a aria-label="RFC 1918. Opens in a new window" class="xref" href="https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc1918" rel="noopener" target="_blank">RFC 1918</a> (the RFC recommends 10.0/8 or 172.16/12 but Oracle doesn't support those sizes so use 10.0/16, 172.16/16, and 192.168/16). However, you can use a publicly routable range. Regardless, this documentation uses the term <em>private IP address</em> when referring to IP addresses in a VCN's CIDR. Address ranges that are disallowed are described in <a class="xref" href="overview.htm#Reserved">IP Addresses Reserved for Use by Oracle</a>. For IPv6-enabled VCNs, Oracle can either allocate a global unicast address /56 prefix or you can create a VCN with a BYOIPv6 prefix.</p>
<p>The VCN's CIDR blocks must not overlap with each other, with CIDRs in a connected on-premises network, or with the CIDRs of <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/VCNpeering.htm">another VCN you peer with</a>. The subnets in a particular VCN must not overlap with each other. For reference, here's a <a aria-label="CIDR calculator. Opens in a new window" class="xref" href="http://www.ipaddressguide.com/cidr" rel="noopener" target="_blank">CIDR calculator</a>.</p>
<p>
IPv6 addressing is supported for all commercial and government regions. For more
            information, see <a class="xref" href="ipv6.htm">IPv6 Addresses</a>. </p>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title4" class="topic nested1" id="Regions">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title4">Availability Domains and VCNs</h2>
<div class="body">
<p id="Regions__availability-domain">A VCN resides in a single Oracle Cloud Infrastructure region. A region can have several availability domains to provide isolation and redundancy. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/General/Concepts/regions.htm">Regions and Availability Domains</a>.</p>
<div>
<p>Originally subnets were designed to cover only one availability domain (AD) in a region. They were all <em>AD-specific</em>, which means the subnet's resources were required to reside in a particular availability domain. Now subnets can be either AD-specific or <em>regional</em>. You select the type when you create the subnet. Both types of subnets can coexist in the same VCN. In the following diagram, subnets 1 to 3 are AD-specific, and subnet 4 is regional.</p>
<div uk-lightbox=""><a href="../Images/network_regional_subnet.svg"><img alt="This image shows a VCN with a regional subnet and three AD-specific subnets." src="../Images/network_regional_subnet.svg" tabindex="" title="Click to expand"/></a></div>
<p>Aside from the removal of the AD constraint, regional subnets behave the same as AD-specific subnets. <strong>We recommend using regional subnets</strong> because they're more flexible. They make it easier to efficiently divide a VCN into subnets while also designing for availability domain failure. </p>
<p>When you create a resource such as a Compute instance, you decide which availability domain the resource is in. From a virtual networking standpoint, you must also decide which VCN and subnet the instance is in. You can select either a regional subnet, or an AD-specific subnet that matches the AD you chose for the instance. </p>
</div>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title5" class="topic nested1" id="Default">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title5">Default Components that Come With a VCN</h2>
<div class="body">
<div>
<p>A VCN automatically comes with these <em>default</em> components:</p>
<ul>
<li>Default <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/managingroutetables.htm">route table</a>, with no route rules</li>
<li>Default <a class="xref" href="securitylists.htm#Default">security list</a>, with default security rules</li>
<li>Default <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/managingDHCP.htm">set of DHCP options</a>, with default values</li>
</ul>
<p>You can't delete these default components. However, you can change their contents (for example, the rules in the default security list). You can also create custom versions of each kind of component in a VCN. Limits exist as to how many you can create and the maximum number of rules. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/General/Concepts/servicelimits.htm">Limits by Service</a>.</p>
</div>
<p>Each subnet always has these components associated with it:</p>
<ul>
<li>One route table</li>
<li>One or more security lists (for the maximum number, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/General/Concepts/servicelimits.htm">Limits by Service</a>)</li>
<li>One set of DHCP options</li>
</ul>
<p>During subnet creation, you can decide which route table, security list, and set of DHCP options the subnet uses. If you don't specify a particular component, the subnet automatically uses the VCN's default component. You can <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/edit_subnet.htm" title="Edit the settings for a subnet in a Virtual Cloud Network (VCN)." uk-tooltip="">change which components the subnet uses</a> at any time.</p>
<div class="uk-alert uk-alert-warning"><span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="lifesaver"></span><strong> Tip</strong><br/><br/>
Security lists are one way to control traffic in and out of the VCN's resources. You can also use <a class="xref" href="networksecuritygroups.htm">network security groups</a>
</div>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title6" class="topic nested1" id="connectivity">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title6">Connectivity Choices</h2>
<div class="body">
<p>You can control whether subnets are public or private, and whether instances get public IP addresses. You can set up a VCN to have access to the internet if required. You can also privately connect a VCN to public Oracle Cloud Infrastructure services such as Object Storage, to an on-premises network, or to another VCN. </p>
</div>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title7" class="topic nested2" id="Public">
<h3 class="title topictitle3" id="ariaid-title7">Public vs. Private Subnets</h3>
<div class="body">
<p>When you create a subnet, by default it's considered public, which means instances in
            that subnet are allowed to have public IPv4 addresses and internet communication is
            permitted with IPv6 endpoints. Whoever launches the instance chooses whether it has a
            public IPv4 address or specifies whether an IPv6 address from the allocated prefix will
            be assigned. You can override that behavior when creating the subnet and request that it
            be private, which disallows the use of public IPv4 addresses and internet communication
            with IPv6 endpoints. Network administrators can therefore ensure that instances in the
            subnet have no internet access, even if the VCN has a working internet gateway, and
            security rules and firewall rules allow the traffic.</p>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title8" class="topic nested2" id="How">
<h3 class="title topictitle3" id="ariaid-title8">How IP Addresses Are Assigned<a name="How"></a>
</h3>
<div class="body">
<p>Each instance has a primary VNIC  that's created during instance launch and cannot be removed. You can add <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/managingVNICs.htm">secondary VNICs</a> to an existing instance (in the same availability domain as the primary VNIC) and remove them as you like.</p>
<p>Every VNIC has a private IP address from the associated subnet's CIDR. You can choose the
            particular IP address (during instance launch or secondary VNIC creation), or Oracle can
            choose it for you. The private IP address does not change during the lifetime of the
            instance and cannot be removed. You can also add <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/managingIPaddresses.htm">secondary private IPv4 addresses</a> or
            secondary IPv6 addresses to a VNIC.</p>
<p>If the VNIC is in a public subnet, then each private IP on that VNIC can have a <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/managingpublicIPs.htm">public IPv4 address or IPv6 address</a>
            assigned to it at your discretion. For IPv4, Oracle chooses the particular IP address.
            For IPv6, you can specify the IP address. There are two types of public IPs:
                <em>ephemeral</em> and <em>reserved</em>. An ephemeral public IP exists only for the
            lifetime of the private IP it's assigned to. In contrast, a reserved public IP exists as
            long as you want it to. You maintain a pool of reserved public IPs and allocate them to
            your instances at your discretion. You can move them from resource to resource in a
            region as you need to.</p>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title9" class="topic nested2" id="Private">
<h3 class="title topictitle3" id="ariaid-title9">Access to the Internet<a name="Private"></a>
</h3>
<div class="body">
<div>
<p>There are two optional gateways (virtual routers) that you can add to your VCN depending on the type of internet access you need:</p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Internet gateway:</strong> For resources with public IP addresses that need to be reached from the internet (example: a web server) or need to initiate connections to the internet.</li>
<li><strong>NAT gateway:</strong> For resources without public IP addresses that need to initiate connections to the internet (example: for software updates) but need to be protected from inbound connections from the internet.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div>
<p>Just having an internet gateway alone does not expose the instances in the VCN's subnets directly to the internet. The following requirements must also be met:</p>
<ul>
<li>The <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/managingIGs.htm">internet gateway</a> must be enabled (by default, the internet gateway is enabled upon creation).</li>
<li>The subnet must be <a class="xref" href="overview.htm#Public">public</a>.</li>
<li>
<p>The subnet must have a <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/managingroutetables.htm">route rule</a> that directs traffic to the internet gateway.</p>
</li>
<li>The subnet must have <a class="xref" href="securitylists.htm">security list rules</a> that allow the traffic (and each instance's firewall must allow the traffic).</li>
<li>
<p>The instance must have a <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/managingpublicIPs.htm">public IP address</a>.</p>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="uk-alert uk-alert-warning"><span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="lifesaver"></span><strong> Tip</strong><br/><br/>
<p>To access public services such as Object Storage from your VCN without the traffic going over the internet, use a <a class="xref" href="overview.htm#service_gateway">service gateway</a>. </p>
<p>Also, notice that traffic through an internet gateway between a VCN and a public IP address<em> that is part of Oracle Cloud Infrastructure
</em> (such as Object Storage) is routed without being sent over the internet.
</p>
</div>
<p class="keepWithNext">You can also give a subnet <em>indirect</em> access to the internet by setting up an  internet proxy in your on-premises network and then connecting that network to your VCN by way of a DRG.  For more information, see <a class="xref" href="overview.htm#on_prem_access">Access to Your On-Premises Network</a>. </p>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title10" class="topic nested2" id="service_gateway">
<h3 class="title topictitle3" id="ariaid-title10">Access to Public Oracle Cloud Infrastructure Services</h3>
<div class="body">
<p>You can use a service gateway with your VCN to enable private access to public Oracle Cloud Infrastructure services such as Object Storage. For example, DB Systems in a private subnet in your VCN can back up data to Object Storage without needing public IP addresses or access to the internet. No internet gateway or NAT is required.  For more information, see <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/servicegateway.htm#Access_to_Oracle_Services_Service_Gateway">Access to Oracle Services: Service Gateway</a>.</p>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title11" class="topic nested2" id="on_prem_access">
<h3 class="title topictitle3" id="ariaid-title11">Access to Your On-Premises Network<a name="on_prem_access"></a>
</h3>
<div class="body">
<div>
<p class="keepWithNext">There are two ways to connect your on-premises network to
                    Oracle Cloud Infrastructure:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a class="xref" href="../Tasks/managingIPsec.htm" title="Site-to-Site VPN provides an IPSec connection between an on-premises network and a Virtual Cloud Network (VCN)." uk-tooltip="">Site-to-Site VPN:</a> Offers multiple IPSec tunnels
                    between your existing network's edge and your VCN, by way of a <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/managingDRGs.htm">DRG</a> that you create
                    and attach to your VCN. </li>
<li>
<a class="xref" href="fastconnect.htm" title="Oracle Cloud Infrastructure FastConnect provides an easy way to create a dedicated, private connection between your data center and Oracle Cloud Infrastructure." uk-tooltip="">Oracle Cloud Infrastructure
FastConnect:</a> Offers a private connection between your existing network's edge and Oracle Cloud Infrastructure. Traffic does not traverse the internet. Both private peering and public peering are supported. That means your on-premises hosts can access private IPv4 or IPv6 addresses in your VCN as well as regional public IPv4 or IPv6 addresses in Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (for example, Object Storage or public <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Balance/Concepts/balanceoverview.htm">load balancers</a> in your VCN). </li>
</ul>
<p>You can use one or both types of the preceding connections. If you use both, you can use them simultaneously, or in a redundant configuration. These connections come to your VCN by way of a single DRG that you create and attach to your VCN. Without that DRG attachment and a route rule for the DRG, traffic does not flow between your VCN and on-premises network. At any time, you can detach the DRG from your VCN but maintain all the remaining components that form the rest of the connection. You could then reattach the DRG again, or attach it to another VCN.</p>
</div>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title12" class="topic nested2" id="access_another_vcn">
<h3 class="title topictitle3" id="ariaid-title12">Access to Another VCN</h3>
<div class="body">
<p>You can connect  your VCN to another VCN over a private connection that doesn't require the traffic to traverse the internet. In general, this type of connection is referred to as <em>VCN peering</em>. Each VCN must have specific components to enable peering. The VCNs must also have specific IAM policies, route rules, and security rules that permit the connection to be made and the wanted network traffic to flow over the connection. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/VCNpeering.htm">Access to Other VCNs: Peering</a>. </p>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title13" class="topic nested2" id="azure">
<h3 class="title topictitle3" id="ariaid-title13">Connection to Microsoft Azure</h3>
<div class="body">
<p>
Oracle and Microsoft have created a cross-cloud connection between Oracle Cloud Infrastructure and Microsoft Azure in certain regions. This connection lets you set up cross-cloud workloads without the traffic between the clouds going over the internet. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="azure.htm">Interconnect for Azure</a>.</p>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title14" class="topic nested2" id="libreswan">
<h3 class="title topictitle3" id="ariaid-title14">Connection to Other Clouds with Libreswan</h3>
<div class="body">
<p>You can connect your VCN to another cloud provider by using Site-to-Site VPN with a <a aria-label="Libreswan. Opens in a new window" class="xref" href="https://libreswan.org/" rel="noopener" target="_blank">Libreswan</a> VM as
            the customer-premises equipment (CPE). For more information, see <a class="xref" href="libreswan.htm">Access to Other Clouds with Libreswan</a>.</p>
</div>
</article>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title15" class="topic nested1" id="scenarios">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title15">Networking Scenarios</h2>
<div class="body">
<p>This documentation includes a few basic networking scenarios to help you understand the Networking service and how the components work together in general. See these topics:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a class="xref" href="../Tasks/scenarioa.htm">Scenario A: Public Subnet</a>
</li>
<li>
<a class="xref" href="../Tasks/scenariob.htm">Scenario B: Private Subnet with a VPN</a>
</li>
<li>
<a class="xref" href="../Tasks/scenarioc.htm">Scenario C: Public and Private Subnets with a VPN</a>
</li>
</ul>
<section class="section"><h3 class="title sectiontitle vl-no-in-page-toc">Transit Routing</h3>
<div>
<p>Scenarios A–C show an on-premises network connected to one or more VCNs by way of a DRG and <a class="xref" href="fastconnect.htm" title="Oracle Cloud Infrastructure FastConnect provides an easy way to create a dedicated, private connection between your data center and Oracle Cloud Infrastructure." uk-tooltip="">FastConnect</a> or <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/managingIPsec.htm" title="Site-to-Site VPN provides an IPSec connection between an on-premises network and a Virtual Cloud Network (VCN)." uk-tooltip="">Site-to-Site VPN</a>, and accessing only the resources in those VCNs.</p>
<p>The following advanced routing scenarios give an on-premises network access beyond the resources in the connected VCN. Traffic travels from an on-premises network to the DRG, and then <em>transits through</em> the DRG to its destination. See these topics:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a class="xref" href="../Tasks/transitrouting.htm">Transit Routing inside a hub VCN</a>: An on-premises network has access to <em>several</em> VCNs in the same region over a single FastConnect private virtual circuit or Site-to-Site VPN. The DRG and attached VCNs are in a hub-and-spoke topology, with the on-premises network connected to the DRG which acts as the hub. The spoke VCNs are peered.</li>
<li>
<a class="xref" href="../Tasks/transitroutingoracleservices.htm">Private Access to Oracle Services</a>: An on-premises network has <em>private access</em> to Oracle services in the <a class="xref" href="https://www.oracle.com/cloud/networking/service-gateway/service-gateway-supported-services/">Oracle Services Network</a> by way of a connected VCN and the VCN's <strong title="An optional virtual router that you can add to your Virtual Cloud Network (VCN). The gateway enables on-premises hosts or VCN hosts to privately access Oracle services (such as Object Storage and Autonomous AI Database) without exposing the resources to the public internet." uk-tooltip="">service gateway <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong>. The traffic doesn't go over the internet.</li>
</ul>
</div>
</section>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title16" class="topic nested1" id="regions">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title16">Regions and Availability Domains</h2>
<div class="body">
<p>A VCN resides in a single Oracle Cloud Infrastructure region. Each subnet resides in a single availability domain (AD). Availability domains are designed to provide isolation and redundancy in the VCN, as illustrated in <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/scenariob.htm">Scenario B</a> and <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/scenarioc.htm">Scenario C</a> mentioned earlier. For example, you could set up a primary set of subnets in a single AD, and then set up a duplicate set of subnets in a secondary AD. The two ADs are isolated from each other in the Oracle data centers, so if one fails, you can easily switch over to the other AD. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/General/Concepts/regions.htm">Regions and Availability Domains</a>.</p>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title17" class="topic nested1" id="oci-public-ips">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title17">Public IP Address Ranges</h2>
<div class="body">
<p>For a list of Oracle Cloud Infrastructure public IP ranges, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/General/Concepts/addressranges.htm">IP Address Ranges</a>.</p>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title18" class="topic nested1" id="Reserved">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title18">IP Addresses Reserved for Use by Oracle<a name="Reserved"></a>
</h2>
<div class="body">
<div class="bodydiv">
<p class="keepWithNext">Certain IP addresses are reserved for Oracle Cloud Infrastructure use and can't be used in an address numbering scheme.</p>
<section class="section" id="Reserved__iscsi"><h3 class="title sectiontitle vl-include-in-page-toc">169.254.0.0/16</h3>
<p>These addresses are used for iSCSI connections to the boot and block volumes, instance metadata, and other services.</p>
</section>
<section class="section" id="Reserved__class_d_e"><h3 class="title sectiontitle vl-include-in-page-toc">Class D and Class E</h3>
<p>All addresses from 224.0.0.0 to 239.255.255.255 (Class D) are prohibited for use in a VCN, they're reserved for multicast address assignments in the IP standards. See <a aria-label="RFC 3171. Opens in a new window" class="xref" href="https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3171" rel="noopener" target="_blank">RFC 3171</a> for details. </p>
<p>All addresses from 240.0.0.0 to 255.255.255.255 (Class E) are prohibited for use in a VCN, they're reserved for future use in the IP standards. See <a aria-label="RFC 1112, Section 4. Opens in a new window" class="xref" href="https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc1112" rel="noopener" target="_blank">RFC 1112, Section 4</a> for details.</p>
</section>
<section class="section" id="Reserved__reserved_subnet"><h3 class="title sectiontitle vl-include-in-page-toc">Three IP Addresses in Each Subnet</h3>
<p>These addresses consist of:</p>
<ul>
<li>The first IP address in the CIDR (the network address)</li>
<li>The last IP address in the CIDR (the broadcast address)</li>
<li>The first host address in the CIDR (the subnet default gateway address)</li>
</ul>
<p> For example, in a subnet with CIDR 192.168.0.0/24, these addresses are reserved:</p>
<ul>
<li> 192.168.0.0 (the network address)</li>
<li>192.168.0.255 (the broadcast address)</li>
<li>192.168.0.1 (the subnet default gateway address)</li>
</ul>
<p>The remaining addresses in the CIDR (192.168.0.2 to 192.168.0.254) are available for use.</p>
</section>
</div>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title19" class="topic nested1" id="events">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title19">Creating Automation with Events</h2>
<div class="body">
<p>
You can create automation based on state changes for Oracle Cloud Infrastructure resources by using event types, rules, and actions. <span id="events__ph_pointertoevents">For more information, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Events/Concepts/eventsoverview.htm">Overview of Events</a>.</span>
</p>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title20" class="topic nested1" id="resource">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title20">Resource Identifiers</h2>
<div class="body">
<p>
Most types of Oracle Cloud Infrastructure resources have a unique, Oracle-assigned identifier called an Oracle Cloud ID (OCID). For information about the OCID format and other ways to identify your resources, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/General/Concepts/identifiers.htm">Resource Identifiers</a>.
</p>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title21" class="topic nested1" id="The">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title21">Ways to Access Oracle Cloud Infrastructure
</h2>
<div class="body">
<div>
<p id="The__p_waystoaccess">You can access Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI) by using the <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/GSG/Tasks/signingin_topic-Signing_In_for_the_First_Time.htm">Console</a> (a browser-based interface), <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/API/Concepts/usingapi.htm">REST API</a>, or <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/API/Concepts/cliconcepts.htm">OCI CLI</a>.<span id="The__ph_instructions"> Instructions for using the Console, API, and CLI are included in topics throughout this documentation.</span>
<span id="The__ph_sdks">For a list of available SDKs, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/API/Concepts/sdks.htm">Software Development Kits and Command Line Interface</a>.</span></p>
<p id="The__p_console-access"><span id="The__ph_console-access">To access <span id="The__ph_console-access-for-service">the <a class="xref" href="https://cloud.oracle.com/">Console</a>, you must use a <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/GSG/Tasks/signinginIdentityDomain.htm#supported-browsers">supported browser</a>. To go to the Console sign-in page, open the navigation menu at the top of this page and select <strong class="ph uicontrol">Infrastructure Console</strong>. You are prompted to enter your cloud tenant, your user name, and your password.</span></span></p>
</div>
<p>For general information about using the API, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/API/Concepts/usingapi.htm">REST APIs</a>.</p>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title22" class="topic nested1" id="auth">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title22">Authentication and Authorization</h2>
<div class="body">
<div>
<p>Each service in Oracle Cloud Infrastructure integrates with IAM for authentication and authorization, for all interfaces (the Console, SDK or CLI, and REST API).</p>
<p>An administrator in an organization needs to set up <strong title="A collection of users who all need a particular type of access to a set of resources or compartment." uk-tooltip="">groups <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong>, <strong title="A collection of related resources that can be accessed only by groups that have been given permission by an administrator in your organization. Compartments can have a hierarchical structure, allowing for the creation of parent compartments and child compartments (also referred to as subcompartments)." uk-tooltip="">compartments <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong>, and <strong title='An Identity and Access Management (IAM) document that specifies who has what type of access to your resources. Policy can refer to several types of documents: an individual statement written in the policy language, a collection of statements in a single named "policy" document, and the overall body of policies that your organization uses to control access to resources.' uk-tooltip="">policies <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong> that control which users can access which services, which resources, and the type of access. For example, the policies control who can create new users, create and manage the cloud network, create instances, create buckets, download objects, and so on. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Identity/domains/overview.htm">Managing Identity Domains</a>. For specific details about writing policies for each of the different services, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Identity/Reference/policyreference.htm">Policy Reference</a>. </p>
<p>If you're a regular user (not an administrator) who needs to use the Oracle Cloud Infrastructure resources that the company owns, contact an administrator to set up a user ID for you. The administrator can confirm which compartment or compartments you can use.</p>
</div>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title23" class="topic nested1" id="Policies">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title23">
IAM Policies for Networking</h2>
<div class="body">
<p> The most straightforward approach to granting access to Networking is the policy listed in <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Identity/Concepts/commonpolicies.htm#network-admins-manage-cloud-network">Let network admins manage a cloud network</a>. It covers the cloud network and all the other Networking components (subnets, security lists, route tables, gateways, and so on). To also give network admins the ability to create instances (to test network connectivity), see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Identity/Concepts/commonpolicies.htm#launch-instances">Let users launch compute instances</a>. </p>
<p>If you're new to policies, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Identity/domains/overview.htm">Managing Identity Domains</a> and <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Identity/Concepts/commonpolicies.htm">Common Policies</a>. </p>
<p>For reference material for writing more detailed policies for Networking, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Identity/policyreference/corepolicyreference.htm">Details for the Core Services</a>. </p>
<section class="section"><h3 class="title sectiontitle vl-no-in-page-toc">Individual Resource-Types</h3>
<p>You can write policies that focus on individual resource-types (for example, security lists only) instead of the broader <code class="ph codeph">virtual-network-family</code>. The <code class="ph codeph">instance-family</code> resource-type also includes several permissions for VNICs, which reside in a subnet but attach to an instance. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Identity/policyreference/corepolicyreference.htm#Core">Details for Verb + Resource-Type Combinations</a> and <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/managingVNICs.htm">Virtual Network Interface Cards (VNICs)</a>.</p>
<p class="keepWithNext">A resource-type called <code class="ph codeph">local-peering-gateways</code> is included within <code class="ph codeph">virtual-network-family</code> and includes two other resource-types related to local VCN peering (within region):</p>
<ul>
<li class="keepWithNext">
<code class="ph codeph">local-peering-from</code>
</li>
<li class="keepWithNext">
<code class="ph codeph">local-peering-to</code>
</li>
</ul>
<p>The <code class="ph codeph">local-peering-gateways</code> resource-type covers all permissions
                related to local peering gateways (LPGs). The <code class="ph codeph">local-peering-from</code>
                and <code class="ph codeph">local-peering-to</code> resource-types are for granting permission to
                    <em>connect </em>two LPGs and define a peering relationship within a single
                region. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/drg-iam.htm#scenario_m__local-LPG">Local Peering using an LPG (VCNs in the Same Tenancy)</a> or <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/drg-iam.htm#scenario_m__local-LPG-xten">Local Peering using an LPG (VCNs in Different Tenancies)</a>.</p>
<p>Similarly, a resource-type called <code class="ph codeph">remote-peering-connections</code> is included within <code class="ph codeph">virtual-network-family</code> and includes two other resource-types related to remote VCN peering (across regions):</p>
<ul>
<li class="keepWithNext">
<code class="ph codeph">remote-peering-from</code>
</li>
<li class="keepWithNext">
<code class="ph codeph">remote-peering-to</code>
</li>
</ul>
<p>The <code class="ph codeph">remote-peering-connections</code> resource-type covers all permissions
                related to remote peering connections (RPCs). The
                    <code class="ph codeph">remote-peering-from</code> and <code class="ph codeph">remote-peering-to</code>
                resource-types are for granting permission to <em>connect</em> two RPCs and define a
                peering relationship across regions. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/drg-iam.htm#scenario_m__remote-peer-policy">Remote Peering with a Legacy DRG</a> and <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/drg-iam.htm#scenario_m__IAM_cross-tenancy">Remote Peering with an Upgraded DRG</a>.</p>
</section>
<section class="section"><h3 class="title sectiontitle vl-no-in-page-toc">Nuances of Different Verbs</h3>
<p>You can write policies that limit the level of access by using a different policy verb (<code class="ph codeph">manage</code> instead of <code class="ph codeph">use</code>, and so on). If you do, here are some nuances to understand about the policy verbs for Networking.</p>
<div>
<p>Be aware that the <code class="ph codeph">inspect</code> verb not only returns general information about the cloud network's components (for example, the name and OCID of a security list, or of a route table). It also includes the contents of the component (for example, the actual rules in the security list, the routes in the route table, and so on). </p>
<p class="keepWithNext">Also, the following types of abilities are available only with the <code class="ph codeph">manage</code> verb, not the <code class="ph codeph">use</code> verb:</p>
<ul>
<li>Update (enable/disable) <code class="ph codeph">internet-gateways</code></li>
<li>Update <code class="ph codeph">security-lists</code></li>
<li>Update <code class="ph codeph">route-tables</code></li>
<li>Update <code class="ph codeph">dhcp-options</code></li>
<li>Attach a Dynamic Routing Gateway (DRG) to a Virtual Cloud Network (VCN)</li>
<li>Create an IPSec connection between a DRG and customer-premises equipment (CPE)</li>
<li>Peer VCNs</li>
</ul>
<div class="uk-alert uk-alert-success"><span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="check"></span><strong> Important</strong><br/><br/> Each VCN has various components that directly affect the behavior of the network (route tables, security lists, DHCP options, Internet Gateway, and so on). When you create one of these components, you establish a relationship between that component and the VCN, which means you must be allowed in a policy to both create the component and manage the VCN itself. However, the ability to <em>update</em> that component (to change the route rules, security list rules, and so on) <strong>doesn't</strong> require permission to manage the VCN itself, even though changing that component can directly affect the behavior of the network. This discrepancy is designed to give you flexibility in granting least privilege to users, and not require you to grant excessive access to the VCN so the user can manage other components of the network. Be aware that by giving someone the ability to update a particular type of component, you're implicitly trusting them with controlling the network's behavior.</div>
</div>
<p>For more information about policy verbs, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Identity/Concepts/policies.htm#Policy">Policy Basics</a>. </p>
</section>
<section class="section"><h3 class="title sectiontitle vl-no-in-page-toc">Peering Policies</h3>
<p>For policies used in connecting a DRG to VCNs and DRGs in other regions and
                tenancies, see  <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/drg-iam.htm" title="Learn about IAM policies used with peering and dynamic routing gateways." uk-tooltip="">IAM Policies for Routing Between VCNs</a>.</p>
</section>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title24" class="topic nested1" id="Limits">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title24">Limits on Networking Components</h2>
<div class="body">
<p>See <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/General/Concepts/servicelimits.htm#network_limits">Networking Limits</a> for a list of applicable service limits, and <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/General/Concepts/servicelimits-request-increase.htm">Requesting a Service Limit Increase</a> for instructions on requesting a limit increase.  </p>
</div>
</article>
</article>
</article>

<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title1" role="article">
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title1" class="topic nested0" id="Security_Lists">
<h1 class="title topictitle1" id="ariaid-title1">Security Lists</h1>
<div class="body">
<p>The Networking service offers two  virtual firewall features to control traffic at the packet level:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<strong>Security lists:</strong> Covered in this topic. This is the original type of virtual firewall offered by the Networking service. </li>
<li>
<strong>Network security groups:</strong> Another type of virtual firewall that we recommend over security lists. See <a class="xref" href="networksecuritygroups.htm">Network Security Groups</a>.</li>
</ul>
<p>Both of these features use <em>security rules</em>. For important information about how security rules work, and a general comparison of security lists and network security groups, see <a class="xref" href="securityrules.htm">Security Rules</a>. </p>
</div>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title2" class="topic nested1" id="highlights">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title2">Highlights</h2>
<div class="body">
<ul>
<li> Security lists act as virtual firewalls for Compute instances and <a class="xref" href="securityrules.htm#comparison">other kinds of resources</a>. A security list consists of a set of ingress and egress <a class="xref" href="securityrules.htm">security rules</a> that apply to all the VNICs <em>in any subnet that the security list is associated with</em>. This means that all the VNICs in a particular subnet are subject to the same set of security lists. See <a class="xref" href="securityrules.htm#comparison">Comparison of Security Lists and Network Security Groups</a>.</li>
<li>Security list rules function the same as network security group rules.   For a discussion of rule parameters, see <a class="xref" href="securityrules.htm#sec_rules_parts">Parts of a Security Rule</a>.</li>
<li>Each VCN comes with a <a class="xref" href="securitylists.htm#Default">default security list</a> that has several default rules for essential traffic. If you don't specify a custom security list for a subnet, the default security list is automatically used with that subnet. You can add and remove rules from the default security list.</li>
<li>Security lists have separate and different limits compared to network security groups. See <a class="xref" href="securityrules.htm#comparison">Comparison of Security Lists and Network Security Groups</a>.</li>
</ul>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title3" class="topic nested1" id="Overview">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title3">Overview of Security Lists</h2>
<div class="body">
<p>
<div>A security list acts as a virtual firewall for an instance, with ingress and egress rules that specify the types of traffic allowed in and out. Each security list is enforced at the VNIC level. However, you configure security lists <em>at the subnet level</em>, which means that all VNICs in a subnet are subject to the same set of security lists. The security lists apply to a particular VNIC whether it's communicating with another instance in the VCN or a host outside the VCN. </div>
</p>
<p> Each subnet can have several security lists associated with it, and each list can have many rules (for the maximum number, see <a class="xref" href="securityrules.htm#comparison">Comparison of Security Lists and Network Security Groups</a>). A packet in question is allowed if <em>any rule in any of the lists</em> allows the traffic (or if the traffic is part of an existing connection being tracked) unless the lists happen to contain both stateful and stateless rules that cover the same traffic. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="securityrules.htm#stateful">Stateful Compared to Stateless Rules</a>.</p>
<p>Security lists are regional entities. For limits related to security lists, see <a class="xref" href="securityrules.htm#comparison">Comparison of Security Lists and Network Security Groups</a>.</p>
<p>Security lists can control both IPv4 and IPv6 traffic. IPv6 addressing and related
            security list rules are supported in all commercial and government regions. For more
            information, see <a class="xref" href="ipv6.htm">IPv6 Addresses</a>. </p>
<p>See <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/General/Concepts/servicelimits.htm#sec_list_limits">Security List Limits</a> and <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/General/Concepts/servicelimits-request-increase.htm">Requesting a Service Limit Increase</a> for limits-related information.</p>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title4" class="topic nested1" id="Default">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title4">Default Security List</h2>
<div class="body">
<div>
<p class="keepWithNext">Unlike other security lists, the default security list comes with an initial set of stateful rules. We recommend changing these rules  to only allow inbound traffic from authorized subnets relevant to the region that homes that VCN or subnet. A list of authorized subnet ranges relevant to each region can be found at <a class="xref" href="/iaas/tools/public_ip_ranges.json">https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/iaas/tools/public_ip_ranges.json</a>.</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p><strong>Stateful ingress: </strong>Allow TCP traffic on destination port 22 (SSH) from authorized source IP addresses and any source port. This rule makes it easy for you to create a new cloud network and public subnet, create a Linux instance, and then immediately use SSH to connect to that instance without needing to write any security list rules yourself. </p>
<div class="uk-alert uk-alert-success"><span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="check"></span><strong> Important</strong><br/><br/>
<p>The default security list doesn't include a rule to allow Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) access. If you're using <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Compute/References/images.htm">Windows images</a>, ensure that you add a stateful ingress rule for TCP traffic on destination port 3389 from authorized source IP addresses and any source port.</p>
<p>See <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Compute/Tasks/launchinginstance.htm#prerequisites__enablerdp">To enable RDP access</a> for more information.</p>
</div>
</li>
<li><strong>Stateful ingress:</strong> Allow ICMP traffic type 3 code 4 from authorized source IP addresses. This rule enables Compute instances to receive Path MTU Discovery fragmentation messages. </li>
<li><strong>Stateful ingress:</strong> Allow ICMP traffic type 3 (all codes) from the VCN's CIDR block. This rule makes it easy for Compute instances to receive connectivity error messages from other instances within the VCN.</li>
<li><strong>Stateful egress:</strong> Allow all traffic. This lets instances start traffic of any kind to any destination. Notice that this means the instances with public IP addresses can talk to any internet IP address if the VCN has a configured internet gateway. And because stateful security rules use connection tracking, the response traffic is automatically allowed regardless of any ingress rules. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="securityrules.htm#stateful">Stateful Compared to Stateless Rules</a>.</li>
</ul>
<p>The default security list comes with no stateless rules. However, you can always add
                or remove rules from the default security list.</p>
</div>
<p>If the VCN is enabled for IPv6 addressing the default security list contains some default rules for IPv6 traffic. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="securitylists.htm#security_lists">Security Rules for IPv6 Traffic</a>. </p>
<section class="section" id="Default__ping"><h3 class="title sectiontitle vl-no-in-page-toc">
Enabling Ping
</h3>
<p>The default security list doesn't include a rule to allow ping requests. If you plan to ping an instance, see <a class="xref" href="securityrules.htm#fragudp">Rules to Handle Fragmented UDP Packets</a>.</p>
</section>
</div>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title5" class="topic nested2" id="security_lists">
<h3 class="title topictitle3" id="ariaid-title5">Security Rules for IPv6 Traffic</h3>
<div class="body">
<p>The VCN's <a class="xref" href="networksecuritygroups.htm">network security groups</a> and <a class="xref" href="securityrules.htm">security lists</a> support both IPv4 and IPv6 <a class="xref" href="securityrules.htm">security rules</a>. For example, a network security group or security list could have these security rules:</p>
<ul>
<li>Rule to allow SSH traffic from the on-premises network's IPv4 CIDR</li>
<li>Rule to allow ping traffic from the on-premises network's IPv4 CIDR</li>
<li>Rule to allow SSH traffic from the on-premises network's <strong>IPv6</strong> prefix</li>
<li>Rule to allow ping traffic from the on-premises network's <strong>IPv6</strong> prefix</li>
</ul>
<p class="keepWithNext">The <a class="xref" href="securitylists.htm#Default">default security list</a> in an IPv6-enabled VCN includes default IPv4 rules and the following default IPv6 rules: </p>
<ul>
<li>
<p><strong>Stateful ingress:</strong> Allow IPv6 TCP traffic on destination port 22 (SSH)
                    from source ::/0 and any source port. This rule makes it easy for you to create
                    a VCN with a public subnet and internet gateway, create a Linux instance, add an
                    internet-access-enabled IPv6, and then immediately connect with SSH to that
                    instance without needing to write any security rules yourself. </p>
<div class="uk-alert uk-alert-success"><span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="check"></span><strong> Important</strong><br/><br/>
<p>The default security list doesn't include a rule to allow Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) access. If you're using <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Compute/References/images.htm">Windows images</a>, add a stateful ingress rule for TCP traffic on destination port 3389 from source ::/0 and any source port.</p>
<p>See <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Compute/Tasks/launchinginstance.htm#prerequisites__enablerdp">To enable RDP access</a> for more information.</p>
</div>
</li>
<li><strong>Stateful ingress: </strong>Allow ICMPv6 traffic type 2 code 0 (Packet Too Big) from source ::/0 and any source port. This rule lets instances to receive Path MTU Discovery fragmentation messages.</li>
<li><strong>Stateful egress:</strong> Choosing to allow all IPv6 traffic lets instances start IPv6 traffic of any kind to any destination. Notice that instances with an internet-access-enabled IPv6 can talk to any internet IPv6 address if the VCN has a configured internet gateway. And because stateful security rules use connection tracking, the response traffic is automatically allowed regardless of any ingress rules. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="securityrules.htm#stateful">Stateful Compared to Stateless Rules</a>.</li>
</ul>
</div>
</article>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title6" class="topic nested1" id="rules">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title6">Security Rules</h2>
<div class="body">
<p>If you're not yet familiar with the basics of security rules, see these sections in the security rules topic:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a class="xref" href="securityrules.htm#sec_rules_parts">Parts of a Security Rule</a>
</li>
<li>
<a class="xref" href="securityrules.htm#stateful">Stateful Compared to Stateless Rules</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
</article>
</article>
</article>
