<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title1" role="article">
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title1" class="topic nested0" id="Network_Security_Groups">
<h1 class="title topictitle1" id="ariaid-title1">Network Security Groups</h1>
<div class="body">
<p>The Networking service offers two virtual firewall features to control traffic at the packet level:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<strong>Network security groups:</strong> Covered in this topic. Network security groups (NSGs) are supported only for <a class="xref" href="networksecuritygroups.htm#support">specific services</a>.</li>
<li>
<strong>Security lists:</strong> The original type of virtual firewall offered by the Networking service. See <a class="xref" href="securitylists.htm">Security Lists</a>.</li>
</ul>
<p>Both of these features use <em>security rules</em>. For important information about how security rules work, and a general comparison of security lists and network security groups, see <a class="xref" href="securityrules.htm">Security Rules</a>. </p>
<div class="uk-alert uk-alert-primary"><span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="file-edit"></span><strong> Note</strong><br/><br/>
You can use Zero Trust Packet Routing (ZPR) along with or in place of network security groups to manage network access to OCI
<strong title="The cloud objects that you create and use when interacting with Oracle Cloud Infrastructure." uk-tooltip="">resources <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong>. To do this, define ZPR policies that govern how resources communicate with each other, and then add security attributes to those resources. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/zero-trust-packet-routing/home.htm">Zero Trust Packet Routing</a>. 
</div>
<div class="uk-alert uk-alert-warning"><span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="warning"></span><strong> Caution</strong><br/><br/>
If an endpoint has a Zero Trust Packet Routing (ZPR) security attribute, traffic to the endpoint must satisfy ZPR policies and also all NSG and security list rules. For example, if you're already using NSGs and you add a security attribute to an endpoint, all traffic to the endpoint is blocked. From then onward, a ZPR policy must explicitly allow traffic to the endpoint.
</div>
</div>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title2" class="topic nested1" id="highlights">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title2">Highlights</h2>
<div class="body">
<ul>
<li> Network security groups (NSGs) act as a virtual firewall for Compute instances and <a class="xref" href="securityrules.htm#comparison">other kinds of resources</a>. An NSG consists of a set of ingress and egress <a class="xref" href="securityrules.htm">security rules</a> that apply only to <em>a set of VNICs in a single VCN</em> (for example: all the Compute instances that act as web servers in the web tier of a multitier application in a VCN). </li>
<li>Compared to security lists, NSGs let you separate a VCN's subnet architecture from the application security requirements. See <a class="xref" href="securityrules.htm#comparison">Comparison of Security Lists and Network Security Groups</a>.</li>
<li>You can use NSGs with certain resource types. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="networksecuritygroups.htm#support">Support for Network Security Groups</a>.</li>
<li>NSG security rules function the same as security list rules.   However, for an NSG security rule's source (for ingress rules) or destination (for egress rules), you can specify an NSG  instead of a CIDR. This means you can easily write security rules to control traffic between two NSGs <em>in the same VCN</em>, or traffic within a single NSG. See <a class="xref" href="securityrules.htm#sec_rules_parts">Parts of a Security Rule</a>.</li>
<li>Unlike with security lists, the VCN doesn't have a default NSG. Also, each NSG you create is initially empty. It has no default security rules.</li>
<li>Network security groups have separate and different limits compared to security lists. See <a class="xref" href="securityrules.htm#sec_list_limits">Security List Limits</a>.</li>
</ul>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title3" class="topic nested1" id="support">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title3">Support for Network Security Groups</h2>
<div class="body">
<p>NSGs are available for you to create and use. However, they're not yet supported by all the relevant Oracle Cloud Infrastructure services.</p>
<p>The following types of <a class="xref" href="securityrules.htm#comparison">parent resources</a> support the use of NSGs:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<strong>Autonomous Recovery Service</strong> (Subnets for Recovery Service): When you <a class="xref" href="/iaas/recovery-service/doc/register-recovery-subnet.html">register a Recovery Service subnet</a>, you can associate one or more NSGs (maximum five) that contain the ingress rules for Recovery Service.</li>
<li>
<strong>
Compute instances:</strong> When you create an instance, you can specify one or more NSGs for the instance's primary VNIC. If you add a secondary VNIC to an instance, you can specify one or more NSGs for that VNIC. You can also update existing VNICs on an instance so that they're in one or more NSGs.</li>
<li>
<strong>Load balancers:</strong> When you create a Load Balancer, you can specify one or more NSGs for the Load Balancer (not the backend set). You can also update an existing Load Balancer to use one or more NSGs.</li>
<li>
<strong>DB systems:</strong> When you create a DB system, you can specify one or more NSGs. You can also update an existing DB system to use one or more NSGs.</li>
<li>
<strong>
Autonomous AI Databases:</strong> When you create an Autonomous AI Database on dedicated Exadata infrastructure, you can specify one or more NSGs for the infrastructure resource. </li>
<li>
<strong>Mount targets:</strong> When you create a mount target for a file system, you can specify one or more NSGs. You can also update an existing mount target to use one or more NSGs. </li>
<li>
<strong>DNS resolver endpoint:</strong> When you create an endpoint for a <a class="xref" href="dns-topic-Private-resolver.htm" title="A private DNS resolver answers DNS queries for a VCN per a configuration you create." uk-tooltip="">private DNS resolver</a>, you can
                specify one or more NSGs. You can also update an existing endpoint to use one or
                more NSGs. </li>
<li>
<strong>Kubernetes clusters:</strong> When you <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/ContEng/Tasks/contengcreatingclusterusingoke_topic-Using_the_Console_to_create_a_Custom_Cluster_with_Explicitly_Defined_Settings.htm">create a Kubernetes cluster</a> using Kubernetes Engine, you can specify one or more NSGs to control access to the Kubernetes API endpoint and to worker nodes. You can also specify NSGs when <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/ContEng/Tasks/contengconfiguringloadbalancersnetworkloadbalancers-subtopic.htm#contengcreatingloadbalancer_topic_Specifying_Load_Balancer_Network_Security_Group">defining a load balancer for a cluster</a>.</li>
<li>
<strong>API gateways:</strong> When you <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/APIGateway/Tasks/apigatewaycreatinggateway.htm">create an API gateway</a>, you can specify one or more NSGs to control access to the API gateway.</li>
<li>
<strong>Functions:</strong> When you <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Functions/Tasks/functionsusingnsgs.htm">set up an application</a> in OCI Functions, you can specify one or more NSGs to define ingress and egress rules that apply to all the functions in that particular application.</li>
<li>
<strong>GoldenGate deployments:</strong> When you <a class="xref" href="https://docs.oracle.com/en/cloud/paas/goldengate-service/llyhq/#GUID-899C1348-58CA-43EE-B775-EAD3B365A7A9">create
                    a GoldenGate deployment</a>, you can specify one or more NSGs to control
                access to the deployment.</li>
<li>
<strong>Redis clusters:</strong> When you <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/ocicache/createcluster.htm">create a Redis cluster</a>, you can specify one or more NSGs to control
                access to the Redis cluster. You can also update an existing cluster to use one or
                more NSGs</li>
</ul>
<p>For resource types that don't yet support NSGs, continue to use security lists to control traffic in and out of those parent resources.</p>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title4" class="topic nested1" id="overview">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title4">Overview of Network Security Groups</h2>
<div class="body">
<p>A network security group (NSG) provides a virtual firewall for a set of cloud resources that all have the same security posture. For example: a group of Compute instances that all perform the same tasks and thus all need to use the same set of ports. </p>
<p>An NSG consists of two types of items:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<strong>VNICs:</strong> One or more <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/managingVNICs.htm">VNICs</a> (for example, the VNICs attached to the set of Compute instances that all have the same security posture). All the VNICs must be in the same VCN as the NSG. Also see <a class="xref" href="securityrules.htm#comparison">Comparison of Security Lists and Network Security Groups</a>.</li>
<li>
<strong>Security rules:</strong> The NSG's<a class="xref" href="securityrules.htm">Security rules</a> define the types of traffic allowed in and out of the VNICs in the group. For example: ingress TCP port 22 SSH traffic from a particular source.</li>
</ul>
<p>If you have resources with different security postures <em>in the same VCN</em>, you can write NSG security rules to control traffic between the resources with one posture compared to another. For example, in the following diagram, NSG1 has VNICs running in one tier of a multitier architecture application. NSG2 has VNICs running in a second tier. Both NSGs must belong to the same VCN. The assumption is that both NSGs need to start connections to the other NSG.</p>
<p>For NSG1, you set up egress security rules that specify NSG2 as the destination, and ingress security rules that specify NSG2 as the source. Likewise for NSG2, you set up egress security rules that specify NSG1 as the destination, and ingress security rules that specify NSG1 as the source. The rules are assumed to be <a class="xref" href="securityrules.htm#stateful">stateful</a> in this example.</p>
<div uk-lightbox=""><a href="../Images/network_nsg_two_tiers.svg"><img alt="You can set up security rules to control traffic between two network security groups." src="../Images/network_nsg_two_tiers.svg" tabindex="" title="Click to expand" width="300"/></a></div>
<p>The preceding diagram assumes that each NSG needs to start connections to the other NSG. </p>
<p>The next diagram assumes that you instead want to only allow connections started from NSG1 to NSG2. To do that, remove the ingress rule from NSG1 and the egress rule from NSG2. The remaining rules don't allow connections started from NSG2 to NSG1.</p>
<div uk-lightbox=""><a href="../Images/network_nsg_two_tiers_one_direction.svg"><img alt="These security rules allow connections started in only one direction: from NSG1 to NSG2." src="../Images/network_nsg_two_tiers_one_direction.svg" tabindex="" title="Click to expand" width="300"/></a></div>
<p>The next diagram assumes that you want to control traffic between VNICs <em>in the same NSG</em>. To do that, set the rule's source (for ingress) or destination (for egress) as the rule's own NSG. </p>
<div uk-lightbox=""><a href="../Images/network_nsg_same_nsg.svg"><img alt="You can set up security rules to control traffic between VNICs in the same NSG." src="../Images/network_nsg_same_nsg.svg" tabindex="" title="Click to expand" width="200"/></a></div>
<p>A VNIC can be in a maximum of five NSGs. A packet in question is allowed if <em>any rule in any of the VNIC's NSGs</em> allows the traffic (or if the traffic is part of an existing connection being tracked), unless the lists happen to contain both stateful and stateless security rules that cover the same traffic. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="securityrules.htm#stateful">Stateful Compared to Stateless Rules</a>.</p>
<p>Network security groups are regional entities. For limits related to network security groups, see <a class="xref" href="securityrules.htm#comparison">Comparison of Security Lists and Network Security Groups</a>. </p>
<p>See <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/General/Concepts/servicelimits.htm#nsg_limits">Network Security Group Limits</a> and <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/General/Concepts/servicelimits-request-increase.htm">Requesting a Service Limit Increase</a> for limits-related information.</p>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title5" class="topic nested1" id="rules">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title5">Security Rules</h2>
<div class="body">
<p>If you're not yet familiar with the basics of NSG security rules, see these sections in the security rules topic:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a class="xref" href="securityrules.htm#sec_rules_parts">Parts of a Security Rule</a>
</li>
<li>
<a class="xref" href="securityrules.htm#stateful">Stateful Compared to Stateless Rules</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title6" class="topic nested1" id="api">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title6">Using the API</h2>
<div class="body">
<p>
For information about using the API and signing requests, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/API/Concepts/usingapi.htm">REST API documentation</a> and <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/General/Concepts/credentials.htm">Security Credentials</a>. For information about SDKs, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/API/Concepts/sdks.htm">SDKs and the CLI</a>.
</p>
<p>
For information about using the API and signing requests, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/API/Concepts/usingapi.htm">REST API documentation</a> and <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/General/Concepts/credentials.htm">Security Credentials</a>. For information about SDKs, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/API/Concepts/sdks.htm">SDKs and the CLI</a>.
</p>
<p>Some differences in the REST API model for NSGs compared to security lists:</p>
<ul>
<li>Security lists have an <code class="ph codeph">IngressSecurityRule</code> object and a separate <code class="ph codeph">EgressSecurityRule</code> object. Network security groups only have a <code class="ph codeph">SecurityRule</code> object, and the object's <code class="ph codeph">direction</code> attribute shows whether the rule is for ingress or egress traffic.</li>
<li>With security lists, the rules are part of the <code class="ph codeph">SecurityList</code> object, and you work with the rules by calling the security list operations (such as <code class="ph codeph">UpdateSecurityList</code>). With NSGs, the rules aren't part of the <code class="ph codeph">NetworkSecurityGroup</code> object. Instead you use separate operations to work with the rules for a particular NSG (example: <code class="ph codeph">UpdateNetworkSecurityGroupSecurityRules</code>).</li>
<li>The model for <em>updating </em>existing security rules is different between security lists and NSGs. With NSGs, each rule in a particular group has a unique Oracle-assigned identifier (example: 04ABEC). When you call <code class="ph codeph">UpdateNetworkSecurityGroupSecurityRules</code>, you provide the IDs of the specific rules that you want to update. For comparison, with security lists, the rules have no unique identifier. When you call <code class="ph codeph">UpdateSecurityList</code>, you must pass in the <em>entire</em> list of rules, including rules that aren't being updated in the call. </li>
<li>Security rules a limit of 25 rules when calling the operations to add, remove, or update.</li>
</ul>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title7" class="topic nested1" id="working">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title7">Working with  Network Security Groups</h2>
<div class="body">
<section class="section"><h3 class="title sectiontitle vl-no-in-page-toc">General Process for Working with NSGs</h3>
<ol>
<li>Create an NSG.</li>
<li>Add security rules to the NSG.</li>
<li>Add parent resources (such as VNICs) to the NSG. You can do this when you create the parent resource, or you can update the parent resource and add it to one or more NSGs. When you create a Compute instance and add it to an NSG, the instance's primary VNIC is added to the NSG. Separately, you can create secondary VNICs and optionally add them to NSGs. </li>
</ol>
</section>
<section class="section" id="working__delete"><h3 class="title sectiontitle vl-no-in-page-toc">
Deleting NSGs
</h3>
<p>To <a class="xref" href="delete_nsg.htm" title="Delete a network security group (NSG) from a Virtual Cloud Network (VCN)." uk-tooltip="">delete an NSG</a>, it must not contain any VNICs or parent resources. When a parent resource (or a Compute instance VNIC) is deleted, it's automatically removed from the NSGs it was in. You might not have permission to delete a particular parent resource. Contact the tenancy administrator to find who owns a particular resource.</p>
</section>
<section class="section"><h3 class="title sectiontitle vl-no-in-page-toc">Required IAM Policy</h3>
<div>
<p>To use Oracle Cloud Infrastructure, an administrator must be a member of a group granted security access in a <strong title='An Identity and Access Management (IAM) document that specifies who has what type of access to your resources. Policy can refer to several types of documents: an individual statement written in the policy language, a collection of statements in a single named "policy" document, and the overall body of policies that your organization uses to control access to resources.' uk-tooltip="">policy <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong> by a tenancy administrator. This access is required whether you're using the Console or the REST API with an SDK, CLI, or other tool. If you get a message that you don't have permission or are unauthorized, verify with the tenancy administrator what type of access you have and which <strong title="A collection of related resources that can be accessed only by groups that have been given permission by an administrator in your organization. Compartments can have a hierarchical structure, allowing for the creation of parent compartments and child compartments (also referred to as subcompartments)." uk-tooltip="">compartment <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong> your access works in.</p>
</div>
<p>For administrators: The policy in <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Identity/Concepts/commonpolicies.htm#network-admins-manage-cloud-network">Let network admins manage a cloud network</a> covers management of all Networking components, including NSGs.</p>
<p class="keepWithNext"> If you have security admins who need to manage NSGs but
                not other components in the Networking service, you
                could write a more restrictive policy: </p>
<div class="uk-position-relative"><pre class="pre codeblock scrollcopy"><code>Allow group NSGAdmins to manage network-security-groups in tenancy
			
Allow group NSGAdmins to manage vcns in tenancy 
      where ANY {request.operation = 'CreateNetworkSecurityGroup',
                 request.operation = 'DeleteNetworkSecurityGroup'}

Allow group NSGAdmins to read vcns in tenancy

Allow group NSGAdmins to use VNICs in tenancy</code></pre></div>
<p>The first statement lets the NSGAdmins group create and manage NSGs
and their security rules.          </p>
<p>The second statement is required because the creation or deletion of an NSG affects the VCN that the NSG is in. The statement restricts the VCN-related permissions to only those required to create or delete an NSG. The statement doesn't allow the NSGAdmins group to create or delete VCNs, or work with any resources in a VCN except NSGs. </p>
<p>The third statement is required for listing the VCNs, which is a prerequisite for creating or deleting an NSG in a VCN. For information about why <em>both</em> the second and third statements are required, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Identity/policiesadvfeatures/policyadvancedfeatures.htm#conditions">Conditions</a>.</p>
<p>The fourth statement is required if the NSGAdmins need to put VNICs into an NSG.
                Whoever creates the parent resource of the VNIC (for example, a Compute instance) must already have this level of
                permission to create the parent resource. </p>
<p>For more information about Networking service policies,
                see <a class="xref" href="overview.htm#Policies">IAM Policies for Networking</a>.</p>
</section>
</div>
</article>
</article>
</article>

<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title1" role="article">
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title1" class="topic nested0" id="top">
<h1 class="title topictitle1" id="ariaid-title1">Overview of Monitoring
</h1>
<div class="body"><p class="shortdesc">Use the Oracle Cloud Infrastructure Monitoring service to actively and passively monitor cloud resources using the Metrics and Alarms features. Learn how Monitoring works.</p>
<p id="top__metrics-alarms-diagram">
<div uk-lightbox=""><a href="../images/monitoringOverview.svg"><img alt="This image shows metrics and alarms as used in the Monitoring service." src="../images/monitoringOverview.svg" tabindex="" title="Click to expand"/></a></div>
</p>
<div class="uk-alert uk-alert-warning"><span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="lifesaver"></span><strong> Tip</strong><br/><br/> Watch a <a class="xref" href="https://apexapps.oracle.com/pls/apex/f?p=44785:265:0:::265:P265_CONTENT_ID:31981">video introduction</a> to the service.</div>
</div>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title2" class="topic nested1" id="How">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title2">How Monitoring Works</h2>
<div class="body">
<p>The Monitoring service uses <strong title="A measurement related to the health, capacity, or performance of a given resource. For example, CPU Utilization (CpuUtilization) measures the activity level from CPU, expressed as a percentage of total time." uk-tooltip="">metrics <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong> to monitor resources and <strong title="The trigger rule and query to evaluate, plus related configuration, such as the notification details to use when the trigger is breached. Alarms passively monitor your cloud resources by using metrics in the Monitoring service." uk-tooltip="">alarms <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong> to notify you when these metrics meet alarm-specified triggers. </p>
<p>Metrics are emitted to the Monitoring service as raw <strong title="A timestamp-value pair for a specified metric—for example, 2018-05-10T22:19:00Z, 10.4." uk-tooltip="">data points <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong>, or timestamp-value pairs, along with <strong title="A qualifier provided in a metric definition—for example, a resource identifier (resourceId) provided in the definitions of oci_computeagent metrics." uk-tooltip="">dimensions <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong> and metadata. Metrics come from various sources:</p>
<ul>
<li>Resource metrics automatically posted by Oracle Cloud Infrastructure
<strong title="The cloud objects that you create and use when interacting with Oracle Cloud Infrastructure." uk-tooltip="">resources <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong>. For example, the Compute service posts metrics for monitoring-enabled compute instances through <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Compute/References/computemetrics.htm#Availabl">the oci_computeagent namespace</a>. One such metric is <code class="ph codeph">CpuUtilization</code>. See <a class="xref" href="monitoringoverview.htm#SupportedServices">Supported Services</a> and <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/viewingcharts.htm" title="View metric charts that use predefined service queries. Default metric charts are available on the Service Metrics page and resource details pages in the Console." uk-tooltip="">Viewing Default Metric Charts</a>.</li>
<li>
<a class="xref" href="../Tasks/publishingcustommetrics.htm" title="Publish custom metrics to the Monitoring service." uk-tooltip="">Custom metrics</a> published using the Monitoring API.</li>
<li>Data sent to new or existing metrics using <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/connector-hub/home.htm">
Connector Hub
</a> (with Monitoring as the target service for a connector).</li>
</ul>
<p id="How__p_transfer-metrics-sch">You can transfer metrics from the Monitoring service using <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/connector-hub/home.htm">
Connector Hub
</a>. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/connector-hub/create-service-connector-monitoring-source.htm">Creating a Connector with a Monitoring Source</a>.</p>
<p>Metric data posted to the Monitoring service is only presented to you or consumed by the Oracle Cloud Infrastructure features that you enable to use metric data.</p>
<p>When you query a metric, the Monitoring service returns aggregated data according to the specified parameters. You can specify a range (such as the last 24 hours), <strong title="The aggregation function applied to the given set of raw data points—for example, SUM." uk-tooltip="">statistic <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong>, and <strong title="The time window used to convert a given set of raw data points—for example, 5 minutes." uk-tooltip="">interval <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong>. The Console displays one monitoring chart per metric for selected resources. The aggregated data in each chart reflects the selected statistic and interval. API requests can optionally filter by <strong title="A qualifier provided in a metric definition—for example, a resource identifier (resourceId) provided in the definitions of oci_computeagent metrics." uk-tooltip="">dimension <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong> and specify a <strong title="The period between time windows, or the regularity at which time windows shift—for example, 1 minute." uk-tooltip="">resolution <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong>. API responses include the metric name along with its source compartment and <strong title="Indicates the resource, service, or application that emits a metric. The namespace is provided in the metric definition. For example, the CpuUtilization metric definition emitted by the Oracle Cloud Agent software on Compute instances lists the oci_computeagent metric namespace as the source of the metric." uk-tooltip="">metric namespace <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong>. You can feed the aggregated data into a visualization or graphing library. </p>
<p>Metric and alarm data is accessible from the Console, CLI, and API. For retention periods, see <a class="xref" href="monitoringoverview.htm#Storage">Storage Limits</a>. </p>
<p>The Alarms feature of the Monitoring service publishes alarm <strong title="An alert published to all subscriptions in the specified topic. Each message is delivered at least once per subscription." uk-tooltip="">messages <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong> to configured destinations, such as topics in <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Notification/home.htm">
Notifications
</a> and streams in <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Streaming/home.htm">
Streaming
</a>.</p>
</div>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title3" class="topic nested2" id="metrics">
<h3 class="title topictitle3 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title3">Metrics Feature Overview<a name="MetricsOverview"></a>
</h3>
<div class="body"><p class="shortdesc">The Metrics feature relays metric data about the health, capacity, and performance of cloud resources.</p>
<p>A metric is a measurement related to health, capacity, or performance of a <strong title="The cloud objects that you create and use when interacting with Oracle Cloud Infrastructure." uk-tooltip="">resource <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong>. Resources, services, and applications emit metrics to the Monitoring service. Common metrics reflect data related to:</p>
<ul>
<li> Availability and latency</li>
<li>Application uptime and downtime</li>
<li>Completed transactions</li>
<li>Failed and successful operations</li>
<li>Key performance indicators (KPIs), such as sales and engagement quantifiers</li>
</ul>
<p>By querying Monitoring for this data, you can understand how well the systems and processes are working to achieve the service levels you commit to your customers. For example, you can monitor the CPU utilization and disk reads of compute <strong title="A bare metal or virtual machine compute host. The image used to create an instance determines its operating system and other software. The shape specified during the creation process determines the number of CPUs and memory allocated to the instance." uk-tooltip="">instances <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong>. You can then use this data to decide when to provision more instances to handle increased load, troubleshoot issues with the instance, or better understand system behavior. </p>
</div>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title4" class="topic nested3" id="Example_Metric_Failure_Rate">
<h4 class="title topictitle4 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title4">Example Metric: Failure Rate</h4>
<div class="body">
<p>For application health, one of the common KPIs is failure rate, for which a common definition is the number of failed transactions divided by total transactions. This KPI is typically delivered through application monitoring and management software.</p>
<p>As a developer, you can capture this KPI from applications using <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/publishingcustommetrics.htm" title="Publish custom metrics to the Monitoring service." uk-tooltip="">custom metrics</a>. Record observations every time an application transaction takes place and then post that data to the Monitoring service. In this case, set up metrics to capture failed transactions, successful transactions, and transaction latency (time spent per completed transaction).</p>
</div>
</article>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title5" class="topic nested2" id="alarms">
<h3 class="title topictitle3 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title5">Alarms Feature Overview</h3>
<div class="body"><p class="shortdesc">Use alarms to monitor the health, capacity, and performance of cloud resources.</p>
<div uk-lightbox=""><a href="../images/alarms-topic-diagram.svg"><img alt="Resources emit metric data points to Monitoring. When triggered, alarms send messages to the configured destination. For Notifications, messages are sent to subscriptions in the configured topic. For Streaming, messages are sent to the configured stream)." src="../images/alarms-topic-diagram.svg" tabindex="" title="Click to expand"/></a></div>
<p>The Alarms feature of the Monitoring service works with the configured destination service to notify you when metrics meet alarm-specified triggers. The previous illustration depicts the flow, starting with resources emitting metric <a class="xref" href="monitoringoverview.htm#concepts__datapointdefinition">data points</a> to Monitoring. When triggered, an <strong title="The trigger rule and query to evaluate, plus related configuration, such as the notification details to use when the trigger is breached. Alarms passively monitor your cloud resources by using metrics in the Monitoring service." uk-tooltip="">alarm <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong> sends an <a class="xref" href="monitoringoverview.htm#MessageFormat">alarm message</a> to the configured destination. For Notifications, messages are sent to <strong title="An endpoint for a topic, typically a URL or email address. Published messages are sent to each subscription for a topic." uk-tooltip="">subscriptions <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong> in the configured topic. For Streaming, messages are sent to the configured stream. (This illustration doesn't cover raw and aggregated metric data. For these details, see <a class="xref" href="monitoringoverview.htm#top__metrics-alarms-diagram">the "Monitoring Overview" illustration at the top of this page
</a>.)</p>
<p>When configured, repeat notifications remind you of a continued firing state at the configured repeat interval. You're also notified when an alarm transitions back to the OK state, or when an alarm is reset.</p>
</div>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title6" class="topic nested3" id="alarm-eval">
<h4 class="title topictitle4 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title6">Alarm Evaluations</h4>
<div class="body"><p class="shortdesc">
Monitoring evaluates alarms once per minute to find alarm status.</p>
<p>When the alarm <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/split-messages.htm" title="Walk through setting up an alarm to send a message for each metric stream. In this example, you want to be notified whenever a server exceeds a threshold. With this setup, you receive server-specific messages." uk-tooltip="">splits notifications</a>, Monitoring evaluates <em>each tracked metric stream</em>. If the evaluation of that metric stream indicates a new <code class="ph codeph">FIRING</code> status or other <a class="xref" href="monitoringoverview.htm#MessageTypes" title="The message type indicates the reason that the message was sent." uk-tooltip="">qualifying event</a>, then Monitoring sends an alarm message.</p>
<p>
Monitoring tracks metric streams per alarm for <a class="xref" href="monitoringoverview.htm#MessageTypes" title="The message type indicates the reason that the message was sent." uk-tooltip="">qualifying events</a>, but messages are subject to the <a class="xref" href="monitoringoverview.htm#limits-alarm-messages" title="The maximum number of messages per alarm evaluation depends on the alarm destination. Limits are associated with the Oracle Cloud Infrastructure service used for the destination." uk-tooltip="">destination service limits</a>.</p>
</div>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title7" class="topic nested4" id="illustration-eval">
<h5 class="title topictitle5 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title7">Illustration of Alarm Evaluation</h5>
<div class="body">
<p>Consider an alarm that measures the 90th percentile of the metric <code class="ph codeph">CpuUtilization</code>.</p>
<pre class="pre codeblock"><code>{
  "compartmentId": "ocid1.compartment.oc1..exampleuniqueID",
  "destinations": ["ocid1.onstopic.exampleuniqueID"],
  "displayName": "High CPU Utilization",
  "id": "ocid1.alarm.oc1..exampleuniqueID",
  "lifecycleState": "ACTIVE",
  "metricCompartmentId": "ocid1.compartment.oc1..exampleuniqueID",
  "namespace": "oci_computeagent",
  "pendingDuration": "PT3M",
  "query": "CpuUtilization[1m]{availabilityDomain = \"cumS:PHX-AD-1\"}.groupBy(availabilityDomain).percentile(0.9) &gt; 85",
  "repeatNotificationDuration": "PT2H",
  "severity": "WARNING",
  "isEnabled": true,
  "timeCreated": "2023-02-01T01:02:29.600Z",
  "timeUpdated": "2023-02-03T01:02:29.600Z"
}</code></pre>
<p>Notes about this example alarm:</p>
<ul>
<li>The percentile is specified in the query as the <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/create-edit-alarm-query-statistic.htm" title="Select the statistic for an alarm query. The statistic is the aggregation function applied to the set of raw data points at the specified interval." uk-tooltip="">statistic</a> (<strong>bold</strong>):<pre class="pre codeblock"><code>CpuUtilization[1m]{availabilityDomain = \"cumS:PHX-AD-1\"}.groupBy(availabilityDomain).<strong>percentile(0.9)</strong> &gt; 85</code></pre>
</li>
<li>Each data point is the 90th percentile (<code class="ph codeph">percentile(0.9)</code>) of a one-minute window, specified in the query as the <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/create-edit-alarm-query-interval.htm" title="Select the interval, or time window, for querying metric data in an alarm in Monitoring." uk-tooltip="">interval</a> (bold):<pre class="pre codeblock"><code>CpuUtilization[<strong>1m</strong>]{availabilityDomain = \"cumS:PHX-AD-1\"}.groupBy(availabilityDomain).percentile(0.9) &gt; 85</code></pre>
</li>
<li>Data point values for this statistic could be anything from null (absent) to 100.</li>
<li>Data point evaluations: <ul>
<li>For any data point value greater than 85, the evaluation is true (<code class="ph codeph">1</code>). A true evaluation means that the trigger rule condition has been met. </li>
<li>For any data point value that isn't greater than 85, the evaluation is false (<code class="ph codeph">0</code>). </li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>The alarm doesn't fire until the <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/create-edit-alarm-query-trigger-rule.htm" title="Define one or more trigger rules, or predicates, for an alarm. A trigger rule is a condition (defined by the query) that must be satisfied for the alarm to be in the firing state, and also includes severity, trigger delay (pendingDuration), and the alarm body to include in notifications. A condition in a trigger rule can specify a threshold, such as 90% for CPU utilization, or an absence." uk-tooltip="">trigger rule</a> condition is met for three successive minutes. This configuration is the alarm's <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/create-edit-alarm-query-trigger-delay.htm" title="Define the number of minutes that the condition must be maintained before the alarm is in firing state." uk-tooltip="">trigger delay</a> (<code class="ph codeph">pendingDuration</code>), set as <code class="ph codeph">PT3M</code>. </li>
<li>The alarm updates its state to OK when the breaching condition has been clear for the most recent minute.</li>
</ul>
<p>The following image shows an aggregated metric stream for the example alarm. Each data point is indicated by a square.</p>
<br/><img alt="Aggregated metric stream for the example alarm." src="../images/monitoring-alarm-eval.svg"/><br/>
<p>The following table shows consecutive alarm evaluations for the example alarm. The alarm is evaluated on a moving window of three one-minute intervals.</p>
<div class="uk-overflow-auto"><table class="table" summary="Consecutive evaluations of the example alarm."><caption></caption><colgroup><col/><col/><col/><col/></colgroup><thead class="thead">

</tr>
</thead><tbody class="tbody">

<p>*A value of one (1) means that the <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/create-edit-alarm-query-trigger-rule.htm" title="Define one or more trigger rules, or predicates, for an alarm. A trigger rule is a condition (defined by the query) that must be satisfied for the alarm to be in the firing state, and also includes severity, trigger delay (pendingDuration), and the alarm body to include in notifications. A condition in a trigger rule can specify a threshold, such as 90% for CPU utilization, or an absence." uk-tooltip="">trigger rule</a> condition is met.</p>
</div>
</article>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title8" class="topic nested3" id="stream-data-points">
<h4 class="title topictitle4 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title8">How Data Points Are Counted</h4>
<div class="body">
<p>This section describes how to determine the number of <em>data points</em> (or <em>datapoints</em>) retrieved by an alarm. This number can help you estimate <a class="xref" href="https://www.oracle.com/cloud/cloud-native/monitoring/pricing/">Monitoring pricing</a>.</p>
<p>To find the number of data points retrieved by an alarm, first get the <em>number of query streams</em> and <em>minutes analyzed</em>.</p>
<ul>
<li>The <em>number of query streams</em> depends on the metric streams returned by the alarm query.</li>
<li>The <em>minutes analyzed</em> depends on the alarm attributes <code class="ph codeph">interval</code>, <code class="ph codeph">resolution</code>, and <code class="ph codeph">pendingDuration</code>. For alarm queries, the only valid value for <code class="ph codeph">resolution</code> is <code class="ph codeph">1m</code>. For more information about <code class="ph codeph">interval</code>, see <a class="xref" href="../Reference/mql.htm#Interval">Interval</a>. For more information about <code class="ph codeph">resolution</code> and <code class="ph codeph">pendingDuration</code>, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/api/#/en/monitoring/latest/">Monitoring API</a>.</li>
</ul>
<p>Each alarm gets evaluated once every minute, and thus each alarm is evaluated 1440 times per day. Each evaluation queries the data in the time window defined by <code class="ph codeph">interval</code> and it checks the period of time that the alarm persists defined by <code class="ph codeph">pendingDuration</code>. Therefore, <em>minutes analyzed</em> at every minute is calculated by the following expression:</p>
<p>
<em>minutes analyzed</em> at every minute = <code class="ph codeph">interval</code> * ceiling(<code class="ph codeph">pendingDuration</code> / <code class="ph codeph">resolution</code>)</p>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title9" class="topic nested3" id="reset">
<h4 class="title topictitle4 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title9">About the Internal Reset Period</h4>
<div class="body">
<p>The <em>internal reset period</em> determines when an <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/managingalarms.htm" title="Create, update, suppress, and delete alarms. Retrieve alarm history." uk-tooltip="">alarm</a> stops checking for an absent metric that triggered the Firing state in the previous evaluation. When the metric is absent for the entire period, later alarm evaluations ignore the indicated metric stream. If no other metric streams are causing the Firing state for the alarm, then the alarm transitions to OK and sends a <a class="xref" href="monitoringoverview.htm#MessageTypes" title="The message type indicates the reason that the message was sent." uk-tooltip="">RESET message</a>. By default, the RESET message arrives after 13 minutes (internal reset period plus the default slack period of 3 minutes). You can customize the <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/create-edit-alarm-query-slack-period.htm" title="Specify a custom value for the slack period to use when querying metric data in an alarm in Monitoring." uk-tooltip="">slack period</a>.</p>
<p id="reset__internal-reset-period">The length of the internal reset period is globally configured at 10 minutes, which causes the <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/get-alarm-history.htm" title="Get the history of an alarm in Monitoring. Alarm history is retained for 90 days." uk-tooltip="">alarm history</a> to show a 10-minute difference.</p>
<p>The beginning of an internal reset period depends on the alarm type. For <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/create-alarm-threshold.htm" title="Create a threshold alarm in Monitoring to send notifications when a metric meets a specified threshold value." uk-tooltip="">threshold alarms</a>, the internal reset period starts when the first absence is detected. For <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/create-alarm-absence.htm" title="Create an absence alarm in Monitoring to send notifications when a metric doesn't emit data for a specified interval." uk-tooltip="">absence alarms</a>, the internal reset period starts after completion of the <em>absence detection period</em> (default of 2 hours, can be <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/create-edit-alarm-query-absence-detection-period.htm" title="Specify a custom value for the absence detection period to use when querying metric data in an alarm in Monitoring." uk-tooltip="">customized</a>).</p>
<section class="section" id="reset__datapoints"><h5 class="title sectiontitle vl-no-in-page-toc">Data Points Gathered During an Internal Reset Period</h5>
<p>Each evaluation during the ten-minute internal reset period accounts for all data points in that period.</p>
<p>For example, consider a metric stream (<code class="ph codeph">A</code>) that exceeds the threshold (dashed red line in following diagrams). The alarm fires (<code class="ph codeph">F</code>). When a lack of emitted data points is detected, an internal reset period begins.</p>
<p>The following diagram shows a single internal reset period for metric stream <code class="ph codeph">A</code>, from the times <code class="ph codeph">t5</code> to <code class="ph codeph">t15</code>. At time <code class="ph codeph">t16</code>, metric stream <code class="ph codeph">A</code> is no longer evaluated.</p>
<div uk-lightbox=""><a href="../images/monitoring-reset-data-points.svg"><img alt="Diagram depicting a single internal reset period." src="../images/monitoring-reset-data-points.svg" tabindex="" title="Click to expand"/></a></div>
<p>The following diagram shows two internal reset periods for metric stream <code class="ph codeph">A</code>, from the times <code class="ph codeph">t3</code> to <code class="ph codeph">t5</code>, and from <code class="ph codeph">t6</code> to <code class="ph codeph">t16</code>. <code class="ph codeph">A</code> emits a data point at <code class="ph codeph">t6</code>, starting another internal reset period. At time <code class="ph codeph">t17</code>, metric stream <code class="ph codeph">A</code> is no longer evaluated.</p>
<div uk-lightbox=""><a href="../images/monitoring-reset-data-points-emitted.svg"><img alt="Diagram depicting two internal reset periods." src="../images/monitoring-reset-data-points-emitted.svg" tabindex="" title="Click to expand"/></a></div>
</section>
<section class="section" id="reset__threshold"><h5 class="title sectiontitle vl-no-in-page-toc">Threshold Alarm Example</h5>
<p>A <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/create-alarm-threshold.htm" title="Create a threshold alarm in Monitoring to send notifications when a metric meets a specified threshold value." uk-tooltip="">threshold alarm</a> reports on metric streams that occur outside the threshold. When a previously problematic metric stream is absent, the alarm starts the <em>internal reset period</em> for the metric stream.</p>
<p>In this example, four metric streams are evaluated by a threshold alarm. The Console shows the initial Firing (1:30) and Ok (1:51) transition states. The internal reset period occurs while the alarm is in Firing state.</p>
<div uk-lightbox=""><a href="../images/monitoring-reset-threshold.svg"><img alt="Example of a threshold alarm with four metric streams." src="../images/monitoring-reset-threshold.svg" tabindex="" title="Click to expand"/></a></div>
<p>The internal reset period and other significant events in this example are described in the following table.</p>
<div class="uk-overflow-auto"><table class="simpletable frame-all"><colgroup><col style="width:12.5%"/><col style="width:12.5%"/><col style="width:12.5%"/><col style="width:50%"/><col style="width:12.5%"/></colgroup><thead><tr class="sthead">
<th class="stentry" id="reset__threshold__stentry__1" scope="col">Time</th>
<th class="stentry" id="reset__threshold__stentry__2" scope="col">State</th>
<th class="stentry" id="reset__threshold__stentry__3" scope="col">Transition</th>
<th class="stentry" id="reset__threshold__stentry__4" scope="col">Events</th>
<th class="stentry" id="reset__threshold__stentry__5" scope="col">Notifications (see <a class="xref" href="monitoringoverview.htm#MessageTypes" title="The message type indicates the reason that the message was sent." uk-tooltip="">Message Types</a>)</th>
</tr></thead><tbody><tr class="strow">
<td class="stentry" headers="reset__threshold__stentry__1">12:00</td>
<td class="stentry" headers="reset__threshold__stentry__2">
<code class="ph codeph">OK</code>
</td>
<td class="stentry" headers="reset__threshold__stentry__3">
<code class="ph codeph">OK</code>
</td>
<td class="stentry" headers="reset__threshold__stentry__4">All emissions are within threshold.</td>
<td class="stentry" headers="reset__threshold__stentry__5">
<code class="ph codeph">FIRING_TO_OK</code>
</td>
</tr><tr class="strow">
<td class="stentry" headers="reset__threshold__stentry__1">1:30</td>
<td class="stentry" headers="reset__threshold__stentry__2">
<code class="ph codeph">FIRING</code>
</td>
<td class="stentry" headers="reset__threshold__stentry__3">
<code class="ph codeph">FIRING</code>
</td>
<td class="stentry" headers="reset__threshold__stentry__4">Emission from resource1 exceeds threshold.</td>
<td class="stentry" headers="reset__threshold__stentry__5">
<code class="ph codeph">OK_TO_FIRING</code>
</td>
</tr><tr class="strow">
<td class="stentry" headers="reset__threshold__stentry__1">1:35</td>
<td class="stentry" headers="reset__threshold__stentry__2">
<code class="ph codeph">FIRING</code>
</td>
<td class="stentry" headers="reset__threshold__stentry__3">
<code class="ph codeph">--</code>
</td>
<td class="stentry" headers="reset__threshold__stentry__4">No emission is detected for resource1. The alarm starts the internal reset period for resource1.</td>
<td class="stentry" headers="reset__threshold__stentry__5">
<code class="ph codeph">--</code>
</td>
</tr><tr class="strow">
<td class="stentry" headers="reset__threshold__stentry__1">1:38</td>
<td class="stentry" headers="reset__threshold__stentry__2">
<code class="ph codeph">FIRING</code>
</td>
<td class="stentry" headers="reset__threshold__stentry__3">
<code class="ph codeph">--</code>
</td>
<td class="stentry" headers="reset__threshold__stentry__4">No emission is detected for resource2. The alarm starts the internal reset period for resource2.</td>
<td class="stentry" headers="reset__threshold__stentry__5">
<code class="ph codeph">--</code>
</td>
</tr><tr class="strow">
<td class="stentry" headers="reset__threshold__stentry__1">1:45</td>
<td class="stentry" headers="reset__threshold__stentry__2">
<code class="ph codeph">FIRING</code>
</td>
<td class="stentry" headers="reset__threshold__stentry__3">
<code class="ph codeph">--</code>
</td>
<td class="stentry" headers="reset__threshold__stentry__4">The internal reset period ends for resource1, so the alarm no longer checks for emissions from resource1. However, the alarm is still Firing because resource2 is still in its own internal reset period.</td>
<td class="stentry" headers="reset__threshold__stentry__5">
<code class="ph codeph">--</code>
</td>
</tr><tr class="strow">
<td class="stentry" headers="reset__threshold__stentry__1">1:48</td>
<td class="stentry" headers="reset__threshold__stentry__2">
<code class="ph codeph">OK</code>
</td>
<td class="stentry" headers="reset__threshold__stentry__3">
<code class="ph codeph">OK</code>
</td>
<td class="stentry" headers="reset__threshold__stentry__4">The internal reset period ends for resource2, so the alarm no longer checks for emissions from resource2. Emissions from the remaining resources (resource3 and resource4) are within threshold.</td>
<td class="stentry" headers="reset__threshold__stentry__5">
<code class="ph codeph">RESET</code> (sent after the three-minute slack period, at about 1:51)</td>
</tr></tbody></table></div>
</section>
<section class="section" id="reset__absent"><h5 class="title sectiontitle vl-no-in-page-toc">Absence Alarm Example</h5>
<p>An <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/create-alarm-absence.htm" title="Create an absence alarm in Monitoring to send notifications when a metric doesn't emit data for a specified interval." uk-tooltip="">absence alarm</a> reports on absent metric streams. When a metric stream is absent, the alarm starts the <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/create-edit-alarm-query-absence-detection-period.htm" title="Specify a custom value for the absence detection period to use when querying metric data in an alarm in Monitoring." uk-tooltip="">
<em>absence detection period</em>
</a> for the metric stream (default of two hours, can be customized). After completion of the absence detection period, the alarm starts the <em>internal reset period</em> for the metric stream. </p>
<p>In this example, a metric stream is evaluated by an absence alarm that uses the default two-hour <em>absence detection period</em> and default three-minute <em>slack period</em>. The Console shows the initial Firing (2:00) and Ok (4:10) transition states. The internal reset period occurs while the alarm is in Firing state.</p>
<div uk-lightbox=""><a href="../images/monitoring-reset-absent.svg"><img alt="Example of an absence alarm with a single metric stream." src="../images/monitoring-reset-absent.svg" tabindex="" title="Click to expand"/></a></div>
<p>The internal reset period and other significant events in this example are described in the following table.</p>
<div class="uk-overflow-auto"><table class="simpletable frame-all"><colgroup><col style="width:12.5%"/><col style="width:12.5%"/><col style="width:12.5%"/><col style="width:50%"/><col style="width:12.5%"/></colgroup><thead><tr class="sthead">
<th class="stentry" id="reset__absent__stentry__1" scope="col">Time</th>
<th class="stentry" id="reset__absent__stentry__2" scope="col">State</th>
<th class="stentry" id="reset__absent__stentry__3" scope="col">Transition</th>
<th class="stentry" id="reset__absent__stentry__4" scope="col">Events</th>
<th class="stentry" id="reset__absent__stentry__5" scope="col">Notifications (see <a class="xref" href="monitoringoverview.htm#MessageTypes" title="The message type indicates the reason that the message was sent." uk-tooltip="">Message Types</a>)</th>
</tr></thead><tbody><tr class="strow">
<td class="stentry" headers="reset__absent__stentry__1">1:00</td>
<td class="stentry" headers="reset__absent__stentry__2">
<code class="ph codeph">OK</code>
</td>
<td class="stentry" headers="reset__absent__stentry__3">--</td>
<td class="stentry" headers="reset__absent__stentry__4">Emissions are detected.</td>
<td class="stentry" headers="reset__absent__stentry__5"></td>
</tr><tr class="strow">
<td class="stentry" headers="reset__absent__stentry__1">2:00</td>
<td class="stentry" headers="reset__absent__stentry__2">
<code class="ph codeph">FIRING</code>
</td>
<td class="stentry" headers="reset__absent__stentry__3">
<code class="ph codeph">FIRING</code>
</td>
<td class="stentry" headers="reset__absent__stentry__4">No emission is detected for resource-z. The alarm starts the absence detection period for resource-z.</td>
<td class="stentry" headers="reset__absent__stentry__5">
<code class="ph codeph">OK_TO_FIRING</code>
</td>
</tr><tr class="strow">
<td class="stentry" headers="reset__absent__stentry__1">4:00</td>
<td class="stentry" headers="reset__absent__stentry__2">
<code class="ph codeph">FIRING</code>
</td>
<td class="stentry" headers="reset__absent__stentry__3">
<code class="ph codeph">--</code>
</td>
<td class="stentry" headers="reset__absent__stentry__4">The absence detection period for resource-z ends. The alarm starts the internal reset period for resource-z.</td>
<td class="stentry" headers="reset__absent__stentry__5">
<code class="ph codeph">--</code>
</td>
</tr><tr class="strow">
<td class="stentry" headers="reset__absent__stentry__1">4:10</td>
<td class="stentry" headers="reset__absent__stentry__2">
<code class="ph codeph">OK</code>
</td>
<td class="stentry" headers="reset__absent__stentry__3">
<code class="ph codeph">OK</code>
</td>
<td class="stentry" headers="reset__absent__stentry__4">The internal reset period ends for resource-z, so the alarm no longer checks for emissions from resource-z. No metric streams are monitored by the alarm any more, so the alarm transitions to Ok state.</td>
<td class="stentry" headers="reset__absent__stentry__5">
<code class="ph codeph">RESET</code> (sent after the three-minute slack period, at about 4:13)</td>
</tr></tbody></table></div>
</section>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title10" class="topic nested3" id="alarm-update-timing">
<h4 class="title topictitle4 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title10">Time Needed to Reflect Alarm Updates</h4>
<div class="body"><p class="shortdesc">Updates to alarms take up to five minutes to be reflected everywhere.</p>
<p>For example, if you update an alarm to <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/split-messages.htm" title="Walk through setting up an alarm to send a message for each metric stream. In this example, you want to be notified whenever a server exceeds a threshold. With this setup, you receive server-specific messages." uk-tooltip="">split notifications</a>, then it might take up to five minutes for <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/list-alarm-status-metric-stream.htm" title="List the status of each metric stream in an alarm in Monitoring. A metric stream corresponds to a set of dimension key-value pairs." uk-tooltip="">metric stream status</a> to be populated in the Console.</p>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title11" class="topic nested3" id="search-alarms">
