<div class="uk-margin-top" uk-accordion=""><div class="vl-include-in-page-toc" id="MessageTypes"><a class="uk-accordion-title vl-include-in-page-toc-h3" href="#" id="ariaid-title12">Message Types</a><div class="uk-accordion-content"><div aria-labelledby="ariaid-title12" class="topic nested2">
<div class="body"><p class="shortdesc">The message type indicates the reason that the message was sent.</p>
<div class="uk-alert uk-alert-primary"><span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="file-edit"></span><strong> Note</strong><br/><br/>
<p>The specified message type is sent at the indicated time plus the alarm's configured trigger delay, if any.</p>
<p>Repeat messages are also sent if configured in the alarm.</p>
</div>
<p>The following table lists the alarm state and transition for each message type.</p>
<div class="uk-overflow-auto"><table class="simpletable frame-all"><colgroup><col style="width:14.285714285714285%"/><col style="width:14.285714285714285%"/><col style="width:14.285714285714285%"/><col style="width:57.14285714285714%"/></colgroup><thead><tr class="sthead">
<th class="stentry" id="MessageTypes__stentry__1" scope="col">Message type</th>
<th class="stentry" id="MessageTypes__stentry__2" scope="col">State</th>
<th class="stentry" id="MessageTypes__stentry__3" scope="col">Transition</th>
<th class="stentry" id="MessageTypes__stentry__4" scope="col">Comments</th>
</tr></thead><tbody><tr class="strow">
<td class="stentry" headers="MessageTypes__stentry__1">
<code class="ph codeph">OK_TO_FIRING</code>
</td>
<td class="stentry" headers="MessageTypes__stentry__2">
<code class="ph codeph">FIRING</code>
</td>
<td class="stentry" headers="MessageTypes__stentry__3">from <code class="ph codeph">OK</code> to <code class="ph codeph">FIRING</code>
</td>
<td class="stentry" headers="MessageTypes__stentry__4"></td>
</tr><tr class="strow">
<td class="stentry" headers="MessageTypes__stentry__1">
<code class="ph codeph">FIRING_TO_OK</code>
</td>
<td class="stentry" headers="MessageTypes__stentry__2">
<code class="ph codeph">OK</code>
</td>
<td class="stentry" headers="MessageTypes__stentry__3">from <code class="ph codeph">FIRING</code> to <code class="ph codeph">OK</code>
</td>
<td class="stentry" headers="MessageTypes__stentry__4"></td>
</tr><tr class="strow">
<td class="stentry" headers="MessageTypes__stentry__1">
<code class="ph codeph">REPEAT</code>
</td>
<td class="stentry" headers="MessageTypes__stentry__2">
<code class="ph codeph">FIRING</code>
</td>
<td class="stentry" headers="MessageTypes__stentry__3">--</td>
<td class="stentry" headers="MessageTypes__stentry__4">This message type is sent when the alarm maintains the <code class="ph codeph">FIRING</code> state, and the alarm is configured for repeat notifications.</td>
</tr><tr class="strow">
<td class="stentry" headers="MessageTypes__stentry__1">
<code class="ph codeph">RESET</code>
</td>
<td class="stentry" headers="MessageTypes__stentry__2">
<code class="ph codeph">OK</code>
</td>
<td class="stentry" headers="MessageTypes__stentry__3">from <code class="ph codeph">FIRING</code> to <code class="ph codeph">OK</code>
</td>
<td class="stentry" headers="MessageTypes__stentry__4">
<p>
<strong>Important: </strong>When a <code class="ph codeph">RESET</code> status change occurs, look at the health of the resource.</p>
<p>This message type is sent when the alarm transitions to the <code class="ph codeph">OK</code> state after one or more <em>internal resets</em>. An internal reset occurs when a metric stream that caused the alarm to transition to the <code class="ph codeph">FIRING</code> state is continuously absent for the full <a class="xref" href="monitoringoverview.htm#reset">internal reset period</a>. A metric stream that's internally reset is no longer tracked by the alarm.</p>
<p> Possible causes for an absent metric stream: The resource that was emitting the metric might have been moved or terminated, or the metric might be emitted only on failure. For more information about the internal reset period, see <a class="xref" href="monitoringoverview.htm#reset">About the Internal Reset Period</a>.</p>
</td>
</tr></tbody></table></div>
</div>
</div></div></div></div>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title13" class="topic nested2" id="MessageFormat">
<h3 class="title topictitle3 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title13">Message Format and Examples</h3>
<div class="body">
<p>See <a class="xref" href="../alarm-message-examples.htm" title="View examples of alarm messages sent by Monitoring." uk-tooltip="">Example Alarm Messages</a> and <a class="xref" href="../alarm-message-format.htm" title="Look up parameters that appear in alarm messages sent by Monitoring. Review parameter descriptions and example values, dynamic variables, and default appearance in formatted messages." uk-tooltip="">Alarm Message Format</a>.</p>
</div>
</article>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title14" class="topic nested1" id="concepts">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title14">Monitoring Concepts</h2>
<div class="body">
<p>The following concepts are essential to working with Monitoring. </p>
<dl>
<dt class="dt dlterm" id="concepts__aggregateddatadefinition2">aggregated data</dt>
<dd class="dd">The result of applying a <em>statistic</em> and <em>interval</em> to a selection of raw <em>data points</em> for a <em>metric</em>. For example, you can apply the <em>statistic</em>
<code class="ph codeph">max</code> and <em>interval</em>
<code class="ph codeph">1h</code> (one hour) to the last 24 hours of raw <em>data points</em> for the <em>metric</em>
<code class="ph codeph">CpuUtilization</code>. Aggregated data is displayed in default metric charts in the Console. You can also build metric queries for specific sets of aggregated data. For instructions, see <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/viewingcharts.htm" title="View metric charts that use predefined service queries. Default metric charts are available on the Service Metrics page and resource details pages in the Console." uk-tooltip="">Viewing Default Metric Charts</a> and <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/buildingqueries.htm" title="View custom metric charts, list metric definitions, and query metric data for resources of interest." uk-tooltip="">Building Metric Queries</a>.</dd>
<dt class="dt dlterm" id="concepts__alarmdefinition2">alarm</dt>
<dd class="dd">The <em>alarm query</em> to evaluate and the <em>notification destination</em> to use when the alarm is in the firing state, along with other alarm properties.</dd>
<dd class="dd ddexpand">To create an alarm, see <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/create-alarm-basic.htm" title="Create a basic alarm in Monitoring to notify you when metrics meet specified triggers." uk-tooltip="">Creating a Basic Alarm</a>.</dd>
<dt class="dt dlterm" id="concepts__alarmquerydefinition">alarm query</dt>
<dd class="dd"> The Monitoring Query Language (MQL) expression to evaluate for the <em>alarm</em>. An alarm query must specify a <em>metric</em>, <em>statistic</em>, <em>interval</em>, and a <em>trigger rule</em> (threshold or absence). The Alarms feature of the Monitoring service interprets results for each returned time series as a Boolean value, where zero represents false and a nonzero value represents true. A true value means that the <em>trigger rule</em> condition has been met.</dd>
<dd class="dd ddexpand">To create a basic alarm query, see <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/create-alarm-chart-basic-query.htm" title="Generate a metric chart on the Create Alarm page in the Console by creating a basic alarm query." uk-tooltip="">Creating a Basic Query to Generate an Alarm Metric Chart</a>. To create an alarm, see <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/create-alarm-basic.htm" title="Create a basic alarm in Monitoring to notify you when metrics meet specified triggers." uk-tooltip="">Creating a Basic Alarm</a>.</dd>
<dt class="dt dlterm" id="concepts__datapointdefinition">data point</dt>
<dd class="dd">A timestamp-value pair for the specified <em>metric</em>. Example: <code class="ph codeph">2022-05-10T22:19:00Z, 10.4</code>
</dd>
<dd class="dd ddexpand">A data point is either raw or aggregated. Raw data points are posted by the <em>metric namespace</em> to the Monitoring service using the <a class="xref" href="/iaas/api/#/en/monitoring/latest/MetricData/PostMetricData">PostMetricData</a> operation. The <em>frequency</em> of the data points posted varies by <em>metric namespace</em>. For example, a custom namespace might send data points for a <em>metric </em>at a 20-second <em>frequency</em>. </dd>
<dd class="dd ddexpand">Aggregated data points are the result of applying a <em>statistic</em> and <em>interval</em> to raw data points. The <em>interval</em> of the aggregated data points is specified in the <a class="xref" href="/iaas/api/#/en/monitoring/latest/MetricData/SummarizeMetricsData">SummarizeMetricsData</a> request. For example, a request specifying the <em>statistic</em>
<code class="ph codeph">sum</code> and <em>interval</em>
<code class="ph codeph">1h</code> (one hour) returns a <code class="ph codeph">sum</code> value for each hour of available raw data points for the <em>metric</em>. </dd>
<dt class="dt dlterm" id="concepts__dimensiondefinition">dimension</dt>
<dd class="dd">A qualifier provided in a <em>metric definition</em>. Example: Resource identifier (<code class="ph codeph">resourceId</code>), provided in the definitions of oci_computeagent metrics. Use dimensions to filter or group metric data. Example dimension name-value pair for filtering by availability domain: <code class="ph codeph">availabilityDomain = "VeBZ:PHX-AD-1"</code>
</dd>
<dd class="dd ddexpand">To select a dimension for a metric chart or query, see <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/view-chart-dimensions.htm" title="Use dimensions to filter the data plotted that's plotted on default metric charts on the Service Metrics page in the Console. For example, filter results to a particular resource or fault domain. Available dimensions vary by metric." uk-tooltip="">Selecting Dimensions to Filter Metrics</a> and <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/query-metric-dimension.htm" title="Limit returned metric data by selecting dimensions when querying metric data in Monitoring. A dimension is a qualifier provided in a metric definition. In MQL, the dimension selection component specifies name-value pairs for dimensions, surrounded by curly brackets." uk-tooltip="">Selecting Dimensions for a Query</a>.</dd>
<dd class="dd ddexpand">To select an interval for an alarm, see <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/create-edit-alarm-query-interval.htm" title="Select the interval, or time window, for querying metric data in an alarm in Monitoring." uk-tooltip="">Selecting the Interval for an Alarm Query</a>.</dd>
<dt class="dt dlterm" id="concepts__frequencydefinition2">frequency</dt>
<dd class="dd">The time period between each posted raw <em>data point</em> for a <em>metric</em>. (Raw data points are posted by the <em>metric namespace</em> to the Monitoring service.) While frequency varies by metric, default service metrics typically have a frequency of 60 seconds (one data point posted per minute). See also <em>
<a class="xref" href="monitoringoverview.htm#concepts__resolutiondefinition">resolution</a>
</em>.</dd>
<dt class="dt dlterm" id="concepts__intervaldefinition">interval</dt>
<dd class="dd">
The time window used to convert the set of raw <em>data points</em>.
</dd>
<dd class="dd ddexpand">
The timestamp of the aggregated data point corresponds to the end of the time window during which raw data points are assessed. For example, for a five-minute interval, the timestamp "2:05" corresponds to the five-minute time window from 2:00:<em>n</em> to 2:05:00.
</dd>
<dd class="dd ddexpand">
<div uk-lightbox=""><a href="../../libraries/global-block-libraries/../../Monitoring/images/monitoringMetricInterval.svg"><img alt="This image shows how the timestamp of an aggregated data point corresponds to the interval." src="../../libraries/global-block-libraries/../../Monitoring/images/monitoringMetricInterval.svg" tabindex="" title="Click to expand"/></a></div>
</dd>
<dd class="dd ddexpand">
The following example query (MQL expression) specifies a 5-minute interval.
For valid interval options in MQL expressions, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Monitoring/Reference/mql.htm#Interval">Interval (Monitoring Query Language (MQL) Reference)</a>.
</dd>
<dd class="dd ddexpand">
<pre class="pre codeblock"><code>CpuUtilization[5m].max()</code></pre>
</dd>
<dd class="dd ddexpand">
<div class="uk-alert uk-alert-primary"><span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="file-edit"></span><strong> Note</strong><br/><br/>
Supported values for interval depend on the specified time range in the metric query (not applicable to alarm queries). More interval values are supported for smaller time ranges. For example, if you select one hour for the time range, then all interval values are supported. If you select 90 days for the time range, then only interval values between 1 hour and 1 day are supported.
</div>
</dd>
<dd class="dd ddexpand">To select an interval for a metric chart or query, see <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/view-chart-interval.htm" title="Change the time window for aggregating metric data points plotted on a default metric chart. Default metric charts are available on the Service Metrics page and resource details pages in the Console." uk-tooltip="">Changing the Interval for a Default Metric Chart</a> and <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/query-metric-interval.htm" title="Select the interval, or time window, for querying metric data in Monitoring." uk-tooltip="">Selecting the Interval for a Query</a>.</dd>
<dd class="dd ddexpand">To select an interval for an alarm, see <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/create-edit-alarm-query-interval.htm" title="Select the interval, or time window, for querying metric data in an alarm in Monitoring." uk-tooltip="">Selecting the Interval for an Alarm Query</a>.</dd>
<dd class="dd ddexpand">See also <em>resolution</em>.</dd>
<dt class="dt dlterm" id="concepts__messagedefinition2">message</dt>
<dd class="dd">The content that the Alarms feature of the Monitoring service publishes to topics in the <em>alarm's</em> configured <em>notification destinations</em>. A message is sent when the <em>alarm</em> transitions to another state, such as from <code class="ph codeph">OK</code> to <code class="ph codeph">FIRING</code>.</dd>
<dd class="dd ddexpand">For more information about alarm messages, see <a class="xref" href="monitoringoverview.htm#MessageFormat">Message Format and Examples</a>.</dd>
<dt class="dt dlterm" id="concepts__metadatadefinition2">metadata</dt>
<dd class="dd">A reference provided in a <em>metric definition</em>. Example: unit (bytes), provided in the definition of the oci_computeagent <em>metric</em>
<code class="ph codeph">DiskBytesRead</code>. Use metadata to determine additional information about a metric. For metric definitions, see <a class="xref" href="monitoringoverview.htm#SupportedServices">Supported Services</a>.</dd>
<dt class="dt dlterm" id="concepts__metricdefinition2">metric</dt>
<dd class="dd">A measurement related to health, capacity, or performance of a resource. Example: The <code class="ph codeph">oci_computeagent</code>
<em>metric</em>
<code class="ph codeph">CpuUtilization</code>, which measures usage of a compute instance. For metric definitions, see <a class="xref" href="monitoringoverview.htm#SupportedServices">Supported Services</a>. </dd>
<dd class="dd ddexpand">
<div class="uk-alert uk-alert-primary"><span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="file-edit"></span><strong> Note</strong><br/><br/> Metric resources don't have <strong title="An Oracle-assigned unique ID for a cloud resource. This ID is included as part of the resource's information in both the Console and API." uk-tooltip="">OCIDs <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong>.</div>
</dd>
<dt class="dt dlterm" id="concepts__metricdefinitiondefinition2">metric definition</dt>
<dd class="dd">A set of references, qualifiers, and other information provided by a <em>metric namespace</em> for a <em>metric</em>. For example, the oci_computeagent <em>metric</em>
<code class="ph codeph">DiskBytesRead</code> is defined by <em>dimensions</em> (such as resource identifier) and <em>metadata</em> (specifying bytes for unit) as well as identification of its <em>metric namespace</em> (oci_computeagent). Each posted set of <em>data points</em> carries this information. Use the <a class="xref" href="/iaas/api/#/en/monitoring/latest/Metric/ListMetrics">ListMetricData</a> API operation to get metric definitions. For metric definitions, see <a class="xref" href="monitoringoverview.htm#SupportedServices">Supported Services</a>.</dd>
<dd class="dd ddexpand">To select a metric name for a query, see <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/query-metric-metric.htm" title="Select the name of the metric for querying metric data in Monitoring." uk-tooltip="">Selecting the Metric Name for a Query</a>.</dd>
<dd class="dd ddexpand">To select a metric name for an alarm, see <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/create-alarm-chart-basic-query.htm" title="Generate a metric chart on the Create Alarm page in the Console by creating a basic alarm query." uk-tooltip="">Creating a Basic Query to Generate an Alarm Metric Chart</a> and <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/create-alarm-basic.htm" title="Create a basic alarm in Monitoring to notify you when metrics meet specified triggers." uk-tooltip="">Creating a Basic Alarm</a>.</dd>
<dt class="dt dlterm" id="concepts__metricnamespacedefinition2">metric namespace</dt>
<dd class="dd">Indicator of the <strong title="The cloud objects that you create and use when interacting with Oracle Cloud Infrastructure." uk-tooltip="">resource <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong>, service, or application that emits the <em>metric</em>. Provided in the <em>metric definition</em>. For example, the <code class="ph codeph">CpuUtilization</code>
<em>metric definition</em> emitted by the Oracle Cloud Agent software on compute <strong title="A bare metal or virtual machine compute host. The image used to create an instance determines its operating system and other software. The shape specified during the creation process determines the number of CPUs and memory allocated to the instance." uk-tooltip="">instances <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong> lists the <em>metric namespace</em>
<code class="ph codeph">oci_computeagent</code> as the source of the <code class="ph codeph">CpuUtilization</code>
<em>metric</em>. For metric definitions, see <a class="xref" href="monitoringoverview.htm#SupportedServices">Supported Services</a>.</dd>
<dd class="dd ddexpand">To select a metric namespace for a metric chart or query, see <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/view-chart-namespace.htm" title="Go to the Service Metrics page in the Console to view metric charts that use predefined service queries for a selected metric namespace. The charts show metric data for all resources in the selected metric namespace, compartment, and region." uk-tooltip="">Viewing Default Metric Charts for a Metric Namespace (Multiple Resources)</a> and <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/query-metric-namespace.htm" title="Select the metric namespace for querying metric data in Monitoring." uk-tooltip="">Selecting the Metric Namespace for a Query</a>.</dd>
<dd class="dd ddexpand">To select a metric namespace for an alarm, see <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/create-alarm-chart-basic-query.htm" title="Generate a metric chart on the Create Alarm page in the Console by creating a basic alarm query." uk-tooltip="">Creating a Basic Query to Generate an Alarm Metric Chart</a> and <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/create-alarm-basic.htm" title="Create a basic alarm in Monitoring to notify you when metrics meet specified triggers." uk-tooltip="">Creating a Basic Alarm</a>.</dd>
<dt class="dt dlterm" id="concepts__metricstreamdefinition">metric stream</dt>
<dd class="dd">An individual set of <em>aggregated data</em> for a <em>metric and zero or more dimension values</em>.</dd>
<dd class="dd ddexpand">In <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/list-alarm-status-metric-stream.htm" title="List the status of each metric stream in an alarm in Monitoring. A metric stream corresponds to a set of dimension key-value pairs." uk-tooltip="">the Metric streams status page</a>, each metric stream corresponds to a set of dimension key-value pairs.</dd>
<dd class="dd ddexpand">In <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/viewingcharts.htm" title="View metric charts that use predefined service queries. Default metric charts are available on the Service Metrics page and resource details pages in the Console." uk-tooltip="">metric charts</a> (in the Console), each metric stream is depicted as a line (unless you <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/view-chart-aggregate-metric-streams.htm" title="Aggregate metric streams in default metric charts on the Service Metrics page in the Console." uk-tooltip="">aggregate all metric streams</a>).</dd>
<dd class="dd ddexpand">The following image depicts metric streams in a chart. Each line in the chart corresponds to a metric stream.<div uk-lightbox=""><a href="../images/metric-streams.png"><img alt="This image depicts metric streams in a chart. Each line in the chart corresponds to a metric stream." src="../images/metric-streams.png" tabindex="" title="Click to expand"/></a></div>
</dd>
<dd class="dd ddexpand">For example, consider a compartment containing three compute instances in the <code class="ph codeph">AD-1</code> availability domain (including two in the <code class="ph codeph">ipexample</code> instance pool) and a fourth instance in the <code class="ph codeph">AD-2</code> availability domain. In this example, the CPU Utilization metric chart shows four lines (one per instance). When <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/view-chart-dimensions.htm" title="Use dimensions to filter the data plotted that's plotted on default metric charts on the Service Metrics page in the Console. For example, filter results to a particular resource or fault domain. Available dimensions vary by metric." uk-tooltip="">filtered</a> by the <code class="ph codeph">AD-1</code> availability domain, the chart shows three lines. When further filtered by the <code class="ph codeph">ipexample</code> instance pool, the chart shows two lines.</dd>
<dd class="dd ddexpand">To select metric streams in a query, see <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/view-chart-dimensions.htm" title="Use dimensions to filter the data plotted that's plotted on default metric charts on the Service Metrics page in the Console. For example, filter results to a particular resource or fault domain. Available dimensions vary by metric." uk-tooltip="">Selecting Dimensions to Filter Metrics</a>, <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/query-metric-dimension.htm" title="Limit returned metric data by selecting dimensions when querying metric data in Monitoring. A dimension is a qualifier provided in a metric definition. In MQL, the dimension selection component specifies name-value pairs for dimensions, surrounded by curly brackets." uk-tooltip="">Selecting Dimensions for a Query</a>, and <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/create-edit-alarm-query-dimensions.htm" title="Limit the metric data that's returned by selecting dimensions for an alarm in Monitoring. A dimension is a qualifier provided in a metric definition. In MQL, the dimension selection component specifies name-value pairs for dimensions, surrounded by curly brackets." uk-tooltip="">Selecting Dimensions for an Alarm Query</a>.</dd>
<dd class="dd ddexpand">To set up an alarm for notifications per metric stream, see <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/create-alarm-split.htm" title="Create an alarm in Monitoring that sends a separate alarm message for each metric stream." uk-tooltip="">Creating an Alarm That Splits Messages by Metric Stream</a> and <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/split-messages.htm" title="Walk through setting up an alarm to send a message for each metric stream. In this example, you want to be notified whenever a server exceeds a threshold. With this setup, you receive server-specific messages." uk-tooltip="">Scenario: Split Messages by Metric Stream</a>.</dd>
<dt class="dt dlterm" id="concepts__notificationdestinationdefinition2">notification destination</dt>
<dd class="dd">Details for sending <em>messages</em> when the <em>alarm</em> transitions to another state, such as from <code class="ph codeph">OK</code> to <code class="ph codeph">FIRING</code>. The details and setup might vary by destination service. Available destination services include Notifications and Streaming.</dd>
<dd class="dd ddexpand">For the Notifications service, specify a <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Notification/Concepts/notificationoverview.htm#concepts__topicdefinition">topic</a>. (If you're creating the topic for the alarm, also specify one or more <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Notification/Concepts/notificationoverview.htm#concepts__subscriptiondefinition">subscription</a> protocols (such as PagerDuty).</dd>
<dd class="dd ddexpand">For the Streaming service, specify a <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Streaming/Concepts/streamingoverview.htm#concepts">stream</a>.</dd>
<dd class="dd ddexpand">For examples of alarm messages sent to topics and streams, see <a class="xref" href="../alarm-message-examples.htm" title="View examples of alarm messages sent by Monitoring." uk-tooltip="">Example Alarm Messages</a>.</dd>
<dd class="dd ddexpand">To set up a notification destination in an alarm, see <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/create-edit-alarm-notification.htm" title="Select the topic or stream to send alarm notifications to. Group or split notifications, format messages, and choose whether to repeat notifications." uk-tooltip="">Defining Notifications for an Alarm</a>.</dd>
<dt class="dt dlterm" id="concepts__oraclecloudagentsoftwaredefinition2">
Oracle Cloud Agent software</dt>
<dd class="dd">Software used by a compute instance to post raw <em>data points</em> to the Monitoring service. Automatically installed with the latest versions of supported images. See <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Compute/Tasks/enablingmonitoring.htm">Enabling Monitoring for Compute Instances</a>. </dd>
<dt class="dt dlterm" id="concepts__querydefinition">query</dt>
<dd class="dd">The Monitoring Query Language (MQL) expression and associated information (such as metric namespace) to evaluate for returning <em>aggregated data</em>. The query must specify a <em>metric</em>, <em>statistic</em>, and <em>interval</em>.</dd>
<dd class="dd ddexpand">To create a metric query, see <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/query-metric.htm" title="Define a query to retrieve data from Monitoring." uk-tooltip="">Creating a Query</a>.</dd>
<dd class="dd ddexpand">To create an alarm query, see <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/create-alarm-chart-basic-query.htm" title="Generate a metric chart on the Create Alarm page in the Console by creating a basic alarm query." uk-tooltip="">Creating a Basic Query to Generate an Alarm Metric Chart</a>.</dd>
<dt class="dt dlterm" id="concepts__resolutiondefinition">resolution</dt>
<dd class="dd">
<div>
<p><span id="concepts__ph_resolution-definition">The period between time windows, or the regularity at which time windows shift. For example, use a resolution of <code class="ph codeph">1m</code> to retrieve aggregations every minute.</span></p>
<div class="uk-alert uk-alert-primary"><span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="file-edit"></span><strong> Note</strong><br/><br/> For metric queries, the <strong title="The time window used to convert a given set of raw data points—for example, 5 minutes." uk-tooltip="">interval <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong> you select drives the default <strong title="The period between time windows, or the regularity at which time windows shift—for example, 1 minute." uk-tooltip="">resolution <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong> of the request, which determines the maximum time range of data returned.<div>
<p>For alarm queries, the specified <strong title="The time window used to convert a given set of raw data points—for example, 5 minutes." uk-tooltip="">interval <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong> has no effect on the <strong title="The period between time windows, or the regularity at which time windows shift—for example, 1 minute." uk-tooltip="">resolution <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong> of the request. <span id="concepts__ph_resolution-alarm-valid">The only valid value of the resolution for an alarm query request is <code class="ph codeph">1m</code>.</span>
<span id="concepts__ph_resolution-alarm-link">For more information about the resolution parameter as used in alarm queries, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/api/#/en/monitoring/latest/Alarm">Alarm</a>.</span></p>
</div></div>
<div id="concepts__div_resolution-image-and-expl"><p><span id="concepts__ph_resolution-image-expl">As shown in the following illustration, <em>resolution</em> controls the start time of each aggregation window relative to the previous window while <em>interval</em> controls the length of the windows. Both requests apply the statistic <code class="ph codeph">max</code> to the data within each five-minute window (from the interval), resulting in a single aggregated <em>data point</em> representing the highest <code class="ph codeph">CPUutilization</code> counter for that window. Only the resolution value differs. This resolution changes the regularity at which the aggregation windows shift, or the start times of successive aggregation windows. Request A doesn't specify a resolution and thus uses the default value equal to the interval (5 minutes). This request's five-minute aggregation windows are thus taken from the sets of data points emitted from 0:<em>n</em> to 5:00, 5:<em>n</em> to 10:00, and so forth. Request B specifies a 1-minute resolution, so its five-minute aggregation windows are taken from the set of data points emitted every minute from 0:<em>n</em> to 5:00, 1:<em>n</em> to 6:00, and so forth.</span></p><div uk-lightbox=""><a href="../images/monitoringMetricResolution.png"><img alt="This image shows how aggregation windows start according to the resolution." id="concepts__image_resolution" src="../images/monitoringMetricResolution.png" tabindex="" title="Click to expand"/></a></div></div>
<p><span id="concepts__ph_resolution-api">To specify a nondefault resolution that differs from the interval, see <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/query-metric-resolution.htm" title="Specify a nondefault value for resolution for querying metric data in Monitoring." uk-tooltip="">Selecting a Nondefault Resolution for a Query</a> and <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/create-alarm.htm" title="Create an alarm in Monitoring to notify you when metrics meet specified triggers." uk-tooltip="">Creating an Alarm</a>.</span></p>
</div>
</dd>
<dt class="dt dlterm" id="concepts__resourcegroupdefinition">resource group</dt>
<dd class="dd"> A custom string provided with a custom metric that can be used as a filter or to aggregate results. The resource group must exist in the definition of the posted metric. Only one resource group can be applied per metric.
          </dd>
<dd class="dd ddexpand">To select a resource group in a query, see <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/query-metric-resource-group.htm" title="Limit returned metric data by matching a resource group when querying custom metric data in Monitoring." uk-tooltip="">Selecting a Resource Group in a Query</a>.</dd>
<dd class="dd ddexpand">To select a resource group in an alarm query, see <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/create-edit-alarm-query-resource-group.htm" title="Limit returned metric data by matching a resource group when querying custom metric data for an alarm in Monitoring." uk-tooltip="">Selecting a Resource Group in an Alarm Query</a>.</dd>
<dt class="dt dlterm" id="concepts__statisticdefinition2">statistic</dt>
<dd class="dd">The aggregation function applied to the set of raw <em>data points</em>.</dd>
<dd class="dd ddexpand">To select the statistic for a metric chart or query, see <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/view-chart-statistic.htm" title="Change the query's statistic used for aggregating data plotted on a default metric chart. Default metric charts are available on the Service Metrics page and resource details pages in the Console." uk-tooltip="">Changing the Statistic for a Default Metric Chart</a> and <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/query-metric-statistic.htm" title="Select the statistic for querying metric data in Monitoring. The statistic is the aggregation function applied to the set of raw data points at the specified interval." uk-tooltip="">Selecting the Statistic for a Query</a>.</dd>
<dd class="dd ddexpand">To select the statistic for an alarm query, see <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/create-edit-alarm-query-statistic.htm" title="Select the statistic for an alarm query. The statistic is the aggregation function applied to the set of raw data points at the specified interval." uk-tooltip="">Selecting the Statistic for an Alarm Query</a>.</dd>
<dt class="dt dlterm" id="concepts__suppressiondefinition2">suppression</dt>
<dd class="dd">
A configuration to stop publishing <em>messages</em> during the specified time range. Useful for suspending alarm notifications during system maintenance.
</dd>
<dd class="dd ddexpand">To suppress alarms, see <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/create-alarm-suppression.htm" title="Temporarily stop notifications from an alarm by applying a suppression. For example, use a suppression to suspend alarm notifications during system maintenance." uk-tooltip="">Suppressing a Single Alarm</a> and <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/create-alarm-suppression-multiple.htm" title="Temporarily stop notifications from alarms by applying a suppression to selected alarms in the Console. For example, use a suppression to suspend notifications from selected alarms." uk-tooltip="">Suppressing Multiple Alarms</a>.</dd>
<dt class="dt dlterm" id="concepts__time-range-definition">time range</dt>
<dd class="dd">The bounds (timestamps) of the metric data that you want. For example, the past hour.</dd>
<dd class="dd ddexpand">To select the time range for a metric chart or query, see <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/view-chart-time-range.htm" title="Set the bounds, or timestamps, of the metric data that you want for default metric charts. By default, charts show the last hour of metric data. Default metric charts are available on the Service Metrics page and resource details pages in the Console." uk-tooltip="">Changing the Time Range for Default Metric Charts</a>, <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/metrics-explorer-time-range.htm" title="Set the bounds, or timestamps, of the metric data that you want for the metric chart on the Metrics Explorer page in the Console. By default, charts show the last hour of metric data." uk-tooltip="">Changing the Time Range for a Custom Metric Chart</a>, and <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/query-metric-time-range.htm" title="Set the bounds, or timestamps, of the metric data that you want returned from a query of metric data in Monitoring." uk-tooltip="">Selecting a Nondefault Time Range for a Query</a>.</dd>
<dt class="dt dlterm" id="concepts__triggerruledefinition2">trigger rule</dt>
<dd class="dd">The condition that must be met for the alarm to be in the firing state. A trigger rule can be based on a threshold or absence of a metric.</dd>
<dd class="dd ddexpand">To set up a trigger rule in an alarm, see <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/create-edit-alarm-query-trigger-rule.htm" title="Define one or more trigger rules, or predicates, for an alarm. A trigger rule is a condition (defined by the query) that must be satisfied for the alarm to be in the firing state, and also includes severity, trigger delay (pendingDuration), and the alarm body to include in notifications. A condition in a trigger rule can specify a threshold, such as 90% for CPU utilization, or an absence." uk-tooltip="">Adding Trigger Rules to an Alarm</a>.</dd>
</dl>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title15" class="topic nested1" id="availability">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title15">Availability</h2>
<div class="body">
<p>The Monitoring service is available in all Oracle Cloud Infrastructure commercial regions. See <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/General/Concepts/regions.htm#About">About Regions and Availability Domains</a> for the <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/General/Concepts/regions.htm#About__The">list</a> of available regions, along with associated locations, region identifiers, region keys, and availability domains.
</p>
</div>
</article>

</li>

Network Firewall - see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/network-firewall/metrics.htm">Monitoring Firewalls</a>
</li>
<li>
Object Storage - see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Object/Reference/objectstoragemetrics.htm">Object Storage Metrics</a>
</li>
<li>
Ops Insights - see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/operations-insights/doc/operations-insights-metrics.html">Ops Insights Metrics</a>
</li>
<li>
Oracle APEX Application Development - see <a class="xref" href="https://docs.oracle.com/en/cloud/paas/apex/gsadd/monitor-apex-service-performance.html#GUID-4E640EB2-CACB-4994-BEE4-E40237AA5945">Monitor APEX Service Performance</a>
</li>
<li>
OS Management Hub - see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/osmh/doc/metrics.htm">OS Management Hub Metrics</a>
</li>
<li>
Process Automation - see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/process-automation/oci-process-automation/monitor-oracle-cloud-infrastructure-process-automation.html">Monitor Oracle Cloud Infrastructure Process Automation</a>
</li>
<li>
Queue - see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/queue/metrics.htm">Queue Metrics</a>
</li>
<li>
Secret Management Service - see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/secret-management/Concepts/metrics.htm">Secret Management Metrics</a>
</li>
<li>
Service Mesh - see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/service-mesh/sm-metrics.htm">Service Mesh Metrics</a>
</li>
<li>
Stack Monitoring - see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/stack-monitoring/doc/metric-reference.html">Metric Reference</a>
</li>
<li>
Streaming - see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Streaming/Reference/streamingmetrics.htm">Streaming Metrics</a>
</li>

Vulnerability Scanning - see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/scanning/using/metrics.htm">Scanning Metrics</a>
</li>

WAF - see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/WAF/Reference/metricsalarms.htm">Edge Policy Metrics</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title17" class="topic nested1" id="resource">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title17">Resource Identifiers</h2>
<div class="body">
<p>
Most types of Oracle Cloud Infrastructure resources have a unique, Oracle-assigned identifier called an Oracle Cloud ID (OCID). For information about the OCID format and other ways to identify your resources, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/General/Concepts/identifiers.htm">Resource Identifiers</a>., see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/General/Concepts/identifiers.htm">Resource Identifiers</a>.</p>
<div class="uk-alert uk-alert-primary"><span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="file-edit"></span><strong> Note</strong><br/><br/> Metric resources don't have <strong title="An Oracle-assigned unique ID for a cloud resource. This ID is included as part of the resource's information in both the Console and API." uk-tooltip="">OCIDs <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong>.</div>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title18" class="topic nested1" id="ways">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title18">Ways to Access Monitoring
</h2>
<div class="body">
<p>You can access Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI) by using the <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/GSG/Tasks/signingin_topic-Signing_In_for_the_First_Time.htm">Console</a> (a browser-based interface), <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/API/Concepts/usingapi.htm">REST API</a>, or <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/API/Concepts/cliconcepts.htm">OCI CLI</a>.<span id="ways__ph_instructions"> Instructions for using the Console, API, and CLI are included in topics throughout this documentation.</span>
<span id="ways__ph_sdks">For a list of available SDKs, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/API/Concepts/sdks.htm">Software Development Kits and Command Line Interface</a>.</span></p>
<p>
Console: To access Monitoring using the <a class="xref" href="https://cloud.oracle.com/">Console</a>, you must use a <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/GSG/Tasks/signinginIdentityDomain.htm#supported-browsers">supported browser</a>. To go to the Console sign-in page, open the navigation menu at the top of this page and select <strong class="ph uicontrol">Infrastructure Console</strong>. You are prompted to enter your cloud tenant, your user name, and your password.
Open the <strong title="Main menu located in the upper-left corner of the Oracle Cloud Console. Use the menu to navigate to OCI services, dashboards, and marketplace." uk-tooltip="">navigation menu <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong> and select <strong class="ph uicontrol">Observability &amp; Management</strong>. Under <strong class="ph uicontrol">Monitoring</strong>, select <strong class="ph uicontrol">Service Metrics</strong>. 
</p>
<p>API: To access Monitoring through APIs, use <a class="xref" href="/iaas/api/#/en/monitoring/latest/">Monitoring API</a> for metrics and alarms and <a class="xref" href="/iaas/api/#/en/notification/latest/">
Notifications API</a> for notifications (used with alarms). </p>
<p>CLI: See <a class="xref" href="/iaas/tools/oci-cli/latest/oci_cli_docs/cmdref/monitoring.html">Command Line Reference for Monitoring</a> and <a class="xref" href="/iaas/tools/oci-cli/latest/oci_cli_docs/cmdref/ons.html">Command Line Reference for Notifications</a>.</p>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title19" class="topic nested1" id="Authenti">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title19">Authentication and Authorization</h2>
<div class="body">
<div>
<p>Each service in Oracle Cloud Infrastructure integrates with IAM for authentication and authorization, for all interfaces (the Console, SDK or CLI, and REST API).</p>
<p>An administrator in an organization needs to set up <strong title="A collection of users who all need a particular type of access to a set of resources or compartment." uk-tooltip="">groups <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong>, <strong title="A collection of related resources that can be accessed only by groups that have been given permission by an administrator in your organization. Compartments can have a hierarchical structure, allowing for the creation of parent compartments and child compartments (also referred to as subcompartments)." uk-tooltip="">compartments <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong>, and <strong title='An Identity and Access Management (IAM) document that specifies who has what type of access to your resources. Policy can refer to several types of documents: an individual statement written in the policy language, a collection of statements in a single named "policy" document, and the overall body of policies that your organization uses to control access to resources.' uk-tooltip="">policies <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong> that control which users can access which services, which resources, and the type of access. For example, the policies control who can create new users, create and manage the cloud network, create instances, create buckets, download objects, and so on. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Identity/domains/overview.htm">Managing Identity Domains</a>. For specific details about writing policies for each of the different services, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Identity/Reference/policyreference.htm">Policy Reference</a>. </p>
<p>If you're a regular user (not an administrator) who needs to use the Oracle Cloud Infrastructure resources that the company owns, contact an administrator to set up a user ID for you. The administrator can confirm which compartment or compartments you can use.</p>
</div>
<p>For more information about user authorizations for monitoring, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Security/Reference/monitoring_security.htm#iam-policies">IAM Policies</a>.</p>
<p>Administrators: For common policies that give groups access to metrics, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Security/Reference/monitoring_security.htm#metric-groups">Metric Access for Groups</a>. 
For common alarm policies, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Security/Reference/monitoring_security.htm#alarm-groups">Alarm Access for Groups</a>. To authorize resources, such as instances, to make API calls, add the resources to a <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Identity/dynamicgroups/managingdynamicgroups.htm">dynamic group</a>. Use the dynamic group's matching rules to add the resources, and then create a policy that allows that dynamic group access to metrics. See <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Security/Reference/monitoring_security.htm#metric-dynamic">Metric Access for Resources</a>. </p>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title20" class="topic nested1" id="limits">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title20">Limits on Monitoring
</h2>
<div class="body">
<p>See <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/General/Concepts/servicelimits.htm#MonitoringLimits">Monitoring Limits</a> for a list of applicable limits and instructions for requesting a limit increase. </p>
<p>Other limits include the following. </p>
</div>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title21" class="topic nested2" id="Storage">
<h3 class="title topictitle3 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title21">Storage Limits</h3>
<div class="body">
<div class="uk-overflow-auto"><table class="table vl-table-bordered vl-table-divider-col" summary="Storage Limits"><caption></caption><colgroup><col/><col/></colgroup><thead class="thead">
<tr class="row">
<th class="entry" id="Storage__entry__1">Item</th>
<th class="entry" id="Storage__entry__2">Time range stored</th>
</tr>
</thead><tbody class="tbody">
<tr class="row">
<th class="entry" headers="Storage__entry__1" id="Storage__entry__3" scope="row">Metric definitions</th>
<td class="entry" headers="Storage__entry__3 Storage__entry__2">90 days</td>
</tr>
<tr class="row">
<th class="entry" headers="Storage__entry__1" id="Storage__entry__5" scope="row">Alarm history entries</th>
<td class="entry" headers="Storage__entry__5 Storage__entry__2">90 days</td>
</tr>
</tbody></table></div>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title22" class="topic nested2" id="ReturnedDataLimits">
<h3 class="title topictitle3 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title22">Returned Data Limits (Metrics)</h3>
<div class="body">
<p>When you <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/buildingqueries.htm" title="View custom metric charts, list metric definitions, and query metric data for resources of interest." uk-tooltip="">query metrics</a> and <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/viewingcharts.htm" title="View metric charts that use predefined service queries. Default metric charts are available on the Service Metrics page and resource details pages in the Console." uk-tooltip="">view metric charts</a>, the returned data is subject to certain limits. 
Limits information for returned data includes the 100,000 data point maximum and <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Monitoring/Reference/mql.htm#Interval">time range maximums (determined by resolution, which relates to interval)</a>. See <a class="xref" href="/iaas/api/#/en/monitoring/latest/MetricData">MetricData</a>.

</p>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title23" class="topic nested2" id="limits-alarm-messages">
<h3 class="title topictitle3 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title23">Alarm Message Limits</h3>
<div class="body"><p class="shortdesc">The maximum number of messages per alarm evaluation depends on the alarm destination. Limits are associated with the Oracle Cloud Infrastructure service used for the destination.</p>
<p>
Monitoring tracks 200,000 metric streams per alarm for <a class="xref" href="monitoringoverview.htm#MessageTypes" title="The message type indicates the reason that the message was sent." uk-tooltip="">qualifying events</a>. For more information about alarm evaluations, see <a class="xref" href="monitoringoverview.htm#alarm-eval" title="Monitoring evaluates alarms once per minute to find alarm status." uk-tooltip="">Alarm Evaluations</a>
 on this page.</p>
<div class="uk-overflow-auto"><table class="simpletable frame-all"><colgroup><col style="width:20%"/><col style="width:20%"/><col style="width:60%"/></colgroup><thead><tr class="sthead">
<th class="stentry" id="limits-alarm-messages__stentry__1" scope="col">Alarm destination</th>
<th class="stentry" id="limits-alarm-messages__stentry__2" scope="col">Delivery</th>
<th class="stentry" id="limits-alarm-messages__stentry__3" scope="col">Maximum alarm messages per evaluation</th>
</tr></thead><tbody><tr class="strow">
<td class="stentry" headers="limits-alarm-messages__stentry__1">topic (Notifications)</td>
<td class="stentry" headers="limits-alarm-messages__stentry__2">
<a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Notification/Concepts/notificationoverview.htm#concepts">At least once</a>
</td>
<td class="stentry" headers="limits-alarm-messages__stentry__3">60</td>
</tr><tr class="strow">
<td class="stentry" headers="limits-alarm-messages__stentry__1">stream (Streaming)</td>
<td class="stentry" headers="limits-alarm-messages__stentry__2">
<a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Streaming/Concepts/streamingoverview.htm#benefits_of_streams">At least once</a>
</td>
<td class="stentry" headers="limits-alarm-messages__stentry__3">100,000</td>
</tr></tbody></table></div>
<p>For example, consider the following evaluations of an alarm that <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/split-messages.htm" title="Walk through setting up an alarm to send a message for each metric stream. In this example, you want to be notified whenever a server exceeds a threshold. With this setup, you receive server-specific messages." uk-tooltip="">splits notifications</a> among 200 metric streams, using a topic as its destination.</p>
<div class="uk-overflow-auto"><table class="simpletable frame-all"><colgroup><col style="width:14.285714285714285%"/><col style="width:42.857142857142854%"/><col style="width:14.285714285714285%"/><col style="width:14.285714285714285%"/><col style="width:14.285714285714285%"/></colgroup><thead><tr class="sthead">
<th class="stentry" id="limits-alarm-messages__stentry__10" scope="col">Alarm evaluation (time)</th>
<th class="stentry" id="limits-alarm-messages__stentry__11" scope="col">Metric stream transition</th>
<th class="stentry" id="limits-alarm-messages__stentry__12" scope="col">Generated messages</th>
<th class="stentry" id="limits-alarm-messages__stentry__13" scope="col">Sent messages</th>
<th class="stentry" id="limits-alarm-messages__stentry__14" scope="col">Dropped messages</th>
</tr></thead><tbody><tr class="strow">
<td class="stentry" headers="limits-alarm-messages__stentry__10">00:01:00</td>
<td class="stentry" headers="limits-alarm-messages__stentry__11">110 metric streams transition from OK to FIRING.</td>
<td class="stentry" headers="limits-alarm-messages__stentry__12">110</td>
<td class="stentry" headers="limits-alarm-messages__stentry__13">60</td>
<td class="stentry" headers="limits-alarm-messages__stentry__14">50</td>
</tr><tr class="strow">
<td class="stentry" headers="limits-alarm-messages__stentry__10">00:02:00</td>
<td class="stentry" headers="limits-alarm-messages__stentry__11">90 metric streams transition from OK to FIRING.</td>
<td class="stentry" headers="limits-alarm-messages__stentry__12">90</td>
<td class="stentry" headers="limits-alarm-messages__stentry__13">60</td>
<td class="stentry" headers="limits-alarm-messages__stentry__14">30</td>
</tr></tbody></table></div>
<p>When a topic or stream is overused, it can result in delayed alarm notifications. Overuse can occur when multiple resources are using that topic or stream.</p>
<section class="section" id="limits-alarm-messages__best-practices"><h4 class="title sectiontitle vl-no-in-page-toc">Best Practices to Work Within Limits</h4>
<p>When you expect a high volume of alarm notifications, follow these best practices to help prevent exceeding alarm message limits and associated delays.</p>
<ul>
<li>Reserve a single topic or stream for use with a high-volume alarm. Don't use one topic or stream for multiple high-volume alarms.</li>
<li>
If you expect more than 60 messages per minute, specify Streaming as the alarm destination.
</li>
<li>Streams:<ul>
<li>Create partitions based on expected load. See <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Streaming/Concepts/streamingoverview_topic-Limits_on_Streaming_Resources.htm">Limits on Streaming Resources</a>.</li>
<li>If alarm messages exceed the stream space, then update the alarm to use a different stream that has more partitions. For example, if the original stream contains five partitions, create a stream with ten partitions and then update the alarm to use the new stream.<div class="uk-alert uk-alert-primary"><span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="file-edit"></span><strong> Note</strong><br/><br/> To avoid missing messages, continue consuming the original stream until no more messages are received.</div>
</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>Increase limits for the tenancy:<ul>
<li>Topics: See <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Notification/Concepts/notificationoverview.htm#limits__PublishMessageLimits">Limits for publishing messages (PublishMessage operation)</a>.</li>
<li>Streams: See <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Streaming/Concepts/streamingoverview_topic-Limits_on_Streaming_Resources.htm">Limits on Streaming Resources</a>.</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
</section>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title24" class="topic nested2" id="TroubleshootingLimits">
<h3 class="title topictitle3 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title24">Troubleshooting Limits</h3>
<div class="body">
<p>To troubleshoot a query error for too many metric streams, see <a class="xref" href="../troubleshooting-queries.htm#query-limits" title="Troubleshoot too many metric streams when querying metric data." uk-tooltip="">Error: Exceeded Maximum Metric Streams</a>.</p>
<p>For troubleshooting information, see <a class="xref" href="../troubleshooting.htm" title="Use troubleshooting information to identify and address common issues that can occur while working with Monitoring." uk-tooltip="">Troubleshooting Monitoring</a>.</p>
</div>
</article>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title25" class="topic concept nested1" id="security">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title25">Security</h2>
<div class="body conbody"><p class="shortdesc">This topic describes security for Monitoring.</p>
<p>For information about how to secure Monitoring, including security information and recommendations, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Security/Reference/monitoring_security.htm">Securing Monitoring</a>.</p>
</div>
</article>
</article>
</article>

  <div class="section" id="monitoring">
<h1>monitoring<a class="headerlink" href="#monitoring" title="Permalink to this headline">¶</a></h1>
<div class="section" id="description">
<h2>Description<a class="headerlink" href="#description" title="Permalink to this headline">¶</a></h2>
<p>Use the Monitoring CLI to manage metric queries and alarms for assessing the health, capacity, and performance of your cloud resources.
Endpoints vary by operation. For PostMetricData, use the <cite>telemetry-ingestion</cite> endpoints; for all other operations, use the <cite>telemetry</cite> endpoints.
For more information, see
<a class="reference external" href="https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/iaas/Content/Monitoring/home.htm">the Monitoring documentation</a>.</p>
</div>

<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title1" role="article">
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title1" class="topic nested0" id="top">
<h1 class="title topictitle1" id="ariaid-title1">Overview of Monitoring
</h1>
<div class="body"><p class="shortdesc">Use the Oracle Cloud Infrastructure Monitoring service to actively and passively monitor cloud resources using the Metrics and Alarms features. Learn how Monitoring works.</p>
<p id="top__metrics-alarms-diagram">
<div uk-lightbox=""><a href="../images/monitoringOverview.svg"><img alt="This image shows metrics and alarms as used in the Monitoring service." src="../images/monitoringOverview.svg" tabindex="" title="Click to expand"/></a></div>
</p>
<div class="uk-alert uk-alert-warning"><span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="lifesaver"></span><strong> Tip</strong><br/><br/> Watch a <a class="xref" href="https://apexapps.oracle.com/pls/apex/f?p=44785:265:0:::265:P265_CONTENT_ID:31981">video introduction</a> to the service.</div>
</div>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title2" class="topic nested1" id="How">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title2">How Monitoring Works</h2>
<div class="body">
<p>The Monitoring service uses <strong title="A measurement related to the health, capacity, or performance of a given resource. For example, CPU Utilization (CpuUtilization) measures the activity level from CPU, expressed as a percentage of total time." uk-tooltip="">metrics <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong> to monitor resources and <strong title="The trigger rule and query to evaluate, plus related configuration, such as the notification details to use when the trigger is breached. Alarms passively monitor your cloud resources by using metrics in the Monitoring service." uk-tooltip="">alarms <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong> to notify you when these metrics meet alarm-specified triggers. </p>
<p>Metrics are emitted to the Monitoring service as raw <strong title="A timestamp-value pair for a specified metric—for example, 2018-05-10T22:19:00Z, 10.4." uk-tooltip="">data points <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong>, or timestamp-value pairs, along with <strong title="A qualifier provided in a metric definition—for example, a resource identifier (resourceId) provided in the definitions of oci_computeagent metrics." uk-tooltip="">dimensions <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong> and metadata. Metrics come from various sources:</p>
<ul>
<li>Resource metrics automatically posted by Oracle Cloud Infrastructure
<strong title="The cloud objects that you create and use when interacting with Oracle Cloud Infrastructure." uk-tooltip="">resources <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong>. For example, the Compute service posts metrics for monitoring-enabled compute instances through <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Compute/References/computemetrics.htm#Availabl">the oci_computeagent namespace</a>. One such metric is <code class="ph codeph">CpuUtilization</code>. See <a class="xref" href="monitoringoverview.htm#SupportedServices">Supported Services</a> and <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/viewingcharts.htm" title="View metric charts that use predefined service queries. Default metric charts are available on the Service Metrics page and resource details pages in the Console." uk-tooltip="">Viewing Default Metric Charts</a>.</li>
<li>
<a class="xref" href="../Tasks/publishingcustommetrics.htm" title="Publish custom metrics to the Monitoring service." uk-tooltip="">Custom metrics</a> published using the Monitoring API.</li>
<li>Data sent to new or existing metrics using <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/connector-hub/home.htm">
Connector Hub
</a> (with Monitoring as the target service for a connector).</li>
</ul>
<p id="How__p_transfer-metrics-sch">You can transfer metrics from the Monitoring service using <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/connector-hub/home.htm">
Connector Hub
</a>. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/connector-hub/create-service-connector-monitoring-source.htm">Creating a Connector with a Monitoring Source</a>.</p>
<p>Metric data posted to the Monitoring service is only presented to you or consumed by the Oracle Cloud Infrastructure features that you enable to use metric data.</p>
<p>When you query a metric, the Monitoring service returns aggregated data according to the specified parameters. You can specify a range (such as the last 24 hours), <strong title="The aggregation function applied to the given set of raw data points—for example, SUM." uk-tooltip="">statistic <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong>, and <strong title="The time window used to convert a given set of raw data points—for example, 5 minutes." uk-tooltip="">interval <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong>. The Console displays one monitoring chart per metric for selected resources. The aggregated data in each chart reflects the selected statistic and interval. API requests can optionally filter by <strong title="A qualifier provided in a metric definition—for example, a resource identifier (resourceId) provided in the definitions of oci_computeagent metrics." uk-tooltip="">dimension <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong> and specify a <strong title="The period between time windows, or the regularity at which time windows shift—for example, 1 minute." uk-tooltip="">resolution <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong>. API responses include the metric name along with its source compartment and <strong title="Indicates the resource, service, or application that emits a metric. The namespace is provided in the metric definition. For example, the CpuUtilization metric definition emitted by the Oracle Cloud Agent software on Compute instances lists the oci_computeagent metric namespace as the source of the metric." uk-tooltip="">metric namespace <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong>. You can feed the aggregated data into a visualization or graphing library. </p>
<p>Metric and alarm data is accessible from the Console, CLI, and API. For retention periods, see <a class="xref" href="monitoringoverview.htm#Storage">Storage Limits</a>. </p>
<p>The Alarms feature of the Monitoring service publishes alarm <strong title="An alert published to all subscriptions in the specified topic. Each message is delivered at least once per subscription." uk-tooltip="">messages <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong> to configured destinations, such as topics in <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Notification/home.htm">
Notifications
</a> and streams in <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Streaming/home.htm">
Streaming
</a>.</p>
</div>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title3" class="topic nested2" id="metrics">
<h3 class="title topictitle3 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title3">Metrics Feature Overview<a name="MetricsOverview"></a>
</h3>
<div class="body"><p class="shortdesc">The Metrics feature relays metric data about the health, capacity, and performance of cloud resources.</p>
<p>A metric is a measurement related to health, capacity, or performance of a <strong title="The cloud objects that you create and use when interacting with Oracle Cloud Infrastructure." uk-tooltip="">resource <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong>. Resources, services, and applications emit metrics to the Monitoring service. Common metrics reflect data related to:</p>
<ul>
<li> Availability and latency</li>
<li>Application uptime and downtime</li>
<li>Completed transactions</li>
<li>Failed and successful operations</li>
<li>Key performance indicators (KPIs), such as sales and engagement quantifiers</li>
</ul>
<p>By querying Monitoring for this data, you can understand how well the systems and processes are working to achieve the service levels you commit to your customers. For example, you can monitor the CPU utilization and disk reads of compute <strong title="A bare metal or virtual machine compute host. The image used to create an instance determines its operating system and other software. The shape specified during the creation process determines the number of CPUs and memory allocated to the instance." uk-tooltip="">instances <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong>. You can then use this data to decide when to provision more instances to handle increased load, troubleshoot issues with the instance, or better understand system behavior. </p>
</div>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title4" class="topic nested3" id="Example_Metric_Failure_Rate">
<h4 class="title topictitle4 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title4">Example Metric: Failure Rate</h4>
<div class="body">
<p>For application health, one of the common KPIs is failure rate, for which a common definition is the number of failed transactions divided by total transactions. This KPI is typically delivered through application monitoring and management software.</p>
<p>As a developer, you can capture this KPI from applications using <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/publishingcustommetrics.htm" title="Publish custom metrics to the Monitoring service." uk-tooltip="">custom metrics</a>. Record observations every time an application transaction takes place and then post that data to the Monitoring service. In this case, set up metrics to capture failed transactions, successful transactions, and transaction latency (time spent per completed transaction).</p>
</div>
</article>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title5" class="topic nested2" id="alarms">
<h3 class="title topictitle3 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title5">Alarms Feature Overview</h3>
<div class="body"><p class="shortdesc">Use alarms to monitor the health, capacity, and performance of cloud resources.</p>
<div uk-lightbox=""><a href="../images/alarms-topic-diagram.svg"><img alt="Resources emit metric data points to Monitoring. When triggered, alarms send messages to the configured destination. For Notifications, messages are sent to subscriptions in the configured topic. For Streaming, messages are sent to the configured stream)." src="../images/alarms-topic-diagram.svg" tabindex="" title="Click to expand"/></a></div>
<p>The Alarms feature of the Monitoring service works with the configured destination service to notify you when metrics meet alarm-specified triggers. The previous illustration depicts the flow, starting with resources emitting metric <a class="xref" href="monitoringoverview.htm#concepts__datapointdefinition">data points</a> to Monitoring. When triggered, an <strong title="The trigger rule and query to evaluate, plus related configuration, such as the notification details to use when the trigger is breached. Alarms passively monitor your cloud resources by using metrics in the Monitoring service." uk-tooltip="">alarm <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong> sends an <a class="xref" href="monitoringoverview.htm#MessageFormat">alarm message</a> to the configured destination. For Notifications, messages are sent to <strong title="An endpoint for a topic, typically a URL or email address. Published messages are sent to each subscription for a topic." uk-tooltip="">subscriptions <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong> in the configured topic. For Streaming, messages are sent to the configured stream. (This illustration doesn't cover raw and aggregated metric data. For these details, see <a class="xref" href="monitoringoverview.htm#top__metrics-alarms-diagram">the "Monitoring Overview" illustration at the top of this page
</a>.)</p>
<p>When configured, repeat notifications remind you of a continued firing state at the configured repeat interval. You're also notified when an alarm transitions back to the OK state, or when an alarm is reset.</p>
</div>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title6" class="topic nested3" id="alarm-eval">
<h4 class="title topictitle4 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title6">Alarm Evaluations</h4>
<div class="body"><p class="shortdesc">
Monitoring evaluates alarms once per minute to find alarm status.</p>
<p>When the alarm <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/split-messages.htm" title="Walk through setting up an alarm to send a message for each metric stream. In this example, you want to be notified whenever a server exceeds a threshold. With this setup, you receive server-specific messages." uk-tooltip="">splits notifications</a>, Monitoring evaluates <em>each tracked metric stream</em>. If the evaluation of that metric stream indicates a new <code class="ph codeph">FIRING</code> status or other <a class="xref" href="monitoringoverview.htm#MessageTypes" title="The message type indicates the reason that the message was sent." uk-tooltip="">qualifying event</a>, then Monitoring sends an alarm message.</p>
<p>
Monitoring tracks metric streams per alarm for <a class="xref" href="monitoringoverview.htm#MessageTypes" title="The message type indicates the reason that the message was sent." uk-tooltip="">qualifying events</a>, but messages are subject to the <a class="xref" href="monitoringoverview.htm#limits-alarm-messages" title="The maximum number of messages per alarm evaluation depends on the alarm destination. Limits are associated with the Oracle Cloud Infrastructure service used for the destination." uk-tooltip="">destination service limits</a>.</p>
</div>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title7" class="topic nested4" id="illustration-eval">
<h5 class="title topictitle5 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title7">Illustration of Alarm Evaluation</h5>
<div class="body">
<p>Consider an alarm that measures the 90th percentile of the metric <code class="ph codeph">CpuUtilization</code>.</p>
<pre class="pre codeblock"><code>{
  "compartmentId": "ocid1.compartment.oc1..exampleuniqueID",
  "destinations": ["ocid1.onstopic.exampleuniqueID"],
  "displayName": "High CPU Utilization",
  "id": "ocid1.alarm.oc1..exampleuniqueID",
  "lifecycleState": "ACTIVE",
  "metricCompartmentId": "ocid1.compartment.oc1..exampleuniqueID",
  "namespace": "oci_computeagent",
  "pendingDuration": "PT3M",
  "query": "CpuUtilization[1m]{availabilityDomain = \"cumS:PHX-AD-1\"}.groupBy(availabilityDomain).percentile(0.9) &gt; 85",
  "repeatNotificationDuration": "PT2H",
  "severity": "WARNING",
  "isEnabled": true,
  "timeCreated": "2023-02-01T01:02:29.600Z",
  "timeUpdated": "2023-02-03T01:02:29.600Z"
}</code></pre>
<p>Notes about this example alarm:</p>
<ul>
<li>The percentile is specified in the query as the <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/create-edit-alarm-query-statistic.htm" title="Select the statistic for an alarm query. The statistic is the aggregation function applied to the set of raw data points at the specified interval." uk-tooltip="">statistic</a> (<strong>bold</strong>):<pre class="pre codeblock"><code>CpuUtilization[1m]{availabilityDomain = \"cumS:PHX-AD-1\"}.groupBy(availabilityDomain).<strong>percentile(0.9)</strong> &gt; 85</code></pre>
</li>
<li>Each data point is the 90th percentile (<code class="ph codeph">percentile(0.9)</code>) of a one-minute window, specified in the query as the <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/create-edit-alarm-query-interval.htm" title="Select the interval, or time window, for querying metric data in an alarm in Monitoring." uk-tooltip="">interval</a> (bold):<pre class="pre codeblock"><code>CpuUtilization[<strong>1m</strong>]{availabilityDomain = \"cumS:PHX-AD-1\"}.groupBy(availabilityDomain).percentile(0.9) &gt; 85</code></pre>
</li>
<li>Data point values for this statistic could be anything from null (absent) to 100.</li>
<li>Data point evaluations: <ul>
<li>For any data point value greater than 85, the evaluation is true (<code class="ph codeph">1</code>). A true evaluation means that the trigger rule condition has been met. </li>
<li>For any data point value that isn't greater than 85, the evaluation is false (<code class="ph codeph">0</code>). </li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>The alarm doesn't fire until the <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/create-edit-alarm-query-trigger-rule.htm" title="Define one or more trigger rules, or predicates, for an alarm. A trigger rule is a condition (defined by the query) that must be satisfied for the alarm to be in the firing state, and also includes severity, trigger delay (pendingDuration), and the alarm body to include in notifications. A condition in a trigger rule can specify a threshold, such as 90% for CPU utilization, or an absence." uk-tooltip="">trigger rule</a> condition is met for three successive minutes. This configuration is the alarm's <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/create-edit-alarm-query-trigger-delay.htm" title="Define the number of minutes that the condition must be maintained before the alarm is in firing state." uk-tooltip="">trigger delay</a> (<code class="ph codeph">pendingDuration</code>), set as <code class="ph codeph">PT3M</code>. </li>
<li>The alarm updates its state to OK when the breaching condition has been clear for the most recent minute.</li>
</ul>
<p>The following image shows an aggregated metric stream for the example alarm. Each data point is indicated by a square.</p>
<br/><img alt="Aggregated metric stream for the example alarm." src="../images/monitoring-alarm-eval.svg"/><br/>
<p>The following table shows consecutive alarm evaluations for the example alarm. The alarm is evaluated on a moving window of three one-minute intervals.</p>
<div class="uk-overflow-auto"><table class="table" summary="Consecutive evaluations of the example alarm."><caption></caption><colgroup><col/><col/><col/><col/></colgroup><thead class="thead">
<tr class="row">
<th class="entry" id="illustration-eval__entry__1">Evaluation period timestamp</th>
<th class="entry" id="illustration-eval__entry__2">Minutes in period</th>
<th class="entry" id="illustration-eval__entry__3">Data point evaluations*</th>
<th class="entry" id="illustration-eval__entry__4">Status</th>
</tr>
</thead><tbody class="tbody">
<tr class="row">
<td class="entry" headers="illustration-eval__entry__1">3</td>
<td class="entry" headers="illustration-eval__entry__2">[1, 2, 3]</td>
<td class="entry" headers="illustration-eval__entry__3">[0, 0, 0]</td>
<td class="entry" headers="illustration-eval__entry__4">
<code class="ph codeph">OK</code>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="row">
<td class="entry" headers="illustration-eval__entry__1">4</td>
<td class="entry" headers="illustration-eval__entry__2">[2, 3, 4]</td>
<td class="entry" headers="illustration-eval__entry__3">[0, 0, 1]</td>
<td class="entry" headers="illustration-eval__entry__4">
<code class="ph codeph">OK</code>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="row">
<td class="entry" headers="illustration-eval__entry__1">5</td>
<td class="entry" headers="illustration-eval__entry__2">[3, 4, 5]</td>
<td class="entry" headers="illustration-eval__entry__3">[0, 1, 1]</td>
<td class="entry" headers="illustration-eval__entry__4">
<code class="ph codeph">OK</code>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="row">
