<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title1" role="article">
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title1" class="topic nested0" id="top">
<h1 class="title topictitle1" id="ariaid-title1">Managing Alarms</h1>
<div class="body"><p class="shortdesc">Create, update, suppress, and delete alarms. Retrieve alarm history.</p>
<p>The following pages describe how you can manage alarms:</p>
<ul>
<li><a class="xref" href="../Tasks/list-alarm.htm" title="List alarms in Monitoring." uk-tooltip="">Listing Alarms</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="../Tasks/create-alarm.htm" title="Create an alarm in Monitoring to notify you when metrics meet specified triggers." uk-tooltip="">Creating an Alarm</a><ul id="top__ul_nav-create-alarm">
<li><a class="xref" href="../Tasks/create-alarm-basic.htm" title="Create a basic alarm in Monitoring to notify you when metrics meet specified triggers." uk-tooltip="">Creating a Basic Alarm</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="../Tasks/update-alarm-event.htm" title="Get notified every time your event-based metric is emitted." uk-tooltip="">Getting Event-Based Notifications for an Alarm</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="../Tasks/create-alarm-split.htm" title="Create an alarm in Monitoring that sends a separate alarm message for each metric stream." uk-tooltip="">Creating an Alarm That Splits Messages by Metric Stream</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="../Tasks/create-alarm-threshold.htm" title="Create a threshold alarm in Monitoring to send notifications when a metric meets a specified threshold value." uk-tooltip="">Creating a Threshold Alarm</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="../Tasks/create-alarm-absence.htm" title="Create an absence alarm in Monitoring to send notifications when a metric doesn't emit data for a specified interval." uk-tooltip="">Creating an Absence Alarm</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="../Tasks/create-alarm-mql.htm" title="Directly edit an alarm's MQL expression when you create the alarm in Monitoring." uk-tooltip="">Editing the MQL Expression When Creating an Alarm</a></li>
</ul></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="../Tasks/create-edit-alarm-chart.htm" title="View a metric chart for an alarm query in the Console." uk-tooltip="">Viewing an Alarm Metric Chart</a><ul id="top__ul_nav-create-edit-alarm-chart">
<li><a class="xref" href="../Tasks/create-alarm-chart-basic-query.htm" title="Generate a metric chart on the Create Alarm page in the Console by creating a basic alarm query." uk-tooltip="">Creating a Basic Query to Generate an Alarm Metric Chart</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="../Tasks/create-edit-alarm-chart-toggle-view.htm" title="View the metric chart for a new or existing alarm in the Console as a table, or switch back to the graph (chart) view." uk-tooltip="">Switching Table and Graph Views for an Alarm Metric Chart</a></li>
</ul></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="../Tasks/list-alarm-status.htm" title="List status levels for alarms in Monitoring." uk-tooltip="">Listing Status of Alarms</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="../Tasks/list-alarm-status-metric-stream.htm" title="List the status of each metric stream in an alarm in Monitoring. A metric stream corresponds to a set of dimension key-value pairs." uk-tooltip="">Listing Metric Stream Status in an Alarm</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="../Tasks/get-alarm.htm" title="Get details for an alarm in Monitoring." uk-tooltip="">Getting an Alarm's Details</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="../Tasks/get-alarm-history.htm" title="Get the history of an alarm in Monitoring. Alarm history is retained for 90 days." uk-tooltip="">Getting the History of an Alarm</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="../Tasks/update-alarm.htm" title="Update an alarm in Monitoring." uk-tooltip="">Updating an Alarm</a><ul id="top__ul_nav-update-alarm">
<li><a class="xref" href="../Tasks/update-alarm-basic.htm" title="Update an alarm in Monitoring." uk-tooltip="">Making Basic Updates to an Alarm</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="../Tasks/update-alarm-after-resource-move.htm" title="Update an alarm in Monitoring after you move a monitored resource." uk-tooltip="">Updating an Alarm After Moving a Resource</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="../Tasks/update-alarm-mql.htm" title="Directly edit an alarm's MQL expression when you update the alarm." uk-tooltip="">Editing the MQL Expression When Updating an Alarm</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="../Tasks/create-edit-alarm-query-absence-detection-period.htm" title="Specify a custom value for the absence detection period to use when querying metric data in an alarm in Monitoring." uk-tooltip="">Customizing the Absence Detection Period for an Alarm Query</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="../Tasks/create-edit-alarm-query-slack-period.htm" title="Specify a custom value for the slack period to use when querying metric data in an alarm in Monitoring." uk-tooltip="">Customizing the Slack Period for an Alarm Query</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="../Tasks/create-edit-alarm-query-interval.htm" title="Select the interval, or time window, for querying metric data in an alarm in Monitoring." uk-tooltip="">Selecting the Interval for an Alarm Query</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="../Tasks/create-edit-alarm-query-statistic.htm" title="Select the statistic for an alarm query. The statistic is the aggregation function applied to the set of raw data points at the specified interval." uk-tooltip="">Selecting the Statistic for an Alarm Query</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="../Tasks/create-edit-alarm-query-dimensions.htm" title="Limit the metric data that's returned by selecting dimensions for an alarm in Monitoring. A dimension is a qualifier provided in a metric definition. In MQL, the dimension selection component specifies name-value pairs for dimensions, surrounded by curly brackets." uk-tooltip="">Selecting Dimensions for an Alarm Query</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="../Tasks/create-edit-alarm-query-trigger-rule.htm" title="Define one or more trigger rules, or predicates, for an alarm. A trigger rule is a condition (defined by the query) that must be satisfied for the alarm to be in the firing state, and also includes severity, trigger delay (pendingDuration), and the alarm body to include in notifications. A condition in a trigger rule can specify a threshold, such as 90% for CPU utilization, or an absence." uk-tooltip="">Adding Trigger Rules to an Alarm</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="../Tasks/create-edit-alarm-query-trigger-delay.htm" title="Define the number of minutes that the condition must be maintained before the alarm is in firing state." uk-tooltip="">Defining the Trigger Delay for an Alarm</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="../Tasks/create-edit-alarm-notification.htm" title="Select the topic or stream to send alarm notifications to. Group or split notifications, format messages, and choose whether to repeat notifications." uk-tooltip="">Defining Notifications for an Alarm</a><ul id="top__ul_nav-notification">
<li><a class="xref" href="../Tasks/create-edit-alarm-notification-stream.htm" title="Select the stream to send alarm notifications to." uk-tooltip="">Selecting a Stream as the Notification Destination for an Alarm</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="../Tasks/create-edit-alarm-notification-topic.htm" title="Select the topic to send alarm notifications to." uk-tooltip="">Selecting a Topic as the Notification Destination for an Alarm</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="../Tasks/update-alarm-event.htm" title="Get notified every time your event-based metric is emitted." uk-tooltip="">Getting Event-Based Notifications for an Alarm</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="../Tasks/update-alarm-split-messages.htm" title="Update an alarm in Monitoring to split notifications." uk-tooltip="">Splitting Notifications for an Alarm</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="../Tasks/update-alarm-group-messages.htm" title="Update an alarm in Monitoring to group notifications." uk-tooltip="">Grouping Notifications for an Alarm</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="../Tasks/update-alarm-dynamic-variables.htm" title="Update an alarm in Monitoring to include values of alarm message parameters in messages." uk-tooltip="">Using Dynamic Variables in Alarm Messages</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="../Tasks/update-alarm-friendly-formats.htm" title="Update an alarm in Monitoring to send messages with friendly formatting or other format options." uk-tooltip="">Formatting Messages for an Alarm</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="../Tasks/create-edit-alarm-query-repeat-notifications.htm" title="Set the frequency for repeating alarm notifications when the alarm keeps firing without interruption." uk-tooltip="">Repeating Notifications for an Alarm</a></li>
</ul></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="../Tasks/create-edit-alarm-query-resource.htm" title="Limit returned metric data to a resource by selecting a resource-specific dimension when querying metric data for an alarm in Monitoring." uk-tooltip="">Selecting a Resource for an Alarm Query</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="../Tasks/create-edit-alarm-query-resource-group.htm" title="Limit returned metric data by matching a resource group when querying custom metric data for an alarm in Monitoring." uk-tooltip="">Selecting a Resource Group in an Alarm Query</a></li>
</ul></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="../Tasks/enable-alarm.htm" title="Enable an alarm in Monitoring." uk-tooltip="">Enabling an Alarm</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="../Tasks/disable-alarm.htm" title="Disable an alarm in Monitoring." uk-tooltip="">Disabling an Alarm</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="../Tasks/suppressions.htm" title="Add dimension-specific and alarm-wide suppressions. Get details about alarm suppressions, get history of suppressions for an alarm, and remove suppressions." uk-tooltip="">Managing Alarm Suppressions</a><ul id="top__ul_nav-suppressions">
<li><a class="xref" href="../Tasks/list-alarm-suppression.htm" title="List suppressions for an alarm in Monitoring." uk-tooltip="">Listing Alarm Suppressions</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="../Tasks/get-alarm-suppression.htm" title="Get details for a suppression of an alarm in Monitoring." uk-tooltip="">Getting an Alarm Suppression's Details</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="../Tasks/summarize-alarm-suppression-history.htm" title="Get history of suppressions for an alarm in Monitoring." uk-tooltip="">Getting Suppression History for an Alarm</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="../Tasks/create-alarm-suppression.htm" title="Temporarily stop notifications from an alarm by applying a suppression. For example, use a suppression to suspend alarm notifications during system maintenance." uk-tooltip="">Suppressing a Single Alarm</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="../Tasks/create-alarm-suppression-multiple.htm" title="Temporarily stop notifications from alarms by applying a suppression to selected alarms in the Console. For example, use a suppression to suspend notifications from selected alarms." uk-tooltip="">Suppressing Multiple Alarms</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="../Tasks/delete-alarm-suppression.htm" title="Remove a suppression of an alarm in Monitoring. For example, if the alarm has an existing (expired) alarm-wide suppression, remove it so you can add another one. An alarm can have only one alarm-wide suppression at a time." uk-tooltip="">Removing a Suppression from a Single Alarm</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="../Tasks/delete-alarm-suppression-multiple.htm" title="Remove suppressions from selected alarms in the Console. For example, if two alarms have existing (expired) alarm-wide suppressions and you want to add a new alarm-wide suppression to them, then remove the existing ones first. An alarm can have only one alarm-wide suppression at a time." uk-tooltip="">Removing Suppressions from Multiple Alarms</a></li>
</ul></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="../Tasks/change-compartment-alarm.htm" title="Move an alarm in Monitoring to another compartment." uk-tooltip="">Moving an Alarm to a Different Compartment</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="../Tasks/delete-alarm.htm" title="Delete an alarm in Monitoring." uk-tooltip="">Deleting an Alarm</a></li>
</ul>
<p>See also <a class="xref" href="../Concepts/alarmsbestpractices.htm" title="Read about best practices for alarms." uk-tooltip="">Best Practices for Your Alarms</a>. </p>
</div>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title2" class="topic nested1" id="prerequisites">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title2">
Before You Begin
</h2>
<div class="body">
<ul>
<li>
IAM policies: Managing alarms is part of monitoring. To monitor resources, you must be granted the required type of access in a <strong title='An Identity and Access Management (IAM) document that specifies who has what type of access to your resources. Policy can refer to several types of documents: an individual statement written in the policy language, a collection of statements in a single named "policy" document, and the overall body of policies that your organization uses to control access to resources.' uk-tooltip="">policy <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong> written by an administrator, whether you're using the Console or the REST API with an SDK, CLI, or other tool. The policy must give you access to both the monitoring services and the resources being monitored. If you try to perform an action and get a message that you don't have permission or are unauthorized, contact the administrator to find out what type of access you were granted and which <strong title="A collection of related resources that can be accessed only by groups that have been given permission by an administrator in your organization. Compartments can have a hierarchical structure, allowing for the creation of parent compartments and child compartments (also referred to as subcompartments)." uk-tooltip="">compartment <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong> you need to work in. For more information about user authorizations for monitoring, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Security/Reference/monitoring_security.htm#iam-policies">IAM Policies</a>. Administrators: For common alarm policies, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Security/Reference/monitoring_security.htm#alarm-groups">Alarm Access for Groups</a>.
</li>
<li>
Metrics exist in Monitoring: The resources that you want to monitor must emit metrics to the Monitoring service.
</li>
<li>
Compute instances: To emit metrics, the Compute Instance Monitoring plugin must be enabled on the instance, and plugins must be running. The instance must also have either a service gateway or a public IP address to send metrics to the Monitoring service. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Compute/Tasks/enablingmonitoring.htm">Enabling Monitoring for Compute Instances</a>.
</li>
</ul>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title3" class="topic nested1" id="applying-tags">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title3">Applying Tags</h2>
<div class="body">
<p>Apply tags to resources to help organize them according to your business needs. You can apply tags when you create a resource, and you can update a resource later to add, revise, or remove tags. For general information about applying tags, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/General/Concepts/resourcetags.htm">Resource Tags</a>.</p>
</div>
</article>
</article>
</article>

<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title1" role="article">
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title1" class="topic nested0" id="loggingoverview">
<h1 class="title topictitle1" id="ariaid-title1">Logging Overview</h1>
<div class="body">
<p>The Oracle Cloud Infrastructure Logging service is a highly scalable and fully managed single pane of glass for all the logs in your tenancy. Logging provides access to logs from Oracle Cloud Infrastructure resources. These logs include critical diagnostic information that describes how resources are performing and being accessed.</p>
<div class="uk-alert uk-alert-warning"><span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="lifesaver"></span><strong> Tip</strong><br/><br/> Watch a <a class="xref" href="https://apexapps.oracle.com/pls/apex/f?p=44785:265:0:::265:P265_CONTENT_ID:32063">video introduction</a> to the service.</div>
</div>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title2" class="topic nested1" id="how_logging_works">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title2">How Logging Works</h2>
<div class="body">
<p>Use Logging to enable, manage, and search logs. The three kinds of logs are the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a class="xref" href="audit_logs.htm" title="On the Audit page, you can explore audit logs. Audit logs are also searchable on the Search page, and you can view Audit logs in every compartment by selecting the /_Audit log group on the Search page." uk-tooltip="">Audit logs</a>: Logs related to events emitted by the Oracle Cloud Infrastructure Audit service. These logs are available from the Logging <strong class="ph uicontrol">Audit</strong> page, or are searchable on the <strong class="ph uicontrol">Search</strong> page alongside the rest of your logs.</li>
<li><a class="xref" href="service_logs.htm" title="Oracle Cloud Infrastructure services emit service logs. Each of these supported services has a Logs resource you can use to enable or disable logging for that service." uk-tooltip="">Service Logs</a>: Emitted by OCI native services, such as API Gateway, Events, Functions, Load Balancer, Object Storage, and VCN Flow Logs. Each of these <a class="xref" href="service_logs.htm#supported_services">supported services</a> has predefined logging categories that you can enable or disable on your respective resources.</li>
<li>
<a class="xref" href="custom_logs.htm" title="Custom logs are logs that contain diagnostic information from custom applications, other cloud providers, or an on-premise environment." uk-tooltip="">Custom logs</a>: Logs that contain diagnostic information from custom applications, other cloud providers, or an on-premises environment. Custom logs can be ingested through the API, or by configuring the Unified Monitoring Agent. You can configure an OCI compute instance/resource to directly upload Custom Logs through the Unified Monitoring Agent. Custom logs are supported in both a virtual machine and bare metal scenario.</li>
</ul>
<p>A <em>log</em> is a first-class Oracle Cloud Infrastructure resource that stores and captures log events collected in a given context. For example, if you enable Flow Logs on a subnet, it has its own dedicated log. Each log has an OCID and is stored in a log group. A <em>log group</em> is a collection of logs stored in a compartment. Logs and log groups are searchable, actionable, and transportable.</p>
<p>To get started, enable a log for a resource. Services provide log categories for the different types of logs available for resources. For example, the Object Storage service supports the following log categories for storage buckets: read and write access events. Read access events capture download events, while write access events capture write events. Each service can have different log categories for resources. The log categories for one service have no relationship to the log categories of another service. As a result, the Functions service uses different log categories than the Object Storage service. </p>
<p>When you enable a log, you must add it to a log group that you create. <em>Log groups</em> are logical containers for logs. Use log groups to organize and streamline management of logs by applying IAM policy or grouping logs for analysis. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="../Task/managinglogs.htm" title="Use Oracle Cloud Infrastructure Logging to manage logs and log groups." uk-tooltip="">Logs and Log Groups</a>.</p>
<p>Logs are indexed in the system, and searchable through the Console, API, and CLI. You can view and search logs on the Logging <strong class="ph uicontrol">Search</strong> page. When searching logs, you can correlate across many logs simultaneously. For example, you can view results from multiple logs, multiple log groups, or even an entire compartment with one query. You can filter, aggregate, and visualize your logs. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="searchinglogs.htm" title="Use the Logging Search page to search logs." uk-tooltip="">Logging Search</a>. </p>
<div class="uk-alert uk-alert-primary"><span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="file-edit"></span><strong> Note</strong><br/><br/> Only UTF-8 text encoding is supported.</div>
<p>After you enable a log, log entries begin to appear on the detail page for the log (see <a class="xref" href="../Task/enabling_logging.htm" title="Service logs can be enabled directly on the resource itself, on the Logs page, or on a log group details page." uk-tooltip="">Enabling Logging for a Resource</a> for more information).</p>
<div class="uk-alert uk-alert-primary"><span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="file-edit"></span><strong> Note</strong><br/><br/> You can view usage report detail for Logging by accessing <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Billing/Concepts/costusagereportsoverview.htm">Cost and Usage Reports</a>.</div>
<section class="section" id="how_logging_works__sch_integration"><h3 class="title sectiontitle vl-include-in-page-toc">
Connector Hub Integration</h3>
<p>
Oracle Cloud Infrastructure Logging integrates with <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/connector-hub/home.htm">Connector Hub</a>. If you need more archiving support, you can use Connector Hub for archiving to object storage, writing to stream, and so on. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="connectors.htm" title="Create a connector in Logging." uk-tooltip="">Connectors</a> and <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/connector-hub/archivelogs.htm">Scenario: Archiving Logs to Object Storage</a>.</p>
</section>
<section class="section" id="how_logging_works__logging_workshop"><h3 class="title sectiontitle vl-include-in-page-toc">Logging Workshop</h3>
<p>See the <a aria-label="OCI Logging Workshop. Opens in a new window" class="xref" href="https://swigmaster.github.io/index.html?lab=introduction" rel="noopener" target="_blank">OCI Logging Workshop</a> for step-by-step, lab-based instructions on setting up your environment, enabling service logs, creating custom application logs, searching logs, and exporting log content to Object Storage.</p>
</section>
<section class="section" id="how_logging_works__logging_apis"><h3 class="title sectiontitle vl-include-in-page-toc">Logging APIs</h3>
<p>
Oracle Cloud Infrastructure Logging has the following APIs available:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a class="xref" href="/iaas/api/#/en/logging-management/latest/">Logging Management API</a>
</li>
<li>
<a class="xref" href="/iaas/api/#/en/logging-dataplane/latest/">Logging Ingestion API</a>
</li>
<li>
<a class="xref" href="/iaas/api/#/en/logging-search/latest/">Logging Search API</a>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Also see the API topics in <a class="xref" href="../Task/log-management.htm" title="Learn about how to create and manage logs." uk-tooltip="">Log Management</a>, <a class="xref" href="using_the_api_customlogs.htm" title="Use the PutLogs Logging Ingestion API operation to ingest custom logs directly." uk-tooltip="">Using the (Logging Ingestion) API for custom logs</a>, and <a class="xref" href="using_the_api_searchlogs.htm" title="Details on Oracle Cloud Infrastructure Logging search API, and SDK examples." uk-tooltip="">Using the (Logging Search) API</a> for more information on logging operations specific to each API.</p>
</section>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title3" class="topic nested1" id="logging_concepts">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title3">Logging Concepts</h2>
<div class="body">
<p>The following concepts are essential to working with Logging.</p>
<dl>
<dt class="dt dlterm">Service Logs</dt>
<dd class="dd">Critical diagnostic information from supported Oracle Cloud Infrastructure
                    services. See <a class="xref" href="service_logs.htm#supported_services">Supported Services</a>.</dd>
<dt class="dt dlterm">Custom Logs</dt>
<dd class="dd">Diagnostic information from custom applications, other cloud providers, or an
                    on-premise environment. To ingest custom logs, call the API directly or
                    configure the unified monitoring agent.</dd>
<dt class="dt dlterm">Audit Logs</dt>
<dd class="dd">Read-only logs from the Audit service, provided for you to analyze and search.
                    Audit logs capture the information about API calls made to public endpoints
                    throughout your tenancy. These include API calls made by the Console, Command Line Interface (CLI), Software
                    Development Kits (SDK), your own custom clients, or other Oracle Cloud Infrastructure services. </dd>
<dt class="dt dlterm">Log Groups</dt>
<dd class="dd">Log groups are logical containers for logs. Use log groups to streamline log
                    management, including applying IAM policy or searching sets of logs. You can
                    move log groups from one compartment to another and all the logs contained in
                    the log group moves with it. </dd>
<dt class="dt dlterm">Service Log Category</dt>
<dd class="dd">Services provide log categories for the different types of logs available for
                    resources. For example, the Object Storage
                    service supports the following log categories for storage buckets: read and
                    write access events. Read access events capture download events, while write
                    access events capture write events. Each service can have different log
                    categories for resources. The log categories for one service have no
                    relationship to the log categories of another service.</dd>
<dt class="dt dlterm">
Connector Hub
</dt>
<dd class="dd">
<p>
<a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/connector-hub/home.htm">Connector Hub</a> moves logging data to other services in Oracle Cloud Infrastructure. For example, use Connector Hub to <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/connector-hub/alarmlogs.htm">alarm on log data</a>, <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/connector-hub/dblogs.htm">send log data to databases</a>, and <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/connector-hub/archivelogs.htm">archive log data to Object Storage</a>. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/connector-hub/home.htm">Connector Hub</a>.</p>
</dd>
<dt class="dt dlterm">
Unified Monitoring Agent
</dt>
<dd class="dd">The fluentd-based agent that runs on customer machines (OCI instances), to help customers
                    ingest custom logs.</dd>
<dt class="dt dlterm">Agent Configuration</dt>
<dd class="dd">A configuration of the Unified Monitoring Agent
                    that specifies how custom logs are ingested.</dd>
</dl>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title4" class="topic concept nested1" id="log_encryption">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title4">Log Encryption</h2>
<div class="body conbody">
<div class="p">
OCI logs are encrypted according to the
                following:<ul>
<li>Logs are encrypted in-flight, that is, while they are in the process of being
                    ingested into Oracle Cloud Infrastructure Logging;</li>
<li>After the logs are in the system, they are encrypted with disk-level encryption
                    for commercial environments; and</li>
<li>Logs are also encrypted when they are archived, and while in storage.</li>
</ul>
</div>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title5" class="topic nested1" id="resource_identifiers">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title5">Resource Identifiers</h2>
<div class="body">
<p>
Most types of Oracle Cloud Infrastructure resources have a unique, Oracle-assigned identifier called an Oracle Cloud ID (OCID). For information about the OCID format and other ways to identify your resources, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/General/Concepts/identifiers.htm">Resource Identifiers</a>.
</p>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title6" class="topic nested1" id="ways_to_access">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title6">Ways to Access Oracle Cloud Infrastructure</h2>
<div class="body">
<div>
<p id="ways_to_access__p_waystoaccess">You can access Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI) by using the <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/GSG/Tasks/signingin_topic-Signing_In_for_the_First_Time.htm">Console</a> (a browser-based interface), <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/API/Concepts/usingapi.htm">REST API</a>, or <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/API/Concepts/cliconcepts.htm">OCI CLI</a>.<span id="ways_to_access__ph_instructions"> Instructions for using the Console, API, and CLI are included in topics throughout this documentation.</span>
<span id="ways_to_access__ph_sdks">For a list of available SDKs, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/API/Concepts/sdks.htm">Software Development Kits and Command Line Interface</a>.</span></p>
<p id="ways_to_access__p_console-access"><span id="ways_to_access__ph_console-access">To access <span id="ways_to_access__ph_console-access-for-service">the <a class="xref" href="https://cloud.oracle.com/">Console</a>, you must use a <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/GSG/Tasks/signinginIdentityDomain.htm#supported-browsers">supported browser</a>. To go to the Console sign-in page, open the navigation menu at the top of this page and select <strong class="ph uicontrol">Infrastructure Console</strong>. You are prompted to enter your cloud tenant, your user name, and your password.</span></span></p>
</div>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title7" class="topic nested1" id="authentication_and_authorization">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title7">Authentication and Authorization</h2>
<div class="body">
<div>
<p>Each service in Oracle Cloud Infrastructure integrates with IAM for authentication and authorization, for all interfaces (the Console, SDK or CLI, and REST API).</p>
<p>An administrator in an organization needs to set up <strong title="A collection of users who all need a particular type of access to a set of resources or compartment." uk-tooltip="">groups <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong>, <strong title="A collection of related resources that can be accessed only by groups that have been given permission by an administrator in your organization. Compartments can have a hierarchical structure, allowing for the creation of parent compartments and child compartments (also referred to as subcompartments)." uk-tooltip="">compartments <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong>, and <strong title='An Identity and Access Management (IAM) document that specifies who has what type of access to your resources. Policy can refer to several types of documents: an individual statement written in the policy language, a collection of statements in a single named "policy" document, and the overall body of policies that your organization uses to control access to resources.' uk-tooltip="">policies <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong> that control which users can access which services, which resources, and the type of access. For example, the policies control who can create new users, create and manage the cloud network, create instances, create buckets, download objects, and so on. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Identity/domains/overview.htm">Managing Identity Domains</a>. For specific details about writing policies for each of the different services, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Identity/Reference/policyreference.htm">Policy Reference</a>. </p>
<p>If you're a regular user (not an administrator) who needs to use the Oracle Cloud Infrastructure resources that the company owns, contact an administrator to set up a user ID for you. The administrator can confirm which compartment or compartments you can use.</p>
</div>
<p>For administrators: Use the following topics to find examples of IAM policy for
            Logging:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a class="xref" href="../Task/managinglogs.htm#required_permissions_logs_groups">Required Permissions for Working with Logs and Log Groups</a>
</li>
<li>
<a class="xref" href="searchinglogs.htm#required_permissions_for_searching_logs">Required Permissions for Searching Logs</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>

<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title1" class="consolehelp" role="article">
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title1" class="topic nested0 consolehelp" id="Overview_of_Vault">
<h1 class="title topictitle1" id="ariaid-title1">Overview of Vaults and Key Management</h1>
<div class="body"><p class="shortdesc">The Key Management service stores and manages keys within vaults for secure access to resources. </p>
<p>The Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI) <a class="xref" href="https://www.oracle.com/security/cloud-security/key-management/">Key Management Service</a> (KMS) is a cloud-based service that provides centralized management and control of encryption keys for data stored in OCI.</p>
<p>
OCI KMS does the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>Simplifies key management by centrally storing and managing encryption keys.</li>
<li>Protects data at rest and in transit by supporting various encryption key types, including symmetric keys and, asymmetric keys.</li>
<li>Addresses security and compliance requirements with several options for creating and storing keys. Features for this include: importing key material to OCI ("Bring Your Own Keys" or BYOK), creating keys in OCI, and storing keys externally ("Hold Your Own Keys" or HYOK) using <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/external_key_management.htm" title="With Oracle Cloud Infrastructure External Key Management Service (EKMS) you can create and manage encryption keys that are hosted outside of OCI. EKMS integrates with supported third-party key management systems to perform cryptographic operations without importing key material into OCI." uk-tooltip="">external key management</a>. Key Management supports FIPS 140-2 Level 3-certified hardware security modules (HSMs) to store and protect your encryption keys.</li>
<li>Integrates encryption with other OCI services such as storage, database, and Fusion Applications for protecting data stored in these services.</li>
</ul>
<div class="uk-alert uk-alert-primary"><span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="file-edit"></span><strong> Note</strong><br/><br/>
<p>The secrets functionality of Vault, including secret tags and secret rules, has moved to a new Secret Management Service. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/secret-management/home.htm">Secret Management Service</a>.</p>
</div>
</div>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title2" class="topic nested1" id="concepts">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title2">Vault and Key Management Concepts</h2>
<div class="body"><p class="shortdesc">Understand vault and key management concepts for accessing and managing vaults and keys. </p>
<dl>
<dt class="dt dlterm" id="concepts__vaulttypes">Vaults</dt>
<dd class="dd">Vaults are logical entities where the Key Management service creates and durably stores vault keys and <a href="/iaas/Content/secret-management/home.htm">secrets</a>. The type of vault you have determines features and functionality such as degrees of storage isolation, access to management and encryption, scalability, and the ability to back up. The type of vault you have also affects pricing. You can't change a vault's type after you create the vault.</dd>
<dd class="dd ddexpand">The Key Management  service offers different vault types to accommodate your organization's needs and budget. All vault types ensure the security and integrity of the encryption keys and secrets that vaults store. A virtual private vault is an isolated partition on a hardware security module (HSM). Vaults otherwise share partitions on the HSM with other vaults.</dd>
<dd class="dd ddexpand">Virtual private vaults include 1000 key versions by default. If you don't require the greater degree of isolation or the ability to back up the vault, you don't need a virtual private vault. Without a virtual private vault, you can manage costs by paying for key versions individually, as you need them. (Key versions count toward your key limit and costs. A vault key always contains at least one active key version. Similarly, a secret always has at least one secret version. However, limits on secrets apply to the tenancy, rather than a vault.)</dd>
<dd class="dd ddexpand">
<p>For customers who have regulatory compliance to store keys outside Oracle cloud or any third-party cloud premises, OCI KMS now offers a functionality called External Key Management Service (External KMS). In External KMS, you can store and control master encryption keys (as external keys) on a third-party key management system hosted outside OCI. You can then use these keys for encrypting your data in Oracle. You can also disable your keys anytime. With the actual keys residing in the third-party key management system, you create only key references (associated with the key material) in OCI.</p>
</dd>
<dd class="dd ddexpand">
<p>
OCI KMS offers the Dedicated KMS, which is a customer-managed, highly available, single-tenant HSM partition resource as a service. It enables you to have greater control by owning the HSM partition and encrypted keys and the users in the partition. In a Dedicated KMS setup, the HSM Cluster comes with three HSM partitions by default, which are auto synchronized. You can manage keys and users in the HSMs integrated with OCI compute instances through Client utilities and PKCS #11 libraries. Dedicated KMS supports only HSM-protected keys and doesn't support Software protected keys. For cryptographic operations, the solution supports both symmetric and asymmetric encryption using AES, RSA, and ECDSA algorithms .</p>
</dd>
<dd class="dd ddexpand">The Vault service designates vaults as an Oracle Cloud Infrastructure resource.</dd>
<dt class="dt dlterm" id="concepts__keys">Keys</dt>
<dd class="dd">Keys are logical entities that represent one or more key versions, each of which contains cryptographic material. A vault key's cryptographic material is generated for a specific algorithm that lets you use the key for encryption or in digital signing. When used for encryption, a key or key pair encrypts and decrypts data, protecting the data where the data is stored or while the data is in transit. With an AES symmetric key, the same key encrypts and decrypts data. With an RSA asymmetric key, the public key encrypts data and the private key decrypts data.</dd>
<dd class="dd ddexpand">You can use AES keys in encryption and decryption, but not in digital signing.
                    RSA keys, however, can be used not only to encrypt and decrypt data, but also to
                    digitally sign data and verify the authenticity of signed data. You can use
                    ECDSA keys in digital signing, but not to encrypt or decrypt data.</dd>
<dd class="dd ddexpand">When processed as part of an encryption algorithm, a key specifies how to transform plaintext into ciphertext during encryption and how to transform ciphertext into plaintext during decryption. When processed as part of a signing algorithm, together, the private key of an asymmetric key and a message produce a digital signature that goes with the message in transit. When processed as part of a signature verifying algorithm by the recipient of the signed message, the message, signature, and the public key of the same asymmetric key confirm or deny the authenticity and integrity of the message.</dd>
<dd class="dd ddexpand">Conceptually, the Key Management  service recognizes three types of encryption keys: master encryption keys, wrapping keys, and data encryption keys.</dd>
<dd class="dd ddexpand">The encryption algorithms that the Key Management service supports for vault master encryption keys include AES, RSA, and ECDSA. You can create AES, RSA, or ECDSA master encryption keys by using the Console, CLI, or API. When you create a master encryption key, the Key Management service can either generate the key material internally or you can import the key material to the service from an external source. (Support for importing key material depends on the encryption algorithm of the key material.) When you create vault master encryption keys, you create them in a vault, but where a key is stored and processed depends on its protection mode.</dd>
<dd class="dd ddexpand">Vault master encryption keys can have one of two protection modes: HSM or software. A master encryption key protected by an HSM is stored on an HSM and can't be exported from the HSM. All cryptographic operations involving the key also happen on the HSM. Meanwhile, a master encryption key protected by software is stored on a server and, therefore, can be exported from the server to perform cryptographic operations on the client instead of on the server. While at rest, the software-protected key is encrypted by a root key on the HSM. For a software-protected key, any processing related to the key happens on the server. A key's protection mode affects pricing and can't be changed after you create the key.</dd>
<dd class="dd ddexpand">After you create your first symmetric master encryption key, you can then use the API to generate data encryption keys that the Key Management service returns to you. Note that a data encryption key needs to have equal or greater encryption strength than the master encryption key used to create it. Some services can use a symmetric master encryption key to generate their own data encryption keys.</dd>
<dd class="dd ddexpand">A type of encryption key that comes included with each vault by default is a wrapping key. A wrapping key is a 4096-bit asymmetric encryption key based on the RSA algorithm. The public and private key pair don't count against service limits. They also don't incur service costs. You use the public key as the key encryption key when you need to wrap key material for import into the Key Management service. You can't create, delete, or rotate wrapping keys.</dd>
<dd class="dd ddexpand">The Key Management service recognizes master encryption keys as an Oracle Cloud Infrastructure resource.</dd>
<dt class="dt dlterm" id="concepts__key-versions-and-rotations-section">Key Versions &amp; Rotations</dt>
<dd class="dd">Each master encryption key is automatically assigned a key version. When you rotate a key, the Key Management service generates a new key version. The Key Management service can generate the key material for the new key version or you can import your own key material.</dd>
<dd class="dd ddexpand">Periodically rotating keys limits the amount of data encrypted or signed by one key version. If a key is ever compromised, key rotation thus reduces the risk. A key's unique, Oracle-assigned identifier, called an Oracle Cloud ID (OCID), remains the same across rotations, but the key version lets the Key Management service seamlessly rotate keys to meet any compliance requirements you might have.</dd>
<dd class="dd ddexpand">Although you can't use an older key version for encryption after you rotate a key, the key version remains available to decrypt any data that it was used to encrypt. If you rotate an asymmetric key, the public key can no longer be used to encrypt data, but the private key remains available to decrypt data that was encrypted by the public key. When you rotate an asymmetric key used in digital signing, you can no longer use the private key version to sign data, but the public key version remains available to verify the digital signature of data previously signed by the older private key version.</dd>
<dd class="dd ddexpand">For symmetric keys, you don't need to track which key version was used to encrypt what data because the key's ciphertext contains the information that the service needs for decryption purposes. Through rotations of asymmetric keys, however, you must track which key version was used to encrypt or sign what data. With asymmetric keys, the key's ciphertext doesn't contain the information that the service requires for decryption or verification.</dd>
<dd class="dd ddexpand">With AES symmetric keys, each key version counts as one key version when
                    calculating service limits usage. However, with RSA and ECDSA asymmetric keys,
                    each key version counts as two when calculating usage against service limits
                    because an asymmetric key has both a public key and private key. (Asymmetric
                    keys are also known as key pairs.)</dd>
<dt class="dt dlterm" id="concepts__automatic-key-rotation-overview-section">Automatic Key Rotation</dt>
<dd class="dd">
<div id="concepts__automatic-key-rotation-overview-info">
<div class="uk-alert uk-alert-primary"><span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="file-edit"></span><strong> Note</strong><br/><br/> This feature is available only for private vaults.
                                    
                                    
                                </div>
<p>
OCI's Key Management service lets you schedule automatic key rotation for an encryption key in a virtual private vault. When you configure automatic rotation, you set the frequency of rotation and the start date of the rotation schedule. For the frequency, you chose a rotation interval between 60 days and 365 days. KMS supports automatic key rotation for both HSM and software keys, and supports automatic rotation of both symmetric and asymmetric keys. Note that a key must be in the "enabled" state to configure automatic rotation.</p>
<div class="p">Features and requirements of automatic key rotation:<ul>
<li>You can update the rotation schedule for a key after you enable automatic rotation, as needed.</li>
<li>You can rotate a key on-demand (perform a manual rotation) when automatic key rotation is enabled for the key.</li>
<li>You can track automatic key rotation activities for a key, including the last rotation status and status message, updates to the rotation interval, and next rotation start date.</li>
<li>You can send an event notification if a key rotation fails. 
                                        </li>
</ul>
</div>
<p>
<strong>Auto rotation event notification:</strong> To receive automatic key rotation event notifications, you must configure the OCI
Events service. After every key rotation, KMS sends out a notification about the rotation status and error messages, if any. The OCI
Events service lets you use events rules to invoke a function, which you can use for automation. For example, you can use functions to automate the following tasks:</p>
<ul>
<li>Re-encrypt data with a new key version</li>
<li>Delete an old key version</li>
<li>Distribute the public part of asymmetric keys for signing or verifying data</li>
</ul>
<p>See <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Events/Task/create-events-rule.htm">Creating an Events Rule</a> and <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Functions/Concepts/functionsoverview.htm">Overview of Functions</a> for more information.</p>
</div>
</dd>
<dt class="dt dlterm">Hardware Security Modules</dt>
<dd class="dd">When you create an AES symmetric master encryption key with the protection mode set to HSM, the Key Management service stores the key version within a hardware security module (HSM) to provide a layer of physical security. (When you create a secret, secret versions are base64-encoded and encrypted by a master encryption key, but are not stored within the HSM.) After you create the resources, the service maintains copies of any given key version or secret version within the service infrastructure to provide resilience against hardware failures. Key versions of HSM-protected keys aren't otherwise stored anywhere else and can't be exported from an HSM.</dd>
<dd class="dd ddexpand">When you create an RSA or ECDSA asymmetric master encryption key with the protection mode set to HSM, the Key Management service stores the private key within an HSM and doesn't allow its export from the HSM. However, you can download the public key.</dd>
<dd class="dd ddexpand">The Key Management service uses HSMs that meet Federal Information Processing Standards (FIPS) 140-2 Security Level 3 security certification. This certification means that the HSM hardware is tamper-evident, has physical safeguards for tamper-resistance, requires identity-based authentication, and deletes keys from the device when it detects tampering.</dd>
<dt class="dt dlterm">Envelope Encryption</dt>
<dd class="dd">The data encryption key used to encrypt your data is, itself, encrypted with a master encryption key. This concept is known as envelope encryption. Oracle Cloud Infrastructure services don't have access to the plaintext data without interacting with the Key Management service and without access to the master encryption key that's protected by Oracle Cloud Infrastructure Identity and Access Management (IAM). For decryption purposes, integrated services such as Object Storage, Block Volume, and File Storage store only the encrypted form of the data encryption key.</dd>
</dl>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title3" class="topic nested1" id="regions">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title3">Regions and Availability Domains</h2>
<div class="body">
<p>The Vault service is available in all Oracle Cloud Infrastructure commercial regions. See <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/General/Concepts/regions.htm#About">About Regions and Availability Domains</a> for the <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/General/Concepts/regions.htm#About__The">list</a> of available regions, along with associated locations, region identifiers, region keys, and availability domains.
</p>
<p>Unlike some Oracle Cloud Infrastructure services, however, the Vault service does not have one regional endpoint for all API operations. The service has one regional endpoint for the provisioning service that handles create, update, and list operations for vaults. For create, update, and list operations for keys, service endpoints are distributed across multiple independent clusters. Service endpoints for secrets are distributed further still across different independent clusters.</p>
<p>Because the Vault service has public endpoints, you can directly use data encryption keys generated by the service for cryptographic operations in your applications. However, if you want to use master encryption keys with a service that has integrated with Vault, you can do so only when the service and the vault that holds the key both exist within the same region. Different endpoints exist for key management operations, key cryptographic operations, secret management operations, and secret retrieval operations. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/api/">Oracle Cloud Infrastructure API Documentation</a>
</p>
<p>The Vault service maintains copies of vaults and their contents to durably persist them and to make it possible for the Vault service to produce keys or secrets upon request, even when an availability domain is unavailable. This replication is independent of any cross-region replication that a customer might configure.</p>
<p>For regions with multiple availability domains, the Vault service maintains copies of encryption keys across all availability domains within the region. Regions with multiple availability domains have one rack for each availability domain, which means that the replication happens across three total racks in these regions, where each rack belongs to a different availability domain. In regions with a single availability domain, the Vault service maintains encryption key copies across fault domains.</p>
<p>For secrets, in regions with multiple availability domains, the Vault service distributes secret copies across two different availability domains. In regions with a single availability domain, the Vault service distributes the copies across two different fault domains.</p>
<p>Every availability domain has three fault domains. Fault domains help provide high availability and fault tolerance by making it possible for the Vault service to distribute resources across different physical hardware within a given availability domain. The physical hardware itself also has independent and redundant power supplies that prevent a power outage in one fault domain from affecting other fault domains.</p>
<p>All of this makes it possible for the Vault service to produce keys and secrets upon request, even when an availability domain is unavailable in a region with multiple availability domains or when a fault domain is unavailable in a region with a single availability domain.</p>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title4" class="topic nested1" id="privateaccess">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title4">Private Access to Vault</h2>
<div class="body">
<p>The Vault service supports private access from Oracle Cloud Infrastructure resources in a virtual cloud network (VCN) through a service gateway. Setting up and using a service gateway on a VCN lets resources (such as the instances that your encrypted volumes are attached to) access public Oracle Cloud Infrastructure services such as the Vault service without exposing them to the public internet. No internet gateway is required and resources can be in a private subnet and use only private IP addresses. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Network/Tasks/servicegateway.htm">Access to Oracle Services: Service Gateway</a>.</p>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title5" class="topic nested1" id="resource">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title5">Resource Identifiers</h2>
<div class="body">
<p>The Vault service supports vaults, keys, and secrets as Oracle Cloud Infrastructure resources. Most types of Oracle Cloud Infrastructure resources have a unique, Oracle-assigned identifier called an Oracle Cloud ID (OCID). For information about the OCID format and other ways to identify your resources, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/General/Concepts/identifiers.htm">Resource Identifiers</a>..</p>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title6" class="topic nested1" id="access">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title6">Ways to Access Oracle Cloud Infrastructure</h2>
<div class="body"><p class="shortdesc">You can access the Oracle Cloud Infrastructure by entering your cloud account.</p>
<p>You can access Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI) by using the <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/GSG/Tasks/signingin_topic-Signing_In_for_the_First_Time.htm">Console</a> (a browser-based interface), <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/API/Concepts/usingapi.htm">REST API</a>, or <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/API/Concepts/cliconcepts.htm">OCI CLI</a>.<span id="access__ph_instructions"> Instructions for using the Console, API, and CLI are included in topics throughout this documentation.</span>
<span id="access__ph_sdks">For a list of available SDKs, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/API/Concepts/sdks.htm">Software Development Kits and Command Line Interface</a>.</span></p>
<p><span id="access__ph_console-access">To access <span id="access__ph_console-access-for-service">the <a class="xref" href="https://cloud.oracle.com/">Console</a>, you must use a <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/GSG/Tasks/signinginIdentityDomain.htm#supported-browsers">supported browser</a>. To go to the Console sign-in page, open the navigation menu at the top of this page and select <strong class="ph uicontrol">Infrastructure Console</strong>. You are prompted to enter your cloud tenant, your user name, and your password.</span></span></p>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title7" class="topic nested1" id="authentication">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title7">Authentication and Authorization</h2>
<div class="body">
<div>
<p>Each service in Oracle Cloud Infrastructure integrates with IAM for authentication and authorization, for all interfaces (the Console, SDK or CLI, and REST API).</p>
<p>An administrator in an organization needs to set up <strong title="A collection of users who all need a particular type of access to a set of resources or compartment." uk-tooltip="">groups <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong>, <strong title="A collection of related resources that can be accessed only by groups that have been given permission by an administrator in your organization. Compartments can have a hierarchical structure, allowing for the creation of parent compartments and child compartments (also referred to as subcompartments)." uk-tooltip="">compartments <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong>, and <strong title='An Identity and Access Management (IAM) document that specifies who has what type of access to your resources. Policy can refer to several types of documents: an individual statement written in the policy language, a collection of statements in a single named "policy" document, and the overall body of policies that your organization uses to control access to resources.' uk-tooltip="">policies <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong> that control which users can access which services, which resources, and the type of access. For example, the policies control who can create new users, create and manage the cloud network, create instances, create buckets, download objects, and so on. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Identity/domains/overview.htm">Managing Identity Domains</a>. For specific details about writing policies for each of the different services, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Identity/Reference/policyreference.htm">Policy Reference</a>. </p>
<p>If you're a regular user (not an administrator) who needs to use the Oracle Cloud Infrastructure resources that the company owns, contact an administrator to set up a user ID for you. The administrator can confirm which compartment or compartments you can use.</p>
</div>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title8" class="topic nested1" id="events">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title8">Creating Automation with Events</h2>
<div class="body">
<p>
You can create automation based on state changes for Oracle Cloud Infrastructure resources by using event types, rules, and actions. <span id="events__ph_pointertoevents">For more information, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Events/Concepts/eventsoverview.htm">Overview of Events</a>.</span>
</p>
<p>See <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/event_notification.htm" title="Learn about Key Management event notifications for success and failure scenarios." uk-tooltip="">Events for Vaults and Keys</a> for more information.</p>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title9" class="topic nested1" id="limits">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title9">Limits on Vault Resources</h2>
<div class="body"><p class="shortdesc">Know the Vault Service limitation and its resource usage before you begin to use them. </p>
<p>
For a list of applicable limits and <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/General/Concepts/servicelimits-request-increase.htm">instructions for requesting a limit increase</a>, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/General/Concepts/servicelimits.htm">Limits by Service</a>. To set compartment-specific limits on a resource or resource family, administrators can use <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Quotas/Concepts/resourcequotas.htm">compartment quotas</a>.
</p>
<p>For instructions to view your usage level against the tenancy's resource limits, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/General/Concepts/servicelimits-view-tenancy.htm">Viewing a Tenancy's Limits and Usage</a>. You can also get each individual vault's usage against key limits by viewing key and key version counts in the vault details.</p>
</div>
</article>
</article>
</article>

<h1>vault<a class="headerlink" href="#vault" title="Permalink to this headline">¶</a></h1>
<div class="section" id="description">
<h2>Description<a class="headerlink" href="#description" title="Permalink to this headline">¶</a></h2>
<p>Use the Secret Management CLI to manage secrets and secret versions. For more information, see <a class="reference external" href="https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/Content/KeyManagement/Tasks/managingsecrets.htm">Managing Secrets</a>. To retrieve secrets from vaults, see <a href="#id1"><span class="problematic" id="id2">`</span></a>Vault Service Secret Retrieval (secrets) &lt;<a class="reference external" href="https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/iaas/tools/oci-cli/latest/oci_cli_docs/cmdref/secrets.html">https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/iaas/tools/oci-cli/latest/oci_cli_docs/cmdref/secrets.html</a>&gt;</p>
</div>

<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title1" class="topic nested0" id="Managing_Keys">
<h1 class="title topictitle1" id="ariaid-title1">Managing Keys</h1>
<div class="body"><p class="shortdesc">Create and manage vault keys and key versions.</p>
<p> For information about creating vault keys with your own key material, see <a class="xref" href="importingkeys.htm" title="When you use imported key material, you remain responsible for the key material while allowing the Vault service to use a copy of it." uk-tooltip="">Importing Vault Keys and Key Versions</a>. For information about assigning keys to protect supported resources, see <a class="xref" href="assigningkeys.htm" title="Assign master encryption keys to supported resources and remove them when they are not needed anymore." uk-tooltip="">Assigning Master Encryption Keys</a>. For information about how you can use keys in cryptographic operations, see <a class="xref" href="usingkeys.htm" title="Use the vault master encryption keys for cryptographic operations." uk-tooltip="">Using Keys</a>. For information about backing up and restoring keys, see <a class="xref" href="backingupvaultsandkeys.htm" title="Learn about backing up and restoring virtual private vaults and master encryption keys in a Hardware Security Module (HSM)." uk-tooltip="">Backing Up and Restoring Vaults and Keys</a>. For information about what you can do with vaults where you store keys, see <a class="xref" href="managingvaults.htm" title="Create and manage vaults as logical containers for encrypting keys and secrets." uk-tooltip="">Managing Vaults</a>. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="../Concepts/keyoverview.htm#concepts" title="Understand vault and key management concepts for accessing and managing vaults and keys." uk-tooltip="">Vault and Key Management Concepts</a>.</p>
<p>Managing vault keys include the following configurations:</p>
<ul>
<li class="keepWithNext">
<a class="xref" href="managingkeys_topic-To_create_a_new_key.htm" title="Learn how to create a master encryption key in OCI's Key Management service." uk-tooltip="">Create a key</a>
</li>
<li>
<a class="xref" href="managingkeys_topic-To_view_key_details.htm" title="Learn how to get the details information for a master encryption key." uk-tooltip="">View key details</a>
</li>
<li>
<a class="xref" href="managingkeys_topic-To_view_a_list_of_keys.htm" title="Learn how to navigate to the list view for keys in the OCI Console." uk-tooltip="">View a list of keys</a>
</li>
<li>
<a class="xref" href="managingkeys_topic-To_view_a_list_of_key_versions.htm" title="Learn how to view a list of key versions for a specified master encryption key." uk-tooltip="">View a list of key versions for a specific key</a>
</li>
<li>
<a class="xref" href="managingkeys_topic-To_enable_a_key.htm" title="Learn how to enable a specified master encryption key." uk-tooltip="">Enable keys for use in vault cryptographic operations</a>
</li>
<li>
<a class="xref" href="managingkeys_topic-To_rotate_a_master_encryption_key.htm" title="Learn how to rotate a key by creating a new key version." uk-tooltip="">Rotate keys to generate vault cryptographic material</a>
</li>
<li>
<a class="xref" href="managingkeys_topic-To_disable_a_key.htm" title="Learn how to disable a specified master encryption key. Note that when you disable a key, any data or resources that use the key are unusable." uk-tooltip="">Disable keys to prevent their usage in vault cryptographic operations</a>
</li>
<li>
<a class="xref" href="managingkeys_topic-To_delete_a_key.htm" title="Learn how to schedule the deletion of a master encryption key stored in an OCI vault." uk-tooltip="">Delete keys to permanently prevent their usage in vault cryptographic operations or assignment to resources</a>
</li>
<li>
<a class="xref" href="managingkeys_topic-To_move_a_key_to_a_different_compartment.htm" title="Learn how to move a master encryption key to a different compartment." uk-tooltip="">Move a key to a new compartment</a>
</li>
</ul>
<div class="p">
<div class="uk-alert uk-alert-primary"><span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="file-edit"></span><strong> Note</strong><br/><br/> For enhanced control and visibility over your vault encryption keys, the External Key Management (EKM) feature in Vault enables you to manage your keys in a third-party key management system outside of Oracle cloud. To enable EKM in your tenancy, contact Oracle sales.</div>
</div>
</div>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title2" class="topic nested1" id="permissions">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title2">Required IAM Policy</h2>
<div class="body">
<div>Open the navigation menu, select <strong><strong class="ph uicontrol">Identity &amp; Security</strong></strong>, and then select <strong><strong class="ph uicontrol">Vault</strong></strong>." </div>
<p>If you're new to policies, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Identity/domains/overview.htm">Managing Identity Domains</a> and <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Identity/Concepts/commonpolicies.htm">Common Policies</a>.</p>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title3" class="topic nested1" id="tagging">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title3">Tagging Keys</h2>
<div class="body">
<p>Apply tags to resources to help organize them according to your business needs. You can apply tags when you create a resource, and you can update a resource later to add, revise, or remove tags. For general information about applying tags, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/General/Concepts/resourcetags.htm">Resource Tags</a>.</p>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title4" class="topic nested1" id="monitoring">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title4">Monitoring Resources</h2>
<div class="body"><p class="shortdesc">This section describes how to monitor your Vault resources.</p>
<p>You can monitor your vault resources.</p>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title5" class="topic nested1" id="movingresources">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title5">Moving Resources to a Different Compartment</h2>
<div class="body"><p class="shortdesc">Learn how to move Vault resources such as keys to different compartment.</p>
<p>You can move keys from one compartment to another. After you move a key to a new compartment, inherent policies apply immediately and affect access to the key and key versions. Moving a key doesn't affect access to the vault that a key is associated with. Similarly, you can move a vault from one compartment to another independently of moving any of its keys. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Identity/Tasks/managingcompartments.htm">Managing Compartments</a>.</p>
</div>
</article>
</article>
</article>

<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title1" role="article">
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title1" class="topic concept nested0" id="overview">
<h1 class="title topictitle1" id="ariaid-title1">Overview of Generative AI Service</h1>
<div class="body conbody"><p class="shortdesc">
Generative AI is a fully managed Oracle Cloud Infrastructure service that provides a set of state-of-the-art, customizable large language models (LLMs) that cover a wide range of use cases, including chat, text generation, summarization, rerank, and creating text embeddings.</p>
<p> Use the <a class="xref" href="use-playground.htm" title="The playground is an interface in the Oracle Cloud Console for exploring the hosted pretrained and custom models in OCI Generative AI without writing a single line of code. Use the playground to test your use cases and refine prompts and parameters. When you're happy with the results, integrate the generated code into your applications." uk-tooltip=""> playground</a>, the API, or the CLI to try out
      the ready-to-use pretrained models  or create and host your own fine-tuned custom models based
      on your own data on dedicated AI clusters.</p>
<p>The OCI
Generative AI service includes the following foundational models for chat, rerank, and text embeddings.</p>
<dl>
<dt class="dt dlterm">Chat</dt>
<dd class="dd">Ask questions and get conversational responses through an AI chatbot.</dd>
</dl>
<dl>
<dt class="dt dlterm">Rerank</dt>
<dd class="dd">Input a query and a list of texts and get an ordered array with each text assigned a relevance score. The relevance score is how the model ranks the documents, that's, how well each text matches the query.</dd>
</dl>
<dl>
<dt class="dt dlterm">Embedding</dt>
<dd class="dd">Convert text to vector embeddings to use in applications for semantic searches, recommender systems, text classification, or text clustering.</dd>
</dl>
</div>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title2" class="topic concept nested1" id="use-pretrained-models">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title2">Using the Pretrained Foundational Models</h2>
<div class="body conbody"><p class="shortdesc">To get started, use the playground to try the pretrained foundational models. Run your prompts, adjust the parameters, update your prompts, and rerun the models until you're happy with the results. Then get the code from the Console and copy the code into your applications.</p>
<p>
<div uk-lightbox=""><a href="images/scenario-1.png"><img alt="User workflow options for using the Generative AI service ready-to-use pretrained models." src="images/scenario-1.png" tabindex="" title="Click to expand"/></a></div>
</p>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title3" class="topic concept nested1" id="fine-tune-pretrained-models">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title3">Fine-Tuning the Pretrained Models</h2>
<div class="body conbody"><p class="shortdesc">You can create a copy of a pretrained foundational model, add your own training dataset, and let the OCI
Generative AI service fine-tune the model for you. OCI
Generative AI uses dedicated AI clusters specially sized for fine-tuning. These clusters belong only to your tenancy. After your model is fine-tuned, you create an endpoint for the custom model and host that model on a dedicated AI cluster that's designed for hosting. When you create the hosting cluster, select the correct pretrained model from which the fine-tuned model is derived from.</p>
<p>
<div uk-lightbox=""><a href="images/scenario-2.png"><img alt="User workflow options for using the Generative AI service for fine-tuning a pretrained model and hosting the fine-tuned model through an endpoint." src="images/scenario-2.png" tabindex="" title="Click to expand"/></a></div>
</p>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title4" class="topic concept nested1" id="use-cases">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title4">Use Cases</h2>
<div class="body conbody"><p class="shortdesc">Use the OCI
Generative AI service for the following types of use cases.</p>
<dl>
<dt class="dt dlterm">Text Generation</dt>
<dd class="dd">
<p>Use the pretrained chat models or text generation models to create text for any
            purpose, for example:</p>
<ul>
<li>Pitch for a new product</li>
<li>Slogan for a marketing campaign</li>
<li>Sales email to a client</li>
<li>Social media post</li>
<li>Job description</li>
<li>Title for an article</li>
</ul>
</dd>
</dl>
<dl>
<dt class="dt dlterm">Conversation</dt>
<dd class="dd">
<p>You can ask questions in natural language and optionally submit text such as documents,
            emails, and product reviews to the LLM and the LLM reasons over the text and provides
            intelligent answers.</p>
</dd>
</dl>
<dl>
<dt class="dt dlterm">Data Extraction</dt>
<dd class="dd">
<p>Extract specific pieces of data from text, for example:</p>
<ul>
<li>Extract applicant information from an application written in free-form text.</li>
<li>Extract dates or sums from a contract.</li>
<li>Extract insights or trends from data tables.</li>
</ul>
</dd>
</dl>
<dl>
<dt class="dt dlterm">Summarization</dt>
<dd class="dd">
<p>Generate executive summaries for documents that are too long to read, or summarize any type of text, for example:</p>
<ul>
<li>Documents</li>
<li>Contracts</li>
<li>Emails</li>
<li>Articles</li>
<li>Blog posts</li>
<li>Product reviews</li>
<li>Social media posts</li>
</ul>
</dd>
</dl>
<dl>
<dt class="dt dlterm">Classification</dt>
<dd class="dd">
<p>Classify text into predefined categories, for example:</p>
<ul>
<li>Given a list of support tickets, classify them by the department that should handle them.</li>
<li>Given a list of sectors and company names, classify the companies by their respective sectors.</li>
</ul>
</dd>
</dl>
<dl>
<dt class="dt dlterm">Style Transfer</dt>
<dd class="dd">
<p>Change the style or tone of text, for example:</p>
<ul>
<li>Rewrite any text in a different style, format (list or paragraphs), or tone.</li>
<li>Rephrase text.</li>
<li>Suggest grammatical improvements.</li>
</ul>
</dd>
</dl>
<dl>
<dt class="dt dlterm">Semantic Similarity</dt>
<dd class="dd">
<p>Evaluate several inputs based on how similar their meaning is, for example:</p>
<ul>
<li>Evaluate a list of questions sent to a support system to extract the most relevant answer given to similar questions in the past when a new question comes in.</li>
<li>Replace keyword-based searches with semantic searches to improve search results relevance.</li>
</ul>
</dd>
</dl>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title5" class="topic concept nested1" id="regions">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title5">Regions with Generative AI
</h2>
<div class="body conbody"><p class="shortdesc">Oracle hosts its OCI services in regions and availability domains. A region is a localized geographic area, and an availability domain is one or more data centers in that region.</p>
<div class="uk-alert uk-alert-success"><span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="check"></span><strong> Important</strong><br/><br/> For a complete list of available regions, see <a class="xref" href="regions.htm#regions" title="Oracle hosts its OCI services in regions and availability domains. A region is a localized geographic area, and an availability domain is one or more data centers in that region. This page provides a list of regions where OCI Generative AI models are available." uk-tooltip="">Generative AI Regions</a> and to find out which models are available in a region near you.<a class="xref" href="model-endpoint-regions.htm#top" title="This page provides a list of regions where OCI Generative AI models are available. Select each model for its details." uk-tooltip="">Generative AI Models by Region</a> t</div>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title6" class="topic concept nested1" id="cross-region-call">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title6">Services that Call into the Generative AI Service</h2>
<div class="body conbody">
<div class="uk-alert uk-alert-success"><span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="check"></span><strong> Important</strong><br/><br/> See <a class="xref" href="regions.htm#regions" title="Oracle hosts its OCI services in regions and availability domains. A region is a localized geographic area, and an availability domain is one or more data centers in that region. This page provides a list of regions where OCI Generative AI models are available." uk-tooltip="">Generative AI Regions</a>.</div>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title7" class="topic task nested1" id="access-generative-ai">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title7">Accessing Generative AI in the Console
</h2>
<div class="body taskbody">
<section><ol class="ol steps"><li class="li step">
<span class="ph cmd">Sign in to the <a class="xref" href="https://cloud.oracle.com/">
Console
</a> by using a <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/GSG/Tasks/signinginIdentityDomain.htm#supported-browsers">supported browser</a>.</span>
</li><li class="li step">
<span class="ph cmd">
In the navigation bar of the Console, select a region with Generative AI, for example, <strong class="ph uicontrol">US Midwest (Chicago)</strong>. See <a class="xref" href="common/../pretrained-models.htm" title="OCI Generative AI offers the following pretrained foundational models. Review the key features, regions, on-demand and dedicated AI cluster offerings, deprecation and retirement dates, and benchmarks for the models." uk-tooltip="">which models are offered in your region</a>.
</span>
</li><li class="li step">
<span class="ph cmd">
Open the <strong title="Main menu located in the upper-left corner of the Oracle Cloud Console. Use the menu to navigate to OCI services, dashboards, and marketplace." uk-tooltip="">navigation menu <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong> and select <strong class="ph uicontrol">Analytics &amp; AI</strong>. Under <strong class="ph uicontrol">AI Services</strong>, select <strong class="ph uicontrol">Generative AI</strong>.
</span>
</li></ol></section>
</div>
</article>
</article>
</article>
