  <div class="section" id="generative-ai">
<h1>generative-ai<a class="headerlink" href="#generative-ai" title="Permalink to this headline">¶</a></h1>
<div class="section" id="description">
<h2>Description<a class="headerlink" href="#description" title="Permalink to this headline">¶</a></h2>
<p>OCI Generative AI is a fully managed service that provides a set of state-of-the-art, customizable large language models (LLMs) that cover a wide range of use cases for text generation, summarization, and text embeddings.</p>
<p>Use the Generative AI service management CLI to create and manage <a class="reference external" href="https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/api/#/en/generative-ai/latest/DedicatedAiCluster/">dedicated AI clusters</a>, <a class="reference external" href="https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/api/#/en/generative-ai/latest/Endpoint/">endpoints</a>, <a class="reference external" href="https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/api/#/en/generative-ai/latest/Model/">custom models</a>, and <a class="reference external" href="https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/api/#/en/generative-ai/latest/WorkRequest/">work requests</a> in the Generative AI service. For example, create a custom model by fine-tuning an out-of-the-box model using your own data, on a fine-tuning dedicated AI cluster. Then, create a hosting dedicated AI cluster with an endpoint to host your custom model.</p>
<p>To access your custom model endpoints, or to try the out-of-the-box models to generate text, summarize, and create text embeddings see the [Generative AI Inference CLI].</p>
<p>To learn more about the service, see the <a class="reference external" href="https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/iaas/Content/generative-ai/home.htm">Generative AI documentation</a>.</p>
</div>

<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title1" role="article">
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title1" class="topic nested0" id="pretrained-models">
<h1 class="title topictitle1" id="ariaid-title1">Offered Pretrained Foundational Models in Generative AI</h1>
<div class="body"><p class="shortdesc">OCI
Generative AI offers the following pretrained foundational models. Review the key features, regions, on-demand and dedicated AI cluster offerings, deprecation and retirement dates, and benchmarks for the models.</p>
<div class="uk-alert uk-alert-primary"><span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="file-edit"></span><strong> Note</strong><br/><br/> For a list of models by region, see <a class="xref" href="model-endpoint-regions.htm" title="This page provides a list of regions where OCI Generative AI models are available. Select each model for its details." uk-tooltip="">Generative AI Models by Region</a>.</div>
</div>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title2" class="topic nested1" id="chat-models">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title2">Chat Models</h2>
<div class="body">
<p>Chat models let you ask questions and get conversational, in-context answers from AI. Select from several model families in OCI
Generative AI to balance speed, quality, and cost for the use case. </p>
</div>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title3" class="topic nested2" id="cohere-models">
<h3 class="title topictitle3" id="ariaid-title3">Cohere Models</h3>
<div class="body">
<ul>
<li><a class="xref" href="cohere-command-a-reasoning-08-2025.htm" title="Released in August 2025, Cohere Command A Reasoning (cohere.command-a-reasoning-08-2025) is Cohere's flagship 111-billion parameter large language model designed for advanced enterprise reasoning, agentic workflows, and tool use. This model is designed for tasks that demand advanced logical processing, in-depth analysis, and multi-step reasoning, such as comprehensive Q&amp;A, intricate document review, and creating structured arguments. The model supports a 256,000 token context window, making it ideal for large-scale data analysis and agentic workflows." uk-tooltip="">Cohere Command A Reasoning</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="cohere-command-a-vision-07-2025.htm" title="Released in July 2025, Cohere Command A Vision (cohere.command-a-vision-07-2025) is an enterprise-focused multimodal large language model that excels at understanding and interpreting visual data (images, charts, document) alongside text." uk-tooltip="">Cohere Command A Vision</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="cohere-command-a-03-2025.htm" title="As of March 2025, the cohere.command-a-03-2025 model is the most performant Cohere chat model than its predecessor Cohere models with better throughput than cohere.command-r-08-2024. This model performs great for agentic enterprise tasks, and has significantly improved compute efficiency and has a 256,000 token context length." uk-tooltip="">Cohere Command A</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="cohere-command-r-08-2024.htm" title="The cohere.command-r-08-2024 model is optimized for complex tasks, offers advanced language understanding, higher capacity and more nuanced responses than cohere.command-r, and can maintain context from its long conversation history of 128,000 tokens. This model is also ideal for question-answering, sentiment analysis, and information retrieval." uk-tooltip="">Cohere Command R (08-2024)</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="cohere-command-r-plus-08-2024.htm" title="The cohere.command-r-plus-08-2024 model is optimized for complex tasks, offers advanced language understanding, higher capacity and more nuanced responses than cohere.command-r-plus, and can maintain context from its long conversation history of 128,000 tokens. This model is also ideal for question-answering, sentiment analysis, and information retrieval." uk-tooltip="">Cohere Command R+ (08-2024)</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="cohere-command-r-16k.htm" title="The cohere.command-r-16k (Command R) model is an excellent choice for those looking for a more affordable and flexible option for general language tasks. On the other hand, Command R+ is designed for power users who require advanced language understanding, higher capacity, and more nuanced responses. The choice between the two would depend on the specific requirements and budget of your application." uk-tooltip="">Cohere Command R (Retired)</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="cohere-command-r-plus.htm" title="The Command R+ model is optimized for complex tasks, offers advanced language understanding, higher capacity, and more nuanced responses than cohere.command-r-16k. Also ideal for question-answering, sentiment analysis, and information retrieval." uk-tooltip="">Cohere Command R+ (Retired)</a></li>
</ul>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title4" class="topic nested2" id="google-models">
<h3 class="title topictitle3" id="ariaid-title4">Google Models</h3>
<div class="body">
<ul>
<li><a class="xref" href="google-gemini-2-5-pro.htm" title="The Google Gemini 2.5 Pro (google.gemini-2.5-pro) is a reasoning, multimodal model that excels at solving complex problems and is the most advanced reasoning Gemini model to date. This model is the next iteration and preforms better than the Gemini 2.0 series. The Google Gemini 2.5 Pro is great at understanding large datasets and complex problems from different types of input, such as text, images, and code." uk-tooltip="">Google Gemini 2.5 Pro</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="google-gemini-2-5-flash.htm" title="The Gemini 2.5 Flash model (google.gemini-2.5-flash) is a multimodal fast reasoning model that offers a balance of price, performance, and a wide range of capabilities, including thinking features. Gemini 2.5 Flash and Gemini 2.5 Flash-Lite models are both efficient models. Flash-Lite is optimized for lower cost and faster performance on high-volume, less complex tasks. Gemini 2.5 Flash offers a balance of speed and intelligence for more complex applications." uk-tooltip="">Google Gemini 2.5 Flash</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="google-gemini-2-5-flash-lite.htm" title="The Google Gemini 2.5 Flash Lite model (google.gemini-2.5-flash-lite) is the fastest and most budget-friendly multimodal reasoning model in the 2.5 family, optimized for low latency. Gemini 2.5 Flash and Google Gemini 2.5 Flash Litemodels are both efficient models. Flash-Lite is optimized for lower cost and faster performance on high-volume, less complex tasks. Gemini 2.5 Flash offers a balance of speed and intelligence for more complex applications." uk-tooltip="">Google Gemini 2.5 Flash-Lite</a></li>
</ul>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title5" class="topic nested2" id="meta-models">
<h3 class="title topictitle3" id="ariaid-title5">Meta Models</h3>
<div class="body">
<ul>
<li><a class="xref" href="meta-llama-4-maverick.htm" title="The Llama 4 models leverage a Mixture of Experts (MoE) architecture, enabling efficient and powerful processing capabilities. These models are optimized for multimodal understanding, multilingual tasks, coding, tool-calling, and powering agentic systems. See the following sections for details about the meta.llama-4-maverick-17b-128e-instruct-fp8 model." uk-tooltip="">Meta Llama 4 Maverick</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="meta-llama-4-scout.htm" title="The Llama 4 models leverage a Mixture of Experts (MoE) architecture, enabling efficient and powerful processing capabilities. These models are optimized for multimodal understanding, multilingual tasks, coding, tool-calling, and powering agentic systems. See the following sections for details about the meta.llama-4-scout-17b-16e-instruct model." uk-tooltip="">Meta Llama 4 Scout</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="meta-llama-3-3-70b.htm" title="The meta.llama-3.3-70b-instruct model is available for on-demand inferencing, dedicated hosting, and fine-tuning, and delivers better performance than Llama 3.1 70B and Llama 3.2 90B for text tasks." uk-tooltip="">Meta Llama 3.3 (70B)</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="meta-llama-3-2-90b.htm" title="The meta.llama-3.2-90b-vision-instruct model offers text and image understanding features and is available for on-demand inferencing and dedicated hosting." uk-tooltip="">Meta Llama 3.2 90B Vision</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="meta-llama-3-2-11b.htm" title="The meta.llama-3.2-11b-vision-instruct model offers text and image understanding features and is available for dedicated hosting. Compared to Llama 3.2 90B Vision, Llama 3.2 11B Vision provides robust multimodal capabilities in a more compact form." uk-tooltip="">Meta Llama 3.2 11B Vision</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="meta-llama-3-1-405b.htm" title="The meta.llama-3.1-405b-instruct model is available for on-demand inferencing, dedicated hosting, and fine-tuning, and delivers better performance than Llama 3.1 70B and Llama 3.2 90B for text tasks." uk-tooltip="">Meta Llama 3.1 (405B)</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="meta-llama-3-1-70b.htm" title="The meta.llama-3.1-70b-instruct model is available for on-demand inferencing, dedicated hosting, and fine-tuning, and is perfect for content creation, conversational AI, and enterprise applications. Its key strengths include:" uk-tooltip="">Meta Llama 3.1 (70B) (Retired)</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="meta-llama-3-70b.htm" title="The meta.llama-3-70b-instruct model is retired." uk-tooltip="">Meta Llama 3 (70B)</a></li>
</ul>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title6" class="topic nested2" id="openai-models">
<h3 class="title topictitle3" id="ariaid-title6">OpenAI Models</h3>
<div class="body">
<ul>
<li><a class="xref" href="openai-gpt-oss-120b.htm" title="OCI Generative AI supports access to the pretrained OpenAI gpt-oss-120b model." uk-tooltip="">OpenAI gpt-oss-120b</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="openai-gpt-oss-20b.htm" title="OCI Generative AI supports access to the pretrained OpenAI gpt-oss-20b model." uk-tooltip="">OpenAI gpt-oss-20b</a></li>
</ul>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title7" class="topic nested2" id="xai-models">
<h3 class="title topictitle3" id="ariaid-title7">xAI Models</h3>
<div class="body">
<ul>
<li><a class="xref" href="xai-grok-code-fast-1.htm" title="Released in late August 2025, the xAI Grok Code Fast 1 model is a coding‑focused AI model that excels at common, high-volume coding task and is designed especially for agentic coding workflows. With its speed, efficiency, and low cost, this model is built to handle the loop of modern software development (planning, writing, testing, and debugging), offers real-time, summarized trace of its reasoning, and is proficient in TypeScript, Python, Java, Rust, C++, and Go. Use this model for building zero‑to‑one projects, answering codebase questions, performing bug fixes, and agentic coding." uk-tooltip="">xAI Grok Code Fast 1</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="xai-grok-4-1-fast.htm" title="The xAI Grok 4.1 Fast model improves upon xAI Grok 4 Fast primarily through specialized training for agentic workflows, offering reduced hallucinations (cut by ~3x), better tool-calling, parallel processing, and a massive 2 million token context window, making this model superior for complex, real-world tasks such as customer support and research, while maintaining high speed and enhanced factual accuracy. This model is optimized for performance and reliability in autonomous agent systems." uk-tooltip="">xAI Grok 4.1 Fast</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="xai-grok-4-fast.htm" title="The xAI Grok 4 Fast model is a speed- and cost-optimized version of the xAI Grok 4 model. Similar to Grok 4, this model excels at enterprise use cases such as data extraction, coding, and summarizing text, and has a deep domain knowledge in finance, healthcare, law, and science." uk-tooltip="">xAI Grok 4 Fast</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="xai-grok-4.htm" title="The xai.grok-4 model has better performance than its predecessor, Grok 3, and excels at enterprise use cases such as data extraction, coding, and summarizing text. This model has a deep domain knowledge in finance, healthcare, law, and science." uk-tooltip="">xAI Grok 4</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="xai-grok-3.htm" title="The xai.grok-3 model excels at enterprise use cases such as data extraction, coding, and summarizing text. This model has a deep domain knowledge in finance, healthcare, law, and science." uk-tooltip="">xAI Grok 3</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="xai-grok-3-mini.htm" title="The xai.grok-3-mini model is a lightweight model that thinks before responding. Fast, smart, and great for logic-based tasks that don't require deep domain knowledge. The raw thinking traces are accessible." uk-tooltip="">xAI Grok 3 Mini</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="xai-grok-3-fast.htm" title="The xai.grok-3-fast model excels at enterprise use cases such as data extraction, coding, and summarizing text. This model has a deep domain knowledge in finance, healthcare, law, and science." uk-tooltip="">xAI Grok 3 Fast</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="xai-grok-3-mini-fast.htm" title="The xai.grok-3-mini-fast model is a lightweight model that thinks before responding. Fast, smart, and great for logic-based tasks that don't require deep domain knowledge. The raw thinking traces are accessible." uk-tooltip="">xAI Grok 3 Mini Fast</a></li>
</ul>
</div>
</article>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title8" class="topic nested1" id="embed-models">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title8">Embed Models</h2>
<div class="body">
<ul>
<li><a class="xref" href="cohere-embed-4.htm" title="The cohere.embed-v4.0 is a multimodal model that can create text embeddings either from text inputs or from an image. Image input isn't available in the Console and you must use the API. For API, input a base64 encoded image in each run. For example, a 512 x 512 image is converted to about 1,610 tokens." uk-tooltip="">Cohere Embed 4</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="cohere-embed-english-image-3.htm" title="The cohere.embed-english-image-v3.0 is a multimodal model that can create text embeddings either from text inputs or from an image. Image input isn't available in the Console and you must use the API. For API, input a base64 encoded image in each run. For example, a 512 x 512 image is converted to about 1,610 tokens." uk-tooltip="">Cohere Embed English Image 3</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="cohere-embed-english-light-image-3.htm" title="The cohere.embed-english-light-image-v3.0 is a multimodal model that can create text embeddings either from text inputs or from an image. Image input isn't available in the Console and you must use the API. For API, input a base64 encoded image in each run. For example, a 512 x 512 image is converted to about 1,610 tokens." uk-tooltip="">Cohere Embed English Light Image 3</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="cohere-embed-multilingual-image-3.htm" title="The cohere.embed-multilingual-image-v3.0 is a multimodal model that can create text embeddings either from text inputs or from an image. Image input isn't available in the Console and you must use the API. For API, input a base64 encoded image in each run. For example, a 512 x 512 image is converted to about 1,610 tokens." uk-tooltip="">Cohere Embed Multilingual Image 3</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="cohere-embed-multilingual-light-image-3.htm" title="The cohere.embed-multilingual-light-image-v3.0 is a multimodal model that can create text embeddings either from text inputs or from an image. Image input isn't available in the Console and you must use the API. For API, input a base64 encoded image in each run. For example, a 512 x 512 image is converted to about 1,610 tokens." uk-tooltip="">Cohere Embed Multilingual Light Image 3</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="cohere-embed-english-3.htm" title="The cohere.embed-english-v3.0 model transforms each phrase, sentence, or paragraph that you input, into an array." uk-tooltip="">Cohere Embed English 3</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="cohere-embed-english-light-3.htm" title="The cohere.embed-english-light-v3.0 model transforms each phrase, sentence, or paragraph that you input, into an array." uk-tooltip="">Cohere Embed English Light 3</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="cohere-embed-multilingual-3.htm" title="The cohere.embed-multilingual-v3.0 model transforms each phrase, sentence, or paragraph that you input, into an array." uk-tooltip="">Cohere Embed Multilingual 3</a></li>
<li><a class="xref" href="cohere-embed-multilingual-light-3.htm" title="The cohere.embed-multilingual-light-v3.0 model transforms each phrase, sentence, or paragraph that you input, into an array." uk-tooltip="">Cohere Embed Multilingual Light 3</a></li>
</ul>
</div>
</article>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title9" class="topic nested1" id="rerank-models">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title9">Rerank Model</h2>
<div class="body">
<ul>
<li><a class="xref" href="cohere-rerank-3-5.htm" title="The cohere.rerank.v3-5 model takes in a query and a list of texts and produces an ordered array with each text assigned a relevance score. The relevance score is how the model ranks the documents, that's, how well each text matches the query." uk-tooltip="">Cohere Rerank 3.5</a></li>
</ul>
</div>
</article>

<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title1" role="article"><article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title1" class="topic nested0" id="Overview_of_Oracle_Cloud_Infrastructure_Identity_and_Access_Management">
<h1 class="title topictitle1" id="ariaid-title1">Overview of Identity and Access Management</h1>
<div class="body">
<p>Oracle Cloud Infrastructure Identity and Access Management (IAM) lets you control who has access to your cloud resources. You can control what type of access a group of users have and to which specific resources. This section gives you an overview of IAM components and an example scenario to help you understand how they work together.</p>
<div class="uk-alert uk-alert-primary"><span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="file-edit"></span><strong> Note</strong><br/><br/> This document uses the term "you" broadly to mean any administrator in your company who has access to work with IAM. </div>
</div>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title2" class="topic nested1" id="Componen">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title2">IAM Components</h2>
<div class="body">
<p>IAM uses the components described in this section. To better understand how the components fit together, see <a class="xref" href="overview.htm#Example">Example Scenario</a>.</p>
<dl>
<dt class="dt dlterm">RESOURCE</dt>
<dd class="dd">The cloud objects that your company's employees create and use when interacting with Oracle Cloud Infrastructure. For example: compute instances, block storage volumes, virtual cloud networks (VCNs), subnets, route tables, etc.</dd>
<dt class="dt dlterm">USER</dt>
<dd class="dd">An individual employee or system that needs to manage or use your company's Oracle Cloud Infrastructure resources. Users might need to launch instances, manage remote disks, work with your virtual cloud network, etc. End users of your application are not typically IAM users. Users have one or more IAM credentials (see <a class="xref" href="usercredentials.htm#User_Credentials">User Credentials</a>). </dd>
<dt class="dt dlterm">GROUP</dt>
<dd class="dd">A collection of users who all need the same type of access to a particular set of resources or compartment.</dd>
<dt class="dt dlterm">DYNAMIC GROUP</dt>
<dd class="dd">A special type of group that contains resources (such as compute instances) that match rules that you define (thus the membership can change dynamically as matching resources are created or deleted). These instances act as "principal" actors and can make API calls to  services according to  policies that you write for the dynamic group.</dd>
<dt class="dt dlterm">NETWORK SOURCE</dt>
<dd class="dd">A group of IP addresses that are allowed to access resources  in your tenancy.  The IP addresses can be public IP addresses or IP addresses from a VCN within your tenancy. After you create the network source, you use policy to restrict access to only requests that originate from the IPs in the network source. </dd>
<dt class="dt dlterm">COMPARTMENT</dt>
<dd class="dd"><span id="Componen__ph_compartment-keyconcept1">A collection of related resources.</span>
<span id="Componen__ph_compartment-keyconcept2">Compartments are a fundamental component of Oracle Cloud Infrastructure for organizing and isolating your cloud resources.</span>
<span id="Componen__ph_compartment-keyconcept3">You use them to clearly separate resources for the purposes of measuring usage and billing, access (through the use of policies), and isolation (separating the resources for one project or business unit from another). A common approach is to create a compartment for each major part of your organization.</span>
<span id="Componen__ph_compartment-keyconcept4">For more information, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/GSG/Concepts/settinguptenancy.htm">Learn Best Practices for Setting Up Your Tenancy</a>.</span></dd>
<dt class="dt dlterm">TENANCY</dt>
<dd class="dd">The root compartment that contains <em>all </em>of your organization's Oracle Cloud Infrastructure resources. Oracle automatically creates your company's tenancy for you. Directly within the tenancy are your IAM entities (users, groups, compartments, and some policies; you can also put policies into compartments inside the tenancy). You place the other types of cloud resources (e.g., instances, virtual networks, block storage volumes, etc.) inside the compartments that you create. </dd>
<dt class="dt dlterm">POLICY</dt>
<dd class="dd">A document
that specifies who can access which resources, and how. Access is granted at the group and compartment level, which means you can write a policy that gives a group a specific type of access within a specific compartment, or to the tenancy itself. If you give a group access to the tenancy, the group automatically gets the same type of access to all the compartments inside the tenancy. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="overview.htm#Example">Example Scenario</a> and <a class="xref" href="policies.htm#How_Policies_Work">How Policies Work</a>. The word "policy" is used by people in different ways: to mean an individual statement written in the policy language; to mean a collection of statements  in a single, named "policy" document (which has an Oracle Cloud ID (OCID) assigned to it); and to mean the overall body of policies your organization uses to control  access to resources. </dd>
<dd class="dd ddexpand">When you apply a policy, there might be a slight delay before the policy is
                    effective.</dd>
<dt class="dt dlterm">HOME REGION</dt>
<dd class="dd">The region where your IAM resources reside. All IAM resources are global and available across all regions, but the master set of definitions reside in a single region, the home region. You must make changes to your IAM resources in your home region. The changes will be automatically propagated to all regions. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/managingregions.htm#Managing_Regions">Managing Regions</a>.</dd>
<dt class="dt dlterm">FEDERATION</dt>
<dd class="dd">A relationship that an administrator configures between an identity provider and a service provider. When you federate Oracle Cloud Infrastructure with an identity provider, you manage users and groups in the identity provider. You manage authorization in Oracle Cloud Infrastructure's IAM service. Oracle Cloud Infrastructure tenancies are federated with Oracle Identity Cloud Service by default.</dd>
</dl>
</div>
</article><article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title3" class="topic nested1" id="two">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title3">Services You Can Control Access To</h2>
<div class="body">
<p>You can write policies to control access to all of the <a class="xref" href="../../services.htm" title="Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI) is a set of complementary cloud services that enable you to build and run a range of applications and services in a highly available hosted environment." uk-tooltip="">services</a> within Oracle Cloud Infrastructure. </p>
</div>
</article><article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title4" class="topic nested1" id="The">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title4">The Administrators Group and Policy<a name="The"></a></h2>
<div class="body">
<p>When your company signs up for an Oracle account and Identity Domain, Oracle sets up a <em>default administrator</em> for the account.  This person will be the first IAM user for your company and will be responsible for initially setting up additional administrators. Your tenancy comes with a group called <em>Administrators</em>, and the default administrator automatically belongs in this group. You can't delete this group, and there must always be at least one user in it.</p>
<p>Your tenancy also automatically has a policy that gives the Administrators group access to all of the Oracle Cloud Infrastructure API operations and all of the cloud resources in your tenancy. You can neither change nor delete this policy. Any other users you put into the Administrators group will have full access to all of the  services. This means they can create and manage  IAM resources such as, groups, policies, and compartments. And they can create and manage the cloud resources such as virtual cloud networks (VCNs), instances, block storage volumes, and any other new types of Oracle Cloud Infrastructure resources that become available in the future.</p>
</div>
</article><article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title5" class="topic nested1" id="Example">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title5">Example Scenario<a name="Example"></a></h2>
<div class="body">
<p>The goal of this scenario is to show how the different IAM components work together, and basic features of
            policies.</p>
<p>In this scenario, Acme Company has two teams that will be using Oracle Cloud Infrastructure resources for infrastructure: Project A and
            Project B. In reality, your company may have many more.</p>
<p>Acme Company plans to use a single virtual cloud network (VCN) for both teams, and wants a network administrator to manage the VCN.</p>
<p>Acme Company also wants the Project A team and Project B team to <em>each </em>have their own set of instances and block storage volumes. The Project A team and Project B teams shouldn't be able to use each other's instances. These two teams also shouldn't be allowed to change anything about the VCN set up by the network administrator. Acme Company wants each team to have administrators for that team's resources. The administrators for the Project A team can decide who can use the Project A cloud resources, and how. Same for the Project B team.</p>
<section class="section"><h3 class="title sectiontitle vl-no-in-page-toc">Acme Company Gets Started with Oracle Cloud Infrastructure</h3>
<p>Acme Company signs up to use Oracle Cloud Infrastructure and tells
                Oracle that an employee named Wenpei will be the default administrator. In response,
                Oracle:</p>
<ul>
<li> Creates a tenancy for Acme Company (see the following diagram).</li>
<li>Creates an IAM user account for Wenpei in
                    the tenancy.</li>
<li> Creates the Administrators group in the tenancy and places Wenpei in that group.</li>
<li>Creates a policy in Acme Company's tenancy that gives the Administrators group access to manage all of the resources in the tenancy. Here's that policy:</li>
</ul>
<pre class="pre codeblock"><code>Allow group Administrators to manage all-resources in tenancy</code></pre>
<p>
<div uk-lightbox=""><a href="../../Resources/Images/identity_scenario_step1.jpg"><img alt="This image shows the tenancy with the initial group, user, and policy." src="../../Resources/Images/identity_scenario_step1.jpg" tabindex="" title="Click to expand"/></a></div>
</p>
</section>
<section class="section"><h3 class="title sectiontitle vl-no-in-page-toc">The Default Administrator Creates Some Groups and Another Administrator</h3>
<p>Wenpei next creates several groups and users (see the following diagram). She:</p>
<ul>
<li>Creates groups called <em>NetworkAdmins</em>, <em>A-Admins</em>, and <em>B-Admins</em> (these last two are for Project A and Project B within the company)</li>
<li>Creates a user called Alex and puts him in the Administrators group.</li>
<li>Leaves the  new groups empty.</li>
</ul>
<p>To learn how to create groups, see <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/managinggroups.htm#Working">Working with Groups</a>. To learn how to create users and put them in groups, see <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/managingusers.htm#Working">Working with Users</a>.</p>
<p>
<div uk-lightbox=""><a href="../../Resources/Images/identity_scenario_step2.jpg"><img alt="This image builds on the previous one by adding more users and groups." src="../../Resources/Images/identity_scenario_step2.jpg" tabindex="" title="Click to expand"/></a></div>
</p>
</section>
<section class="section"><h3 class="title sectiontitle vl-no-in-page-toc">The Default Administrator Creates Some Compartments and Policies</h3>
<p>Wenpei next creates compartments to group resources  together (see the following diagram). She:</p>
<ul>
<li>Creates a compartment called <em>Networks</em> to control access to the Acme
                    Company's VCN, subnets, Site-to-Site VPN, and other
                    components from Networking. </li>
<li>Creates a compartment called <em>Project-A</em> to organize Project A team's cloud resources and control access to them.</li>
<li>Creates a compartment called <em>Project-B</em> to organize Project B team's cloud resources and control access to them.</li>
</ul>
<p>To learn how to manage compartments, see <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/managingcompartments.htm#Working">Working with Compartments</a>. </p>
<p>Wenpei then creates a policy to give the administrators for each compartment their required level of access. She attaches the policy to the tenancy, which means that only users with access to manage policies in the tenancy can later update or delete the policy. In this scenario, that is only the Administrators group. The policy includes multiple statements that:</p>
<ul>
<li>Give the NetworkAdmins group access to manage networks and instances (for the purposes of easily testing the network) in the Networks compartment </li>
<li>Give both the A-Admins and B-Admins groups access to use the networks in the Networks compartment (so they can create instances into the network).
</li>
<li>Give the A-Admins group access to manage all resources in the Project-A compartment.</li>
<li>Give the B-Admins group access to manage all resources in the Project-B compartment.</li>
</ul>
<p>Here's what that policy looks like (notice it has multiple statements in it):</p>
<pre class="pre codeblock"><code>Allow group NetworkAdmins to manage virtual-network-family in compartment Networks
Allow group NetworkAdmins to manage instance-family in compartment Networks

Allow group A-Admins,B-Admins to use virtual-network-family in compartment Networks

Allow group A-Admins to manage all-resources in compartment Project-A

Allow group B-Admins to manage all-resources in compartment Project-B
</code></pre>
<p>Notice the difference in the verbs (<code class="ph codeph">manage, use</code>), as well as the resources (<code class="ph codeph">virtual-network-family, instance-family, all-resources</code>). For more information about them, see <a class="xref" href="policies.htm#Verbs">Verbs</a> and <a class="xref" href="policies.htm#Resource-Types">Resource-Types</a>.To learn how to create policies, see <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/managingpolicies.htm#To_create_a_policy">To create a policy</a>.</p>
<div class="uk-alert uk-alert-success"><span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="check"></span><strong> Important</strong><br/><br/> A-Admins and B-Admins can <em>use</em> the virtual-network-family in the compartment Networks. However, they can't create instances in that compartment. They can only create instances in the Project-A or Project-B compartment. Remember, a compartment is a logical grouping, not a physical one, so resources that make up or reside on the same VCN can belong to different compartments.</div>
<p>Acme Company wants to let the administrators of the Project-A and Project-B compartments decide which users can use the resources in those compartments. So Wenpei creates two more groups: A-Users and B-Users. She then adds six more statements that give the compartment admins the required access they need in order to add and remove users from those groups:</p>
<pre class="pre codeblock"><code>Allow group A-Admins to use users in tenancy where target.group.name='A-Users'
Allow group A-Admins to use groups in tenancy where target.group.name='A-Users'

Allow group B-Admins to use users in tenancy where target.group.name='B-Users'
Allow group B-Admins to use groups in tenancy where target.group.name='B-Users'

Allow group A-Admins,B-Admins to inspect users in tenancy
Allow group A-Admins,B-Admins to inspect groups in tenancy</code></pre>
<p>Notice that this policy doesn't let the project admins <em>create</em> new users or manage credentials for the users. It lets them decide which existing users can be in the A-Users and B-Users groups. The last two statements are necessary  for A-Admins and B-Admins to list all the users and groups, and confirm which users are in which groups.</p>
<p>
<div uk-lightbox=""><a href="../../Resources/Images/identity_scenario_step3.jpg"><img alt="This image builds on the previous one by adding compartments and policy statements." src="../../Resources/Images/identity_scenario_step3.jpg" tabindex="" title="Click to expand"/></a></div>
</p>
<div class="uk-overflow-auto"><table class="table vl-table-bordered vl-table-divider-col" id="Example__table_lqf_wtl_ltb" summary="Descriptions for the callout item"><caption></caption><colgroup><col style="width:0.25"/><col style="width:100%"/></colgroup><thead class="thead">
<tr class="row">
<th class="entry" id="Example__table_lqf_wtl_ltb__entry__1">Item</th>
<th class="entry" id="Example__table_lqf_wtl_ltb__entry__2">Description</th>
</tr>
</thead><tbody class="tbody">
<tr class="row">
<td class="entry" headers="Example__table_lqf_wtl_ltb__entry__1"><img alt="Callout 1" id="Example__image_glv_wtl_ltb" src="../../Resources/Images/callout_iamtable1.png"/></td>
<td class="entry" headers="Example__table_lqf_wtl_ltb__entry__2">
<div class="p">Policies attached to the tenancy: <ul id="Example__ul_zwz_mby_3tb">
<li><code class="ph codeph">Allow group Administrators to manage all-resources in tenancy</code></li>
<li><code class="ph codeph">Allow group NetworkAdmins to manage virtual-network-family in compartment Networks</code></li>
<li><code class="ph codeph">Allow group NetworkAdmins to manage instance-family in compartment Networks</code></li>
<li><code class="ph codeph">Allow group A-Admins, B-Admins to use virtual-network-family in compartment Networks</code></li>
<li><code class="ph codeph">Allow group A-Admins to manage all-resources in compartment Project-A</code></li>
<li><code class="ph codeph">Allow group B-Admins to manage all-resources in compartment Project-B</code></li>
<li><code class="ph codeph">Allow group A-Admins to use users in tenancy where target.group.name='A-Users'</code></li>
<li><code class="ph codeph">Allow group A-Admins to use groups in tenancy where target.group.name='A-Users'</code></li>
<li><code class="ph codeph">Allow group B-Admins to use users in tenancy where target.group.name='B-Users'</code></li>
<li><code class="ph codeph">Allow group B-Admins to use groups in tenancy where target.group.name='B-Users'</code></li>
<li><code class="ph codeph">Allow group A-Admins, B-Admins to inspect users in tenancy</code></li>
<li><code class="ph codeph">Allow group A-Admins, B-Admins to inspect groups in tenancy</code></li>
</ul></div>
</td>
</tr>
</tbody></table></div>
</section>
<section class="section"><h3 class="title sectiontitle vl-no-in-page-toc">An Administrator Creates New Users</h3>
<p>At this point, Alex is in the Administrators group and now has access to create new users. So he provisions users named  Leslie, Jorge, and Cheri and places them in the  NetworkAdmins, A-Admins, and B-Admins groups, respectively. Alex also creates other users who will eventually be put in the A-Users and B-Users groups by the admins for Project A and Project B.</p>
<p>
<div uk-lightbox=""><a href="../../Resources/Images/identity_scenario_step4.jpg"><img alt="This image builds on the previous one by adding new users and putting them in groups." src="../../Resources/Images/identity_scenario_step4.jpg" tabindex="" title="Click to expand"/></a></div>
</p>
<div class="uk-overflow-auto"><table class="table vl-table-bordered vl-table-divider-col" id="Example__table_c2w_ytl_ltb" summary="Descriptions for the callout item"><caption></caption><colgroup><col style="width:50%"/><col style="width:50%"/></colgroup><thead class="thead">
<tr class="row">
<th class="entry" id="Example__table_c2w_ytl_ltb__entry__1">Item</th>
<th class="entry" id="Example__table_c2w_ytl_ltb__entry__2">Description</th>
</tr>
</thead><tbody class="tbody">
<tr class="row">
<td class="entry" headers="Example__table_c2w_ytl_ltb__entry__1"><img alt="Callout 1" id="Example__image_rbq_15l_ltb" src="../../Resources/Images/callout_iamtable1.png"/></td>
<td class="entry" headers="Example__table_c2w_ytl_ltb__entry__2">
<div class="p">Policies attached to the tenancy: <ul id="Example__ul_th3_dcy_3tb">
<li><code class="ph codeph">Allow group Administrators to manage all-resources in tenancy</code></li>
<li><code class="ph codeph">Allow group NetworkAdmins to manage virtual-network-family in compartment Networks</code></li>
<li><code class="ph codeph">Allow group NetworkAdmins to manage instance-family in compartment Networks</code></li>
<li><code class="ph codeph">Allow group A-Admins, B-Admins to use virtual-network-family in compartment Networks</code></li>
<li><code class="ph codeph">Allow group A-Admins to manage all-resources in compartment Project-A</code></li>
<li><code class="ph codeph">Allow group B-Admins to manage all-resources in compartment Project-B</code></li>
<li><code class="ph codeph">Allow group A-Admins to use users in tenancy where target.group.name='A-Users'</code></li>
<li><code class="ph codeph">Allow group A-Admins to use groups in tenancy where target.group.name='A-Users'</code></li>
<li><code class="ph codeph">Allow group B-Admins to use users in tenancy where target.group.name='B-Users'</code></li>
<li><code class="ph codeph">Allow group B-Admins to use groups in tenancy where target.group.name='B-Users'</code></li>
<li><code class="ph codeph">Allow group A-Admins, B-Admins to inspect users in tenancy</code></li>
<li><code class="ph codeph">Allow group A-Admins, B-Admins to inspect groups in tenancy</code></li>
</ul></div>
</td>
</tr>
</tbody></table></div>
</section>
<section class="section"><h3 class="title sectiontitle vl-no-in-page-toc">The Network Admin Sets Up the Network</h3>
<p>Leslie (in the NetworkAdmins group) has access to manage <code class="ph codeph">virtual-network-family</code> and <code class="ph codeph">instance-family</code> in the Networks compartment. She creates a virtual cloud network (VCN) with a single subnet in that compartment.  She also sets up an Internet gateway for the VCN, and updates the VCN's route table to allow traffic via that gateway. To test the VCN's connectivity to the on-premises network, she launches an instance in the subnet in the VCN. As part of the launch request, she must specify which compartment the instance should reside in. She specifies the Networks compartment, which is the only one she has access to. She then confirms connectivity from the on-premises network to the VCN by logging in to the instance via SSH from the on-premises network.</p>
<p>Leslie terminates her test instance and lets Jorge and Cheri know that the VCN is up and running and ready to try out. She lets them know that their compartments are named Project-A and Project-B respectively. For more information about setting up a cloud network, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Network/Concepts/landing.htm">Networking</a>. For information about launching instances into the network, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Compute/home.htm">Compute</a>.</p>
</section>
<section class="section"><h3 class="title sectiontitle vl-no-in-page-toc">Compartment Admins Set Up Their Compartments</h3>
<p>Jorge and Cheri now need to set up their respective compartments. Each admin needs to do the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>Launch instances in their own compartment</li>
<li>Put users in their "users" group (e.g., A-Users)</li>
<li>Decide the type of access to give those users, and accordingly attach a policy to their compartment</li>
</ul>
<p>Jorge and Cheri both launch instances into the subnet in the VCN, into their respective team's compartments. They create and attach block volumes to the instances. Only the compartment admins can launch/terminate instances or attach/detach block volumes in their respective team's compartments.</p>
<div class="uk-alert uk-alert-success"><span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="check"></span><strong> Important</strong><br/><br/>
<p class="infoTitle">Network Topology and Compartment Access Are Different Concepts</p>
<p> It's important to understand the difference between the network topology of the VCN and the access control that the compartments provide.  The instances Jorge launched reside in the VCN from a network topology standpoint. But from an access standpoint, they're in the Project-A compartment, not the Networks compartment where the VCN is.  Leslie (the Networks admin) can't terminate or reboot Jorge's instances, or launch new ones into the Project-A compartment. But Leslie controls the instances' network, so she controls what traffic will be routed to them. If Jorge had specified the Networks compartment instead of the Project-A compartment when launching his instances, his request would have been denied. The story is similar for Cheri and the Project-B compartment. </p>
<p>But it's also important to note that Wenpei and Alex in the Administrators group do have access to the resources inside the compartments, because they have access to manage all kinds of resources in the tenancy. Compartments inherit any policies attached to their parent compartment (the tenancy), so the Administrators access also applies to all compartments <em>within </em>the tenancy.</p>
</div>
<p>Next, Jorge puts several of the users that Alex created into the A-Users group. Cheri does the same for B-Users. </p>
<p>Then Jorge writes a policy that gives users the level of access they need in the Project-A compartment. </p>
<pre class="pre codeblock"><code>Allow group A-Users to use instance-family in compartment Project-A
Allow group A-Users to use volume-family in compartment Project-A
Allow group A-Users to inspect virtual-network-family in compartment Networks
</code></pre>
<p>This lets them use existing instances (with attached block volumes) that the compartment admins already launched in the compartment, and stop/start/reboot them. It does not let A-Users create/delete or attach/detach any volumes. To give that ability, the policy would need to include <code class="ph codeph">manage volume-family</code>.</p>
<p>Jorge attaches this policy to the Project-A compartment. Anyone with the ability to manage policies <em>in the compartment</em> can now modify or delete this policy. Right now, that is only the A-Admins group (and the Administrators group, which can do anything throughout the tenancy). </p>
<p>Cheri creates and attaches her own policy to the Project-B compartment, similar to Jorge's policy:</p>
<pre class="pre codeblock"><code>Allow group B-Users to use instance-family in compartment Project-B
Allow group B-Users to use volume-family in compartment Project-B
Allow group B-Users to inspect virtual-network-family in compartment Networks
</code></pre>
<p>Now the A-Users and B-Users can work with the existing instances and attached volumes in the Project-A and Project-B compartments, respectively. Here's what the layout looks like:</p>
<p>
<div uk-lightbox=""><a href="../../Resources/Images/identity_scenario_step5.jpg"><img alt="This image builds on the previous one by adding policy statements for some of the compartments." src="../../Resources/Images/identity_scenario_step5.jpg" tabindex="" title="Click to expand"/></a></div>
</p>
<div class="uk-overflow-auto"><table class="table vl-table-bordered vl-table-divider-col" id="Example__table_oc5_42y_3tb" summary="Descriptions for the callout items"><caption></caption><colgroup><col style="width:0.25"/><col style="width:100%"/></colgroup><thead class="thead">
<tr class="row">
<th class="entry" id="Example__table_oc5_42y_3tb__entry__1">Item</th>
<th class="entry" id="Example__table_oc5_42y_3tb__entry__2">Description</th>
</tr>
</thead><tbody class="tbody">
<tr class="row">
<td class="entry" headers="Example__table_oc5_42y_3tb__entry__1"><img alt="Callout 1" src="../../Resources/Images/callout_iamtable1.png"/></td>
<td class="entry" headers="Example__table_oc5_42y_3tb__entry__2">
<div class="p">Policies attached to the tenancy: <ul id="Example__ul_icf_ycy_3tb">
<li><code class="ph codeph">Allow group Administrators to manage all-resources in tenancy</code></li>
<li><code class="ph codeph">Allow group NetworkAdmins to manage virtual-network-family in compartment Networks</code></li>
<li><code class="ph codeph">Allow group NetworkAdmins to manage instance-family in compartment Networks</code></li>
<li><code class="ph codeph">Allow group A-Admins, B-Admins to use virtual-network-family in compartment Networks</code></li>
<li><code class="ph codeph">Allow group A-Admins to manage all-resources in compartment Project-A</code></li>
<li><code class="ph codeph">Allow group B-Admins to manage all-resources in compartment Project-B</code></li>
<li><code class="ph codeph">Allow group A-Admins to use users in tenancy where target.group.name='A-Users'</code></li>
<li><code class="ph codeph">Allow group A-Admins to use groups in tenancy where target.group.name='A-Users'</code></li>
<li><code class="ph codeph">Allow group B-Admins to use users in tenancy where target.group.name='B-Users'</code></li>
<li><code class="ph codeph">Allow group B-Admins to use groups in tenancy where target.group.name='B-Users'</code></li>
<li><code class="ph codeph">Allow group A-Admins, B-Admins to inspect users in tenancy</code></li>
<li><code class="ph codeph">Allow group A-Admins, B-Admins to inspect groups in tenancy</code></li>
</ul></div>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="row">
<td class="entry" headers="Example__table_oc5_42y_3tb__entry__1"><img alt="Callout 2" src="../../Resources/Images/callout_iamtable2.png"/></td>
<td class="entry" headers="Example__table_oc5_42y_3tb__entry__2">
<div class="p">Policy attached and managed by Jorge:<ul id="Example__ul_gnq_3dy_3tb">
<li><code class="ph codeph">Allow group A-Users to use instance-family in compartment Project-A</code></li>
<li><code class="ph codeph">Allow group A-Users to use volume-family in compartment Project-A</code></li>
<li><code class="ph codeph">Allow group A-Users to use virtual-network-family in compartment Project-A</code></li>
</ul></div>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="row">
<td class="entry" headers="Example__table_oc5_42y_3tb__entry__1"><img alt="Callout 3" src="../../Resources/Images/callout_iamtable3.png"/></td>
<td class="entry" headers="Example__table_oc5_42y_3tb__entry__2">
<div class="p">Policy attached and managed by Cheri:<ul id="Example__ul_xxb_mdy_3tb">
<li><code class="ph codeph">Allow group B-Users to use instance-family in compartment Project-B</code></li>
<li><code class="ph codeph">Allow group B-Users to use volume-family in compartment Project-B</code></li>
<li><code class="ph codeph">Allow group B-Users to use virtual-network-family in compartment Project-B</code></li>
</ul></div>
</td>
</tr>
</tbody></table></div>
<p>For more information about basic and advanced features of policies, see <a class="xref" href="policies.htm#How_Policies_Work">How Policies Work</a>. For examples of other typical policies your organization might use, see <a class="xref" href="commonpolicies.htm#top">Common Policies</a>.</p>
</section>
</div>
</article><article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title6" class="topic nested1" id="five">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title6">Viewing Resources by Compartment in the Console</h2>
<div class="body">
<p>In the Console, you view your cloud resources <em>by compartment</em>. This means that after you sign in to the Console, you'll choose which compartment to work in (there's a list of the compartments you have access to on the left side of the page). Notice that compartments can be nested inside other compartments. The page will update to show that compartment's resources that are within the current region. If there are none, or if you don't have access to the resource in that compartment, you'll see a message.</p>
<p>This experience is different when you're viewing the lists of users, groups, dynamic groups, and federation providers. Those reside in the tenancy itself (the root compartment), not in an individual compartment. </p>
<p>As for policies, they can reside in either the tenancy or a compartment, depending on where the policy <em>is attached.</em> Where it's attached controls who has access to modify or delete it. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="policies.htm#Policy3">Policy Attachment</a>.</p>
</div>
</article><article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title7" class="topic nested1" id="six">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title7">The Scope of IAM Resources</h2>
<div class="body">
<p>Oracle Cloud Infrastructure uses the concepts of regions and availability domains (see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/General/Concepts/regions.htm">Regions and Availability Domains</a>). Some resources are available regionally, whereas others are available only within a certain availability domain. IAM resources (users, groups, dynamic groups, compartments, tag namespaces, federation providers, and policies) are global and available across all regions. See <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/managingregions.htm#Managing_Regions">Managing Regions</a>.</p>
</div>
</article><article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title8" class="topic nested1" id="iamevents">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title8">Creating Automation with Events</h2>
<div class="body">
<p>You can create automation based on state changes for Oracle Cloud Infrastructure resources by using event types, rules, and actions. <span id="iamevents__ph_pointertoevents">For more information, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Events/Concepts/eventsoverview.htm">Overview of Events</a>.</span></p>
<p>The following IAM resources emit events: </p>
<ul>
<li>Authentication policies</li>
<li>Credentials </li>
<li>Dynamic groups</li>
<li>Groups</li>
<li>Identity Providers</li>
<li>Multifactor Authentication TOTP Devices</li>
<li>Policies</li>
<li>Users</li>
</ul>
</div>
</article><article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title9" class="topic nested1" id="seven">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title9">Resource Identifiers</h2>
<div class="body">
<p>Most types of Oracle Cloud Infrastructure resources have a unique, Oracle-assigned identifier called an Oracle Cloud ID (OCID). For information about the OCID format and other ways to identify your resources, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/General/Concepts/identifiers.htm">Resource Identifiers</a>.</p>
</div>
</article><article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title10" class="topic nested1" id="Ways">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title10">Ways to Access Oracle Cloud Infrastructure</h2>
<div class="body">
<div>
<p id="Ways__p_waystoaccess">You can access Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI) by using the <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/GSG/Tasks/signingin_topic-Signing_In_for_the_First_Time.htm">Console</a> (a browser-based interface), <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/API/Concepts/usingapi.htm">REST API</a>, or <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/API/Concepts/cliconcepts.htm">OCI CLI</a>.<span id="Ways__ph_instructions"> Instructions for using the Console, API, and CLI are included in topics throughout this documentation.</span>
<span id="Ways__ph_sdks">For a list of available SDKs, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/API/Concepts/sdks.htm">Software Development Kits and Command Line Interface</a>.</span></p>
<p id="Ways__p_console-access"><span id="Ways__ph_console-access">To access <span id="Ways__ph_console-access-for-service">the <a class="xref" href="https://cloud.oracle.com/">Console</a>, you must use a <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/GSG/Tasks/signinginIdentityDomain.htm#supported-browsers">supported browser</a>. To go to the Console sign-in page, open the navigation menu at the top of this page and select <strong class="ph uicontrol">Infrastructure Console</strong>. You are prompted to enter your cloud tenant, your user name, and your password.</span></span></p>
</div>
<p>For general information about using the API, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/API/Concepts/usingapi.htm">REST APIs</a>.</p>
</div>
</article><article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title11" class="topic nested1" id="Limits">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title11">Limits on IAM Resources</h2>
<div class="body">
<p>For a list of applicable limits and <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/General/Concepts/servicelimits-request-increase.htm">instructions for requesting a limit increase</a>, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/General/Concepts/servicelimits.htm">Limits by Service</a>. To set compartment-specific limits on a resource or resource family, administrators can use <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/Quotas/Concepts/resourcequotas.htm">compartment quotas</a>.</p>
</div>
</article></article></article>

  <div class="section" id="iam">
<h1>iam<a class="headerlink" href="#iam" title="Permalink to this headline">¶</a></h1>
<div class="section" id="description">
<h2>Description<a class="headerlink" href="#description" title="Permalink to this headline">¶</a></h2>
<p>Use the Identity and Access Management Service CLI to manage users, groups, identity domains, compartments, policies, tagging, and limits. For information about managing users, groups, compartments, and policies, see <a class="reference external" href="https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/iaas/Content/Identity/Concepts/overview.htm">Identity and Access Management (without identity domains)</a>. For information about tagging and service limits, see <a class="reference external" href="https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/iaas/Content/Tagging/Concepts/taggingoverview.htm">Tagging</a> and <a class="reference external" href="https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/iaas/Content/General/Concepts/servicelimits.htm">Service Limits</a>. For information about creating, modifying, and deleting identity domains, see <a class="reference external" href="https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/iaas/Content/Identity/home.htm">Identity and Access Management (with identity domains)</a>.</p>
</div>
