<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title1" role="article"><article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title1" class="topic nested0" id="How_Policies_Work">
<h1 class="title topictitle1" id="ariaid-title1">How Policies Work</h1>
<div class="body">
<p>This topic describes how policies work and the basic features.</p>
</div>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title2" class="topic nested1" id="Overview">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title2">Overview of Policies</h2>
<div class="body">
<p>A <em>policy </em>is a document that specifies who can access which Oracle Cloud Infrastructure resources that your company has, and how. A policy simply allows a <strong title="A collection of users who all need a particular type of access to a set of resources or compartment." uk-tooltip="">group <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong> to work in certain ways with specific types of <strong title="The cloud objects that you create and use when interacting with Oracle Cloud Infrastructure." uk-tooltip="">resources <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong> in a particular <strong title="A collection of related resources that can be accessed only by groups that have been given permission by an administrator in your organization. Compartments can have a hierarchical structure, allowing for the creation of parent compartments and child compartments (also referred to as subcompartments)." uk-tooltip="">compartment <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong>. If you're not familiar with users, groups, or compartments, see <a class="xref" href="overview.htm#Overview_of_Oracle_Cloud_Infrastructure_Identity_and_Access_Management">Overview of Identity and Access Management</a>. </p>
<p>In general, here's the process an IAM administrator in your organization needs to follow:</p>
<ol>
<li>Define users, groups, and one or more compartments to hold the cloud resources for your organization.</li>
<li>Create  one or more policies, each written in the policy language. See <a class="xref" href="commonpolicies.htm#top">Common Policies</a>.</li>
<li>Place users into the appropriate groups depending on the compartments and resources they need to work with.</li>
<li>Provide the users with the one-time passwords that they need in order to access the Console and work with the compartments. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="usercredentials.htm#User_Credentials">User Credentials</a>. </li>
</ol>
<p>After the administrator completes these steps, the users can access the Console, change their one-time passwords, and work with specific cloud resources as stated in the policies. </p>
</div>
</article><article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title3" class="topic nested1" id="Policy">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title3">Policy Basics<a name="Policy"></a></h2>
<div class="body">
<p>To govern control of your resources, your company will have at least one policy. Each policy consists of one or more policy<em> statements</em> that follow this basic syntax:</p>
<pre class="pre codeblock"><code>Allow group <var class="keyword varname">&lt;group_name&gt;</var> to <var class="keyword varname">&lt;verb&gt;</var> <var class="keyword varname">&lt;resource-type&gt;</var> in compartment <var class="keyword varname">&lt;compartment_name&gt;</var></code></pre>
<p>Notice that the statements always begin with the word <code class="ph codeph">Allow</code>. Policies only <em>allow</em> access; they cannot deny it. Instead there's an implicit deny, which means by default, users can do nothing and have to be granted access through policies. (There's one exception to this rule; see <a class="xref" href="policygetstarted.htm#Can">Can users do anything without an administrator writing a policy for them?</a>) </p>
<p>An administrator in your organization defines the groups and compartments in your tenancy. Oracle defines the possible verbs and resource-types you can use in policies (see <a class="xref" href="policies.htm#Verbs">Verbs</a> and <a class="xref" href="policies.htm#Resource-Types">Resource-Types</a>).</p>
<p>In some cases you'll want the policy to apply to the tenancy and not a compartment inside the tenancy. In that case, change the end of the policy statement like so:</p>
<pre class="pre codeblock"><code>Allow group <var class="keyword varname">&lt;group_name&gt;</var> to <var class="keyword varname">&lt;verb&gt;</var> <var class="keyword varname">&lt;resource-type&gt;</var> in tenancy</code></pre>
<p>For more details about the syntax, see <a class="xref" href="policysyntax.htm#Policy_Syntax">Policy Syntax</a>.</p>
<p>For information about how many policies you can have, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/General/Concepts/servicelimits.htm">Limits by Service</a>.</p>
</div>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title4" class="topic nested2" id="A_Few_Examples">
<h3 class="title topictitle3" id="ariaid-title4">A Few Examples</h3>
<div class="body">
<p>Let's say your administrator creates a group called <em>HelpDesk</em> whose job is to manage users and their credentials. Here is a policy that enables that: </p>
<pre class="pre codeblock"><code>Allow group HelpDesk to manage users in tenancy</code></pre>
<p>Notice that because users reside in the tenancy (the root compartment), the policy simply states the word <code class="ph codeph">tenancy</code>, without the word <code class="ph codeph">compartment</code> in front of it.</p>
<p>Next, let's say you have a compartment called <em>Project-A</em>, and a group called <em>A-Admins</em> whose job is to manage all of the Oracle Cloud Infrastructure resources in the compartment. Here's an example policy that enables that:</p>
<pre class="pre codeblock"><code>Allow group A-Admins to manage all-resources in compartment Project-A</code></pre>
<p>Be aware that the policy directly above includes the ability to write policies <em>for that compartment</em>, which means A-Admins can control access to the compartment's resources. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="policies.htm#Policy3">Policy Attachment</a>.</p>
<p>If you wanted to limit A-Admins' access to only launching and managing compute instances and block storage volumes (both the volumes and their backups) in the Project-A compartment, but the network itself lives in the Networks compartment, then the policy could instead be:</p>
<pre class="pre codeblock"><code>Allow group A-Admins to manage instance-family in compartment Project-A

Allow group A-Admins to manage volume-family in compartment Project-A

Allow group A-Admins to use virtual-network-family in compartment Networks</code></pre>
<p>The third statement with the <code class="ph codeph">virtual-network-family</code> resource-type enables the instance launch process, because the cloud network is involved. Specifically, the launch process creates a new VNIC and attaches it to the subnet where the instance resides.</p>
<p>For additional examples, see <a class="xref" href="commonpolicies.htm#top">Common Policies</a>.</p>
</div>
</article><article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title5" class="topic nested2" id="Details_about_Specifying_Groups_and_Compartments">
<h3 class="title topictitle3" id="ariaid-title5">Details about Specifying Groups and Compartments</h3>
<div class="body">
<p>Typically you'll specify a group or compartment by name in the policy. However, you can use the OCID instead. Just make sure to add "<code class="ph codeph">id</code>" before the OCID. For example:</p>
<pre class="pre codeblock"><code>Allow group

 <span class="Highlight">id</span> ocid1.group.oc1..aaaaaaaaqjihfhvxmumrl3isyrjw3n6c4rzwskaawuc7i5xwe6s7qmnsbc6a

 to manage instance-family in compartment Project-A</code></pre>
<p>You can specify multiple groups  separated by commas: </p>
<pre class="pre codeblock"><code>Allow group <span class="Highlight">A-Admins, B-Admins</span> to manage instance-family in compartment Projects-A-and-B</code></pre>
</div>
</article><article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title6" class="topic nested2" id="Verbs">
<h3 class="title topictitle3" id="ariaid-title6">Verbs<a name="Verbs"></a><a name="Verbs"></a></h3>
<div class="body">
<p>Oracle defines the possible verbs  you can use in your policies.  Here's a summary of the verbs, from least amount of access to the most: </p>
<div>
<div class="uk-overflow-auto"><table class="table vl-table-divider-col" summary="This table summarizes the verbs you can use in a policy statement."><caption></caption><colgroup><col style="width:20.161290322580648%"/><col style="width:20.161290322580648%"/><col style="width:59.67741935483871%"/></colgroup><thead class="thead">
<tr class="row">
<th class="entry" id="Verbs__entry__1">Verb</th>
<th class="entry" id="Verbs__entry__2">Target User</th>
<th class="entry" id="Verbs__entry__3">Types of Access Covered</th>
</tr>
</thead><tbody class="tbody">
<tr class="row">
<th class="entry" headers="Verbs__entry__1" id="Verbs__entry__4" scope="row"><code class="ph codeph">inspect</code>
</th>
<td class="entry" headers="Verbs__entry__4 Verbs__entry__2">Third-party auditors</td>
<td class="entry" headers="Verbs__entry__4 Verbs__entry__3">Ability to list resources, without access to any confidential information or user-specified metadata that might be part of that resource. <strong>Important:</strong> The operation to list policies includes the contents of the policies themselves. The list operations for the Networking resource-types return all the information (for example, the contents of security lists and route tables). </td>
</tr>
<tr class="row">
<th class="entry" headers="Verbs__entry__1" id="Verbs__entry__7" scope="row"><code class="ph codeph">read</code>
</th>
<td class="entry" headers="Verbs__entry__7 Verbs__entry__2">Internal auditors</td>
<td class="entry" headers="Verbs__entry__7 Verbs__entry__3">Includes <code class="ph codeph">inspect</code> plus the ability to get user-specified metadata and the actual resource itself. </td>
</tr>
<tr class="row">
<th class="entry" headers="Verbs__entry__1" id="Verbs__entry__10" scope="row"><code class="ph codeph">use</code>
</th>
<td class="entry" headers="Verbs__entry__10 Verbs__entry__2">Day-to-day end users of resources</td>
<td class="entry" headers="Verbs__entry__10 Verbs__entry__3">Includes <code class="ph codeph">read</code> plus the ability to work with existing resources (the actions vary by resource type). Includes the ability to update the resource, except for resource-types where the "update" operation has the same effective impact as the "create" operation (for example, <code class="ph codeph">UpdatePolicy</code>, <code class="ph codeph">UpdateSecurityList</code>, and more), in which case the "update" ability is available only with the <code class="ph codeph">manage</code> verb. In general, this verb doesn't include the ability to create or delete that type of resource.</td>
</tr>
<tr class="row">
<th class="entry" headers="Verbs__entry__1" id="Verbs__entry__13" scope="row"><code class="ph codeph">manage</code>
</th>
<td class="entry" headers="Verbs__entry__13 Verbs__entry__2">Administrators</td>
<td class="entry" headers="Verbs__entry__13 Verbs__entry__3">Includes all permissions for the resource.</td>
</tr>
</tbody></table></div>
</div>
<p>The verb gives a certain general type of access (for example, <code class="ph codeph">inspect</code> lets you list and get resources). When you then join that type of access with a particular resource-type in a policy (for example, <code class="ph codeph">Allow group XYZ to <span class="Highlight">inspect compartments</span> in the tenancy</code>), then you give that group access to a specific set of permissions and API operations (for example, <code class="ph codeph">ListCompartments</code>, <code class="ph codeph">GetCompartment</code>). For more examples, see <a class="xref" href="../Reference/iampolicyreference.htm#Identity">Details for Verbs + Resource-Type Combinations</a>. Each service details the list of API operations covered for each combination of verb and resource-type. </p>
<p>some special exceptions or nuances for certain resource-types. </p>
<p><strong>Users:</strong> Access to both <code class="ph codeph">manage users</code> and <code class="ph codeph">manage groups</code> lets you do anything with users and groups, including creating and deleting users and groups, and adding/removing users from groups. To add/remove users from groups without access to creating and deleting users and groups, only both <code class="ph codeph">use users</code> and <code class="ph codeph">use groups</code> are required. See <a class="xref" href="commonpolicies.htm#top">Common Policies</a>. </p>
<p><strong>Policies:</strong> The ability to update a policy is available only with <code class="ph codeph">manage policies</code>, not <code class="ph codeph">use policies</code>, because updating a policy is similar in effect to creating a new policy (you can overwrite the existing policy statements). In addition,  <code class="ph codeph">inspect policies </code>lets you get the full contents of the policies. </p>
<p><strong>Object Storage objects:</strong>
<code class="ph codeph">inspect objects</code> lets you list all the objects in a  bucket and do a HEAD operation for a particular object. In comparison, <code class="ph codeph">read objects</code> lets you download the object itself.</p>
<p><strong>Load Balancer resources:</strong> Be aware that <code class="ph codeph">inspect load-balancers</code> lets you get <em>all</em> information about your load balancers and related components (backend sets, and more.). </p>
<p><strong>Networking resources:</strong>
</p>
<div>
<p>Be aware that the <code class="ph codeph">inspect</code> verb not only returns general information about the cloud network's components (for example, the name and OCID of a security list, or of a route table). It also includes the contents of the component (for example, the actual rules in the security list, the routes in the route table, and so on). </p>
<p class="keepWithNext">Also, the following types of abilities are available only with the <code class="ph codeph">manage</code> verb, not the <code class="ph codeph">use</code> verb:</p>
<ul>
<li>Update (enable/disable) <code class="ph codeph">internet-gateways</code></li>
<li>Update <code class="ph codeph">security-lists</code></li>
<li>Update <code class="ph codeph">route-tables</code></li>
<li>Update <code class="ph codeph">dhcp-options</code></li>
<li>Attach a Dynamic Routing Gateway (DRG) to a Virtual Cloud Network (VCN)</li>
<li>Create an IPSec connection between a DRG and customer-premises equipment (CPE)</li>
<li>Peer VCNs</li>
</ul>
<div class="uk-alert uk-alert-success"><span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="check"></span><strong> Important</strong><br/><br/> Each VCN has various components that directly affect the behavior of the network (route tables, security lists, DHCP options, Internet Gateway, and so on). When you create one of these components, you establish a relationship between that component and the VCN, which means you must be allowed in a policy to both create the component and manage the VCN itself. However, the ability to <em>update</em> that component (to change the route rules, security list rules, and so on) <strong>doesn't</strong> require permission to manage the VCN itself, even though changing that component can directly affect the behavior of the network. This discrepancy is designed to give you flexibility in granting least privilege to users, and not require you to grant excessive access to the VCN so the user can manage other components of the network. Be aware that by giving someone the ability to update a particular type of component, you're implicitly trusting them with controlling the network's behavior.</div>
</div>
</div>
</article><article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title7" class="topic nested2" id="Resource-Types">
<h3 class="title topictitle3" id="ariaid-title7">Resource-Types</h3>
<div class="body">
<p>Oracle also defines the resource-types you can use in your policies. First, there are<em> individual </em>types. Each individual type represents a specific type of resource. For example, the <code class="ph codeph">vcns</code> resource-type is specifically for virtual cloud networks (VCNs). </p>
<p>To make policy writing easier, there are <em>family</em> types that include multiple individual resource-types that are often managed together.  For example, the <code class="ph codeph">virtual-network-family</code> type brings together a variety of types related to the management of  VCNs (e.g., <code class="ph codeph">vcns</code>, <code class="ph codeph">subnets</code>, <code class="ph codeph">route-tables</code>, <code class="ph codeph">security-lists</code>, etc.). If you need to write a more granular policy that gives access to only an individual resource-type, you can. But you can also easily write a policy to give access to a broader range of resources.</p>
<p> In another example: Block Volume has <code class="ph codeph">volumes</code>, <code class="ph codeph">volume-attachments</code>, and <code class="ph codeph">volume-backups</code>. If you need to give access to only making backups of volumes, you can specify the<code class="ph codeph"> volume-backups</code> resource-type in your policy. But if you need to give broad access to all of the Block Volume resources, you can specify the family type called <code class="ph codeph">volume-family</code>. For a full list of the family resource-types, see <a class="xref" href="../Reference/policyreference.htm#Resource">Resource-Types</a>.</p>
<div class="uk-alert uk-alert-success"><span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="check"></span><strong> Important</strong><br/><br/> If a service introduces new individual resource-types, they will typically be included in the family type for that service. For example, if Networking introduces a new individual resource-type, it will be automatically included in the definition of the <code class="ph codeph">virtual-network-family</code> resource type. For more information about future changes to the definitions of resource-types, see <a class="xref" href="policies.htm#Policies">Policies and Service Updates</a>.</div>
<p>Note that there are other ways to make policies more granular, such as the ability to specify conditions under which the access is granted. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="policyadvancedfeatures.htm#Advanced_Policy_Features">Advanced Policy Features</a>.</p>
<div class="uk-alert uk-alert-success"><span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="check"></span><strong> Important</strong><br/><br/> If a service introduces new permissions for an existing resource type, you must update the policy statement for the existing resource type to make the new permissions take effect. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="known-issues_root.htm#new-permissions-in-family">New permissions in resource-types are not propagated</a> for more information.</div>
</div>
</article><article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title8" class="topic nested2" id="Access_that_Requires_Multiple_ResourceTypes">
<h3 class="title topictitle3" id="ariaid-title8">Access that Requires Multiple Resource-Types</h3>
<div class="body">
<p>Some API operations require access to multiple resource-types. For example, <code class="ph codeph">LaunchInstance</code> requires the ability to create instances and work with a cloud network. The  <code class="ph codeph">CreateVolumeBackup</code> operation requires access to both the volume and the volume backup. That means you'll have separate statements to give access to each resource-type (for an example, see <a class="xref" href="commonpolicies.htm#volume-backup-admins-manage-only-backups">Let volume backup admins manage only backups</a>). These individual statements do not have to be in the same policy. And a user can gain the required access from being in different groups. For example, George could be in one group that gives the required level of access to the <code class="ph codeph">volumes</code> resource-type, and in another group that gives the required access to the <code class="ph codeph">volume-backups</code> resource-type. The sum of the individual statements, regardless of their location in the overall set of policies, gives George access to <code class="ph codeph">CreateVolumeBackup</code>.</p>
</div>
</article><article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title9" class="topic nested2" id="Policy2">
<h3 class="title topictitle3" id="ariaid-title9">Policy Inheritance<a name="Policy2"></a></h3>
<div class="body">
<p>A basic feature of policies is the concept of <em>inheritance</em>: Compartments inherit any policies from their parent compartment. The simplest example is the Administrators group, which automatically comes with your tenancy (see <a class="xref" href="overview.htm#The">The Administrators Group and Policy</a>). There's a built-in policy that enables the Administrators group to do anything  in the tenancy:</p>
<pre class="pre codeblock"><code>Allow group Administrators to manage all-resources in tenancy</code></pre>
<p>Because of policy inheritance, the Administrators group can also do anything in <em>any</em> of the compartments in the tenancy. </p>
<p>To illustrate further, consider a tenancy with three levels of compartments: CompartmentA, CompartmentB, and  ComparmentC, shown here:</p>
<p>
<div uk-lightbox=""><a href="../../Resources/Images/iam_compartment_hierarchy.PNG"><img alt="Image shows CompartmentA. CompartmentB, CompartmentC hierarchy" src="../../Resources/Images/iam_compartment_hierarchy.PNG" tabindex="" title="Click to expand"/></a></div>
</p>
<p>Policies that apply to resources in CompartmentA also apply to resources in CompartmentB and CompartmentC. So this policy:</p>
<pre class="pre codeblock"><code>Allow group NetworkAdmins to manage virtual-network-family in compartment CompartmentA</code></pre>
<p>allows the group NetworkAdmins to manage VCNs in CompartmentA, CompartmentB, and CompartmentC.</p>
</div>
</article><article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title10" class="topic nested2" id="Policy3">
<h3 class="title topictitle3" id="ariaid-title10">Policy Attachment<a name="Policy3"></a></h3>
<div class="body">
<p>Another basic feature of policies is the concept of <em>attachment</em>. When you create a policy you must attach it to a compartment (or the tenancy, which is the root compartment).  <strong>Where you attach it controls who can then modify it or delete it.</strong>  If you attach it to the tenancy (in other words, if the policy <em>is in</em> the root compartment), then anyone with access to manage policies in the tenancy can then change or delete it. Typically that's the Administrators group or any similar group you create and give broad access to. Anyone with access only to a child compartment cannot modify or delete that policy. </p>
<p>If you instead attach the policy to a child compartment, then anyone with access to manage the policies <em>in that compartment</em> can change or delete it. In practical terms, this means it's easy to give compartment administrators (i.e., a group with access to <code class="ph codeph">manage all-resources</code> in the compartment) access to manage their own compartment's policies, without giving them broader access to manage policies that reside in the tenancy. For an example that uses this kind of compartment administrator design, see <a class="xref" href="overview.htm#Example">Example Scenario</a>. (Recall that because of policy inheritance, users with access to manage policies in the tenancy automatically have the ability to manage policies in compartments inside the tenancy.)  </p>
<p>The process of attaching the policy is easy (whether attaching to a compartment or the tenancy): If you're using the Console, when you add the policy to IAM, simply make sure you're in the desired compartment when you create the policy.  If you're using the API, you specify the OCID of the desired compartment (either the tenancy or other compartment) as part of the request to create the policy. </p>
<p>When you attach a policy to a compartment, you must be in that compartment <em>and</em> you must indicate directly in the statement which compartment it applies to. If you are not in the compartment, you'll get an error if you try to attach the policy to a different compartment.  Notice that attachment occurs during policy creation, which means a policy can be attached to only one compartment. To learn how to attach a policy to a compartment, see <a class="xref" href="../Tasks/managingpolicies.htm#To_create_a_policy">To create a policy</a>.</p>
</div>
</article><article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title11" class="topic nested2" id="hierarchy">
<h3 class="title topictitle3" id="ariaid-title11">Policies and Compartment Hierarchies</h3>
<div class="body">
<p>As described in the previous section, a policy statement must specify  the compartment for which access is being granted (or the tenancy). Where you create the policy determines who can update the policy. If you attach the policy to the compartment or its parent, you can simply specify the compartment name. If you attach the policy further up the hierarchy, you must specify the path. The format of the path is each compartment name (or OCID) in the path, separated by a colon:</p>
<p><var class="keyword varname">&lt;compartment_level_1&gt;</var><strong>:</strong><var class="keyword varname">&lt;compartment_level_2&gt;</var><strong>:</strong> . . . <var class="keyword varname">&lt;compartment_level_n&gt;</var></p>
<p>For example, assume you have a three-level compartment hierarchy, shown here:</p>
<p>
<div uk-lightbox=""><a href="../../Resources/Images/iam_compartment_hierarchy.PNG"><img alt="Image shows CompartmentA. CompartmentB, CompartmentC hierarchy" src="../../Resources/Images/iam_compartment_hierarchy.PNG" tabindex="" title="Click to expand"/></a></div>
</p>
<p>You want to create a policy to allow NetworkAdmins to manage VCNs in CompartmentC. If you want to attach this policy to CompartmentC or to its parent, CompartmentB, write this policy statement:</p>
<div class="uk-position-relative"><pre class="pre codeblock scrollcopy"><code>Allow group NetworkAdmins to manage virtual-network-family in compartment CompartmentC</code></pre></div>
<p>However, if you want to attach this policy to CompartmentA (so that only administrators of CompartmentA can modify it), write this policy statement that specifies the path:</p>
<div class="uk-position-relative"><pre class="pre codeblock scrollcopy"><code>Allow group NetworkAdmins to manage virtual-network-family in compartment CompartmentB:CompartmentC</code></pre></div>
<p>To attach this policy to the tenancy, write this policy statement that specifies the path from CompartmentA to CompartmentC:</p>
<div class="uk-position-relative"><pre class="pre codeblock scrollcopy"><code>Allow group NetworkAdmins to manage virtual-network-family in compartment CompartmentA:CompartmentB:CompartmentC</code></pre></div>
</div>
</article><article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title12" class="topic nested2" id="Policies">
<h3 class="title topictitle3" id="ariaid-title12">Policies and Service Updates</h3>
<div class="body">
<p>It's possible that the definition of a verb or resource-type could change in the future.
            For example, let's say that the <code class="ph codeph">virtual-network-family</code> resource-type
            changes to include a new kind of resource that's been added to Networking. By default, your policies automatically stay
            current with any changes in service definition, so any policy you have that gives access
            to <code class="ph codeph">virtual-network-family</code> would automatically include access to the
            newly added resource. </p>
<div class="uk-alert uk-alert-success"><span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="check"></span><strong> Important</strong><br/><br/> If a service introduces new permissions for an existing resource type, you must update the policy statement for the existing resource type to make the new permissions take effect. For more information, see <a class="xref" href="known-issues_root.htm#new-permissions-in-family">New permissions in resource-types are not propagated</a> for more information.</div>
</div>
</article><article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title13" class="topic nested2" id="Writing_Policies_for_Each_Service">
<h3 class="title topictitle3" id="ariaid-title13">Writing Policies for Each Service</h3>
<div class="body">
<p>The <a class="xref" href="../policieshow/Policy_Basics.htm" title="IAM policies govern control of resources in Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI) tenancies." uk-tooltip="">IAM Policies Overview</a> includes details of the specific resource-types for each service, and which verb + resource-type combination gives access to which API operations.</p>
</div>
</article></article></article></article>

<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title1" role="article"><article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title1" class="topic nested0" id="Managing_Dynamic_Groups">
<h1 class="title topictitle1" id="ariaid-title1">Managing Dynamic Groups</h1>
<div class="body">
<p>This topic describes how to manage dynamic groups and define the rules to determine a dynamic group's members.</p>
</div>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title2" class="topic nested1" id="About">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title2">About Dynamic Groups</h2>
<div class="body">
<p>Dynamic groups allow you to group Oracle Cloud Infrastructure compute
            instances as "principal" actors (similar to user groups). You can then create
            policies to permit instances to <a class="xref" href="callingservicesfrominstances.htm#Calling_Services_from_an_Instance">make API
                calls against Oracle Cloud Infrastructure services</a>. When you
            create a dynamic group, rather than adding members explicitly to the group, you instead
            define a set of <em>matching rules</em> to define the group members. For example, a rule
            could specify that all instances in a particular compartment are members of the dynamic
            group. The members can change dynamically as instances are launched and terminated in
            that compartment.</p>
</div>
</article><article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title3" class="topic nested1" id="one">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title3">Required IAM Policy</h2>
<div class="body">
<p>If you're in the Administrators group, then you have the required access for managing dynamic groups. </p>
<p>If you're new to policies, see <a class="xref" href="../Concepts/policygetstarted.htm#Getting_Started_with_Policies">Getting Started with Policies</a> and <a class="xref" href="../Concepts/commonpolicies.htm#top">Common Policies</a>. If you want to dig deeper into writing policies for dynamic groups or other IAM components, see <a class="xref" href="../Reference/iampolicyreference.htm#top">Details for IAM without Identity Domains</a>.</p>
</div>
</article><article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title4" class="topic nested1" id="Tagging_Resources">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title4">Tagging Resources</h2>
<div class="body">
<p>Apply tags to resources to help organize them according to your business needs. You can apply tags when you create a resource, and you can update a resource later to add, revise, or remove tags. For general information about applying tags, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/General/Concepts/resourcetags.htm">Resource Tags</a>.</p>
</div>
</article><article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title5" class="topic nested1" id="Working">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title5">Working with Dynamic Groups</h2>
<div class="body">
<p>When creating a dynamic group, you must provide a unique, unchangeable <em>name </em>for the dynamic group. The name must be unique across all groups within your tenancy. You must also provide the dynamic group with a <em>description</em> (although it can be an empty string), which is a non-unique, changeable description for the group. Oracle will also assign the group a unique ID called an Oracle Cloud ID (OCID). For more information, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/General/Concepts/identifiers.htm">Resource Identifiers</a>. </p>
<div class="uk-alert uk-alert-primary"><span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="file-edit"></span><strong> Note</strong><br/><br/>
<p>If you delete a dynamic group and then create a new dynamic group with the same name, they'll be considered different groups because they'll have different OCIDs. </p>
</div>
<p>A dynamic group has no permissions until you write at least one <strong title='An Identity and Access Management (IAM) document that specifies who has what type of access to your resources. Policy can refer to several types of documents: an individual statement written in the policy language, a collection of statements in a single named "policy" document, and the overall body of policies that your organization uses to control access to resources.' uk-tooltip="">policy <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong> that gives that dynamic group permission to either the tenancy or a compartment. When writing the policy, you can specify the dynamic group by using either the unique name or the dynamic group's OCID. Per the preceding note, even if you specify the dynamic group name  in the policy, IAM internally uses the OCID to determine the dynamic group. For information about writing policies, see <a class="xref" href="managingpolicies.htm#Managing_Policies">Managing Policies</a>. </p>
<p>You can delete a dynamic group, but only if the group is empty.</p>
</div>
</article><article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title6" class="topic nested1" id="Updating_Dynamic_Groups">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title6">Updating Dynamic Groups</h2>
<div class="body">
<p>You can update the matching rules that define the members of a dynamic group. For example, you might change a matching rule that includes all instances in a compartment to exclude a particular instance. Or, you might update a rule to include a new tag value.</p>
<div class="uk-alert uk-alert-success"><span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="check"></span><strong> Important</strong><br/><br/>  When you make a change to a matching rule you must allow about one hour for the updated policy to take effect. For example, if you update tags on an instance to either include or exclude that instance from a dynamic group, you must wait for that policy to take effect to include or exclude the instance.</div>
</div>
</article><article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title7" class="topic nested1" id="Limits_on_Instances_in_Dynamic_Groups">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title7">Limits on Dynamic Groups</h2>
<div class="body">
<p>A single compute instance can belong to a maximum of 5 dynamic groups.  </p>
<p>You can have a maximum of 50 dynamic groups in your tenancy.</p>
</div>
</article><article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title8" class="topic nested1" id="three">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title8">Using the Console</h2>
<div class="body"></div>
<div class="uk-margin-top" uk-accordion=""><div id="To"><a class="uk-accordion-title" href="#" id="ariaid-title9">To create a dynamic group</a><div class="uk-accordion-content"><div aria-labelledby="ariaid-title9" class="topic nested2">
<div class="body">
<ol>
<li>Open the <strong title="Main menu located in the upper-left corner of the Oracle Cloud Console. Use the menu to navigate to OCI services, dashboards, and marketplace." uk-tooltip="">navigation menu <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong> and select <strong class="ph uicontrol">Identity &amp; Security</strong>. Under <strong class="ph uicontrol">Identity</strong>, select <strong class="ph uicontrol">Domains</strong>. Under <strong class="ph uicontrol">Identity domain</strong>, select <strong class="ph uicontrol">Dynamic groups</strong>.</li>
<li>Select <strong>Create Dynamic Group</strong>. </li>
<li>Enter the following:
<ul>
<li><strong>Name:</strong> A unique name for the group. The name must be unique across all groups in your tenancy (dynamic groups and user groups). You can't change this later. Avoid entering confidential information.</li>
<li><strong>Description:</strong> A friendly description.</li></ul></li>
<li>Enter the <strong>Matching Rules</strong>. Resources that meet the rule criteria are members of the group.<ul>
<li><strong>Rule 1:</strong> Enter a rule following the guidelines in <a class="xref" href="managingdynamicgroups.htm#Writing">Writing Matching Rules to Define Dynamic Groups</a>. You can manually enter the rule in the text box or launch the rule builder.</li>
<li><p>Enter additional rules as needed. To add a rule, select <strong>+Additional Rule</strong>.</p></li></ul></li>
<li>
<span id="To__ph_tagging-create-ref">If you have permissions to create a resource, then you also have permissions to apply <em>free-form</em> tags to that resource. To apply a <em>defined</em> tag, you must have permissions to use the tag <em>namespace</em>. For more information about tagging, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/General/Concepts/resourcetags.htm">Resource Tags</a>.</span> If you're not sure whether to apply tags, skip this option or ask an administrator. You can apply tags later.
</li>
<li>
<p>Select <strong>Create Dynamic Group</strong>.</p>
<p>The matching rule syntax is verified, but the OCIDs are not. Be sure that the OCIDs you enter are correct.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>Next, to give the dynamic group permissions, you need to write a policy. See <a class="xref" href="callingservicesfrominstances.htm#Writing">Writing Policies for Dynamic Groups</a>.</p>
</div>
</div></div></div></div><div class="uk-margin-top" uk-accordion=""><div id="To_delete_a_dynamic_group"><a class="uk-accordion-title" href="#" id="ariaid-title10">To delete a dynamic group</a><div class="uk-accordion-content"><div aria-labelledby="ariaid-title10" class="topic nested2">
<div class="body">
<ol>
<li>
Open the <strong title="Main menu located in the upper-left corner of the Oracle Cloud Console. Use the menu to navigate to OCI services, dashboards, and marketplace." uk-tooltip="">navigation menu <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong> and select <strong class="ph uicontrol">Identity &amp; Security</strong>. Under <strong class="ph uicontrol">Identity</strong>, select <strong class="ph uicontrol">Domains</strong>. Under <strong class="ph uicontrol">Identity domain</strong>, select <strong class="ph uicontrol">Dynamic groups</strong>. A list of the dynamic groups in your tenancy is displayed.</li>
<li>Locate the dynamic group in the list. </li>
<li>For the dynamic group you want to delete, select <strong>Delete</strong>.</li>
<li>Confirm when prompted.</li>
</ol>
</div>
</div></div></div></div><div class="uk-margin-top" uk-accordion=""><div id="To_update_a_dynamic_groups_description"><a class="uk-accordion-title" href="#" id="ariaid-title11">To update a dynamic group's description</a><div class="uk-accordion-content"><div aria-labelledby="ariaid-title11" class="topic nested2">
<div class="body">
<ol>
<li>
Open the <strong title="Main menu located in the upper-left corner of the Oracle Cloud Console. Use the menu to navigate to OCI services, dashboards, and marketplace." uk-tooltip="">navigation menu <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong> and select <strong class="ph uicontrol">Identity &amp; Security</strong>. Under <strong class="ph uicontrol">Identity</strong>, select <strong class="ph uicontrol">Domains</strong>. Under <strong class="ph uicontrol">Identity domain</strong>, select <strong class="ph uicontrol">Dynamic groups</strong>. A list of the groups in your tenancy is displayed.</li>
<li>Select the dynamic group you want to update. The dynamic's group's details are
                displayed. </li>
<li>Select <strong>Edit Dynamic Group</strong>.</li>
<li>Edit the description. When finished, select <strong>Save Changes</strong>. </li>
</ol>
</div>
</div></div></div></div><div class="uk-margin-top" uk-accordion=""><div id="To_update_a_dynamic_groups_matching_rules"><a class="uk-accordion-title" href="#" id="ariaid-title12">To update a dynamic group's matching rules</a><div class="uk-accordion-content"><div aria-labelledby="ariaid-title12" class="topic nested2">
<div class="body">
<ol>
<li>
Open the <strong title="Main menu located in the upper-left corner of the Oracle Cloud Console. Use the menu to navigate to OCI services, dashboards, and marketplace." uk-tooltip="">navigation menu <span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="icon: info; ratio: .8"></span></strong> and select <strong class="ph uicontrol">Identity &amp; Security</strong>. Under <strong class="ph uicontrol">Identity</strong>, select <strong class="ph uicontrol">Domains</strong>. Under <strong class="ph uicontrol">Identity domain</strong>, select <strong class="ph uicontrol">Dynamic groups</strong>. A list of the dynamic groups in your tenancy is displayed.</li>
<li>Select the dynamic group you want to update.
The dynamic group's details are displayed. </li>
<li>Select <strong>Edit All Matching Rules</strong>.</li>
<li>Edit the matching rule in the text box; or, you can use the rule builder if the change is <a class="xref" href="managingdynamicgroups.htm#Limitati">supported by the rule builder</a>. 
</li>
</ol>
</div>
</div></div></div></div></article><article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title13" class="topic nested1" id="Writing">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title13">Writing Matching Rules to Define Dynamic Groups<a name="Writing"></a></h2>
<div class="body">
<p>Matching rules define the resources that belong to the dynamic group. In the Console, you can either enter the rule manually in the provided text box, or you can use the <a class="xref" href="managingdynamicgroups.htm#Using2">rule builder</a>. The rule builder lets you make selections and entries in a dialog, then writes the rule for you, based on your entries. </p>
<p>You can define the members of the dynamic group based on the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>compartment ID - include (or exclude) the instances that reside in that compartment based on compartment OCID</li>
<li>instance ID - include (or exclude) an instance based on its instance OCID</li>
<li>tag namespace and tag key -  include (or exclude) instances tagged with a specific tag namespace and tag key. All tag values are included. For example, include all instances tagged the with tag namespace <code class="ph codeph">department</code> and the tag key <code class="ph codeph">operations</code>. </li>
<li>tag namespace, tag key, and tag value -  include (or exclude) instances tagged with a specific value for the tag namespace and tag key. For example include all instances tagged with the tag namespace <code class="ph codeph">department</code> and the tag key <code class="ph codeph">operations</code> and with the value '<code class="ph codeph">45</code>'.</li>
<li>resource.compartment.id - the OCID of the compartment where the resource
                resides</li>
<li>resource.id - the OCID of the resource</li>
<li>resource.type - the type of the resource</li>
</ul>
<p>A matching rule has the following syntax:</p>
<p>For a single condition:</p>
<pre class="pre codeblock"><code>variable =|!= 'value'</code></pre>
<p>For multiple conditions:</p>
<pre class="pre codeblock"><code>any|all {&lt;condition&gt;,&lt;condition&gt;,...}</code></pre>
<p>Supported variables are:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<code class="ph codeph">instance.compartment.id</code> - the OCID of the compartment where the instance resides
            </li>
<li>
<code class="ph codeph">instance.id</code> - the OCID of the instance
            </li>
<li>
<code class="ph codeph">tag.<var class="keyword varname">&lt;tagnamespace&gt;</var>.<var class="keyword varname">&lt;tagkey&gt;</var>.value</code> - the tag namespace and tag key. For example, <code class="ph codeph">tag.department.operations.value</code>.
            </li>
<li>
<code class="ph codeph">tag.<var class="keyword varname">&lt;tagnamespace&gt;</var>.<var class="keyword varname">&lt;tagkey&gt;</var>.value='<var class="keyword varname">&lt;tagvalue&gt;</var>'</code> - the tag namespace, tag key, and tag value. For example, <code class="ph codeph">tag.department.operations.value='45'</code>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Here are some examples:</p>
</div>
<div class="uk-margin-top" uk-accordion=""><div id="Include_All_Instances_in_a_Specific_Compartment_in_the_Dynamic_Group"><a class="uk-accordion-title" href="#" id="ariaid-title14">Include All Instances in a Specific Compartment in the Dynamic Group</a><div class="uk-accordion-content"><div aria-labelledby="ariaid-title14" class="topic nested2">
<div class="body">
<p>To include all instances that are in a specific compartment, add a rule with the following syntax:</p>
<pre class="pre codeblock"><code>instance.compartment.id = '<var class="keyword varname">&lt;compartment_ocid&gt;</var>'</code></pre>
<p>You can type the rule directly in the text box, or you can use the <a class="xref" href="managingdynamicgroups.htm#Using2">rule
            builder</a>.</p>
<p>Example entry in text box:</p>
<pre class="pre codeblock"><code>instance.compartment.id = 'ocid1:compartment:oc1:phx:samplecompartmentocid6q6igvfauxmima74jv'</code></pre>
<p>To add the same rule using the Console rule builder:</p>
<ul>
<li>For <strong>Include Instances That Match:</strong> Select <strong>All of the following</strong>.</li>
<li>For <strong>Match Instances with:</strong> Select <strong>Compartment OCID</strong>.</li>
<li>For <strong>Value:</strong> Enter the compartment OCID. For this example, you would enter
                    <code class="ph codeph">ocid1:compartment:oc1:phx:samplecompartmentocid6q6igvfauxmima74jv</code></li>
</ul>
<p>All instances that currently exist or get created in the compartment (identified by the OCID) are members of this group.</p>
</div>
</div></div></div></div><div class="uk-margin-top" uk-accordion=""><div id="Include_All_Instances_in_Any_of_Two_or_More_Compartments"><a class="uk-accordion-title" href="#" id="ariaid-title15">Include All Instances in Any of Two or More Compartments</a><div class="uk-accordion-content"><div aria-labelledby="ariaid-title15" class="topic nested2">
<div class="body">
<p>To include all instances that reside in any of two (or more) compartments, add a rule with the following syntax:</p>
<pre class="pre codeblock"><code>Any {instance.compartment.id = '<var class="keyword varname">&lt;compartment_ocid&gt;</var>', instance.compartment.id = '<var class="keyword varname">&lt;compartment_ocid&gt;</var>'}</code></pre>
<p>separating each compartment entry with a comma.</p>
<p>You can type the rule directly in the text box, or you can use the <a class="xref" href="managingdynamicgroups.htm#Using2">rule
            builder</a>.</p>
<p>Example entry in the text box:</p>
<pre class="pre codeblock"><code>Any {instance.compartment.id = 'ocid1:compartment:oc1:phx:samplecompartmentocid6q6igvfauxmima74jv', instance.compartment.id = 'ocid1:compartment:oc1:phx:samplecompartmentocidythksk89ekslsoelu2'}</code></pre>
<p>To add the same rule using the Console rule builder:</p>
<ol>
<li>For <strong>Include Instances That Match:</strong> Select <strong>Any of the following</strong>.</li>
<li>For <strong>Match Instances With:</strong> Select <strong>Compartment OCID</strong>.</li>
<li>For <strong>Value:</strong> Enter the compartment OCID. For this example, you would enter
                    <code class="ph codeph">ocid1:compartment:oc1:phx:samplecompartmentocid6q6igvfauxmima74jv</code></li>
<li>Select <strong>+Additional Line</strong>. Enter the following on the second line:<ul>
<li>For <strong>Match Instances With:</strong> Select <strong>Compartment OCID</strong>.</li>
<li>For <strong>Value:</strong> Enter the additional compartment OCID. For this example,
                        you would enter
                            <code class="ph codeph">ocid1:compartment:oc1:phx:samplecompartmentocidythksk89ekslsoelu2</code></li>
</ul></li>
</ol>
<p>Instances that currently exist or are later created in either of the specified
            compartments are members of this group.</p>
</div>
</div></div></div></div><div class="uk-margin-top" uk-accordion=""><div id="Include_All_Instances_Tagged_with_a_Specific_Namespace_and_Tag_Key"><a class="uk-accordion-title" href="#" id="ariaid-title16">Include All Instances Tagged with a Specific Namespace and Tag Key</a><div class="uk-accordion-content"><div aria-labelledby="ariaid-title16" class="topic nested2">
<div class="body">
<p>To include all instances that are tagged with a specific tag namespace and tag key, add a rule with the following syntax:</p>
<pre class="pre codeblock"><code>tag.<var class="keyword varname">&lt;tagnamespace&gt;</var>.<var class="keyword varname">&lt;tagkey&gt;</var>.value</code></pre>
<p> All instances assigned the tagnamespace.tagkey combination are included. Note that the tag value is not evaluated, so all values are included.</p>
<p><strong>Example:</strong> Assume you have a tag namespace called <code class="ph codeph">department</code> and a tag key called <code class="ph codeph">operations</code>. You want to include all instances that are tagged with the namespace and tag key.</p>
<p>Enter the following rule in the text box:</p>
<pre class="pre codeblock"><code>tag.department.operations.value</code></pre>
<p>All instances that currently exist or get created with the tag namespace and tag key <code class="ph codeph">department.operations</code>  are members of this group.</p>
</div>
</div></div></div></div><div class="uk-margin-top" uk-accordion=""><div id="Include_All_Instances_In_a_Specific_Compartment_with_a_Specific_Tag_Namespace_Tag_Key_and_Tag_Value"><a class="uk-accordion-title" href="#" id="ariaid-title17">Include All Instances In a Specific Compartment with a Specific Tag Namespace, Tag Key, and Tag Value</a><div class="uk-accordion-content"><div aria-labelledby="ariaid-title17" class="topic nested2">
<div class="body">
<p>To include all instances in a specific compartment that are tagged with a specific tag namespace, key, and value, add a rule with the following syntax:</p>
<p><code class="ph codeph">All {instance.compartment.id = '<var class="keyword varname">&lt;compartment_ocid&gt;</var>', tag.<var class="keyword varname">&lt;tagnamespace&gt;</var>.<var class="keyword varname">&lt;tagkey&gt;</var>.value='<var class="keyword varname">&lt;tagvalue&gt;</var>'}</code>
</p>
<p>All instances that are in the identified compartment and that are assigned the tagnamespace.tagkey with the specified tag value are included. </p>
<p><strong>Example:</strong> Assume you have a tag namespace called <code class="ph codeph">department</code> and a tag key called <code class="ph codeph">operations</code>. You want to include all instances that are tagged with the value 45, that are in a particular compartment.</p>
<p>Enter the following statement in the text box:</p>
<pre class="pre codeblock"><code>All {instance.compartment.id='ocid1:compartment:oc1:phx:oc1:phx:samplecompartmentocid6q6igvfauxmima74jv,',
tag.department.operations.value='45'}</code></pre>
</div>
</div></div></div></div><article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title18" class="topic nested2" id="Using2">
<h3 class="title topictitle3" id="ariaid-title18">Using the Rule Builder</h3>
<div class="body">
<p>The rule builder is a tool available from the Console to help you write matching rules. The rule builder provides menus and text boxes for you to make entries and then writes the rule for you. The rule builder does have some limitations, so you can't use it for all cases.</p>
</div>
<article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title19" class="topic nested3" id="Limitati">
<h4 class="title topictitle4" id="ariaid-title19">Limitations of the Rule Builder</h4>
<div class="body">
<p>The rule builder does not support the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>Exclusion rules - the rule builder lets you select compartment IDs and instance IDs to include only. </li>
<li>Rules based on tags - the rule builder does not allow you to select tags to include in your rule. To add a rule based on tag values, you need to enter the rule in the Rule text box using the syntax above. </li>
</ul>
</div>
</article><article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title20" class="topic nested3" id="Launching_the_Rule_Builder">
<h4 class="title topictitle4" id="ariaid-title20">Launching the Rule Builder</h4>
<div class="body">
<p>When you select <strong>Create Dynamic Group</strong>, the Rule Builder is displayed in the <strong>Create Dynamic Group</strong> dialog.</p>
<p>To create a matching rule using the rule builder</p>
<ol>
<li>Under the <strong>Matching Rules </strong>section, select <strong>Rule Builder</strong>.</li>
<li>
<p> From the <strong>Include Instances That Match</strong> menu, select <strong>All of the
                        following</strong> or <strong>Any of the following</strong>.</p>
<p><strong>All of the following</strong> includes only instances that match all of the
                    statements in the rule.</p>
<p><strong>Any of the following</strong> includes instances that match any of the statements
                    in the rule.</p>
<div class="uk-alert uk-alert-primary"><span class="vl-1px-up" uk-icon="file-edit"></span><strong> Note</strong><br/><br/> You can select the following instance and compartment
                        variables:<ul id="Launching_the_Rule_Builder__ul_abh_5w1_f5b">
<li><span class="keyword cmdname">instance.compartment.id</span> and
                                <span class="keyword cmdname">instance.id</span> are applicable when matching
                            instances</li>
<li><span class="keyword cmdname">resource.compartment.id</span>,
                                <span class="keyword cmdname">resource.id</span> and <span class="keyword cmdname">resource.type</span>
                            are applicable when matching resources</li>
<li><span class="keyword cmdname">tag.*</span> variables apply to both instances and
                            resources</li>
</ul></div>
</li>
<li>
<p>Select a resource type from the <strong>Match Instances With</strong> menu, and then enter
                    the OCID for the resource in the <strong>Value</strong> field:</p>
<p><strong>Compartment OCID</strong> includes instances in the compartment you specify.</p>
<p><strong>Instance OCID</strong> includes the instances with the OCIDs you specify.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Select <strong>+Additional line</strong> to add more statements to this rule.</p>
<p>When you add multiple statements to a rule, remember that <strong>Any of the following
                    </strong>includes instances that match any of the statements. If you choose <strong>All of
                        the following</strong>, instances must match all of the specifications in the
                    statements to be included in the group.</p>
</li>
</ol>
</div>
</article><article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title21" class="topic nested3" id="Examples_Using_the_Rule_Builder">
<h4 class="title topictitle4" id="ariaid-title21">Examples Using the Rule Builder</h4>
<div class="body"></div>
</article></article><div class="uk-margin-top" uk-accordion=""><div id="unique_1879328961"><a class="uk-accordion-title" href="#" id="ariaid-title22">Include All Instances in a Specific Compartment in the Dynamic Group</a><div class="uk-accordion-content"><div aria-labelledby="ariaid-title22" class="topic nested2">
<div class="body">
<p>To include all instances that are in a specific compartment, using the rule builder: </p>
<ul>
<li>Select <strong>All of the following</strong>.</li>
<li>For <strong>Match Instances With:</strong> Select <strong>Compartment OCID</strong>.</li>
<li>For <strong>Value:</strong> Enter the compartment OCID, for example,
                    <code class="ph codeph">ocid1:compartment:oc1:phx:samplecompartmentocidythksk89ekslsoelu2</code></li>
</ul>
<p>All instances that currently exist or are later created in the compartment (identified by
            the OCID) are members of this group.</p>
</div>
</div></div></div></div><div class="uk-margin-top" uk-accordion=""><div id="unique_1270165896"><a class="uk-accordion-title" href="#" id="ariaid-title23">Include All Instances in Any of Two or More Compartments</a><div class="uk-accordion-content"><div aria-labelledby="ariaid-title23" class="topic nested2">
<div class="body">
<p>To include all instances that reside in any of two (or more) compartments using the rule builder:</p>
<ol>
<li>From the <strong>Include Instances That Match</strong> menu, select <strong>Any of the
                    following</strong>.</li>
<li>In the first line, enter:<ul>
<li>For <strong>Match Instances With</strong>, select <strong>Compartment OCID</strong>.</li>
<li>For <strong>Value</strong>, enter the compartment OCID, for example:
                            <code class="ph codeph">ocid1:compartment:oc1:phx:samplecompartmentocid6q6igvfauxmima74jv</code></li>
</ul></li>
<li>Select <strong>+Additional Line</strong>. Enter the following on the second line:<ul>
<li>For <strong>Match Instances With</strong>, select <strong>Compartment OCID</strong></li>
<li>For <strong>Value</strong>, enter the compartment OCID, for example:
                            <code class="ph codeph">ocid1:compartment:oc1:phx:samplecompartmentocidythksk89ekslsoelu2</code></li></ul></li>
<li>Continue adding additional lines as needed for each compartment you want to include.</li>
</ol>
<p>Instances that currently exist or get created in any of the specified compartments are members of this group.</p>
</div>
</div></div></div></div></article><article aria-labelledby="ariaid-title24" class="topic nested1" id="Using">
<h2 class="title topictitle2 vl-include-in-page-toc" id="ariaid-title24">Using the API</h2>
<div class="body">
<p>For information about using the API and signing requests, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/API/Concepts/usingapi.htm">REST API documentation</a> and <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/General/Concepts/credentials.htm">Security Credentials</a>. For information about SDKs, see <a class="xref" href="/iaas/Content/API/Concepts/sdks.htm">SDKs and the CLI</a>.</p>
<p>Use these API operations to manage dynamic groups:</p>
<ul>
<li><a class="xref" href="/iaas/api/#/en/identity/latest/DynamicGroup/CreateDynamicGroup">CreateDynamicGroup</a>
</li>
<li><a class="xref" href="/iaas/api/#/en/identity/latest/DynamicGroup/ListDynamicGroups">ListDynamicGroups</a>
</li>
<li><a class="xref" href="/iaas/api/#/en/identity/latest/DynamicGroup/GetDynamicGroup">GetDynamicGroup</a>
</li>
<li><a class="xref" href="/iaas/api/#/en/identity/latest/DynamicGroup/UpdateDynamicGroup">UpdateDynamicGroup</a>
</li>
<li><a class="xref" href="/iaas/api/#/en/identity/latest/DynamicGroup/DeleteDynamicGroup">DeleteDynamicGroup</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
</article></article></article>
